Fort Zoutman was built in January 1798 on order of director (governor) Johan R. Lauffer.Lauffer named it after Johan Arnold Zoutman. Zoutman was rear admiral during the Dutch-English war in 1781. Theunis Lourens Vos Jansz and Adriaan Wever were appointed on February 8, 1798, as gunners of the batteries in Aruba.The most important feat of arms of the fort was beating off an English attack in 1799. In 1805, Aruba was in British hands. A Dutch effort to regain the fort on November 18 failed. Still the English left the island. The fort got its current aspect during the restoration of 1826.

title: Asaudi
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Asaudi was a settlement on Hoamoal (Western Seram), a clove-producing region ruled by the <kimelaha>, the leader of Hoamoal with whom the VOC was periodically in conflict. Asaudi periodically sent out raids against the allies of the VOC in the region, and in response, was attacked and destroyed by the VOC several times over the early 17th century. During the Great Ambon War (1651-1656) it was the center of resistance against the VOC, and a base for the Makasar allies of the <kimelaha>, for an extended period. In July 1655, the VOC conquered it after a long deliberate strategy of starving the region. At the end of the war, the entire peninsula was depopulated, and the people living there forced to relocate.

title: Ash Shihr
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Around 1614 VOC official Pieter van den Broeke gained permission to station three merchants in Shihr. They set up a trading post but the opportunities for trade proved disappointing.

title: Ava
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Around 1635 the VOC established an office in Ava, or Awa, which lay north of Birma near the city of Mandalay. Here the Company traded in indigo, saltpetre, mercury and vermilion. In 1679 the Company decided to close down the posts in Siriangh and Ava because of their 'onbehoorlyke maniere van doen en de slegte negotie' ('indecent conduct and the poor relations').

title: Avissawella
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Sitawaka was situated east of Colombo on the road to Kandy. Together with Hanwella it lay on the all-important route linking the mountain region with the coast. Raja Sinha, the king of Kandy, used Sitawaka as a base for his attacks on the enemy Portuguese. Towards the end of the 16th century Sitiwaka's beautiful palaces and temples were razed to the ground by Azevedo, a Portuguese general. Around 1595 the Portuguese built a small fort here. After the VOC wrested power from the Portuguese, the Company built a stronger fort not far distant from the Portuguese castle. When relations with the king of Kandy deteriorated, this fort offered protection against the armies of the king. But Sitawaka also functioned as a halfway house, offering hospitality to VOC ambassadors en route to visit the King of Kandy. Their annual visits to the King of Kandy were major undertakings due to the size of the entourage and the large number of gifts for the monarch. After the fort at Hanwella was reinforced in 1685 the Company left Sitawaka.

title: Axim
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Al in 1503 bezaten de Portugezen in Axim een handelspost. In 1515 werd fort St. Antonio neergezet, het tweede Portugese fort aan de Goudkust (in 1482 vestigden de Portugezen zich in São Jorge da Mina, ofwel Elmina, aan de Goudkust). Tijdens de Portugese aanwezigheid werd nabij Axim een goudmijn geopend. In 1637 veroverden de Nederlanders Elmina op de Portugezen. Vier en een half jaar later, in 1641, veroverden zij ook Axim. Een rapport uit 1706 meldt dat de Nederlanders in Axim meer goud verzamelden dan waar ook. In de loop van de 18de eeuw leverde Axim naast goud ook timmerhout en werd er kantoen verbouwd.

title: Aynamaka
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Ayutthaya
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Ayutthaya - known as Judea during the VOC period - was the capital of the kingdom of Siam, today's Thailand. Siam was very important to the VOC, and so in 1608 the Company opened a trading post there concentrating primarily on the trade in sappan wood - which was used as dye - as well as tin and animal pelts. The VOC sold most of its pelts to Japan.In 1609 the king of Siam sent a delegation to the Dutch Republic to try and improve relations with the VOC. Although this initial meeting met with little enthusiasm from the Dutch side, the ties between the Company and Siam gradually became stronger. Indeed, in the mid-17th century the VOC even had a shipyard in Ayutthaya where a Dutch shipwright built ships on the European model, with the help of Siamese labour.In 1650 the VOC's ships seized control of the River Menam, on which Ayutthaya is situated. This enabled the Company to force the king of Siam to agree to a treaty. One of the provisions was that the Chinese were no longer to be admitted to Siamese territory; furthermore, the king was required to guarantee the free export of all animal pelts.From 1630 there was an 'opperhoofd' or supervisor resident in Ayutthaya responsible for trade in Siam. This trading post closed and reopened several times before finally closing for good in 1762.

title: Azoren
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Baai van Boina
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Located on the northwest coast of Madagascar, this bay was used to buy slaves by the Dutch in the late seventeenth century.

title: Baai van Caledonië
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. This bay was temporaly colonized by the Scottish Company by the late seventeenth century.

title: Babahan
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Babakan
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Babar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. There was a small VOC fort on the island of Babber east of Timor, which was rarely manned by more than three soldiers.

title: Bacan
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Fort Barneveld on the island of Bacan was captured by the VOC from the Spanish in 1609. From that point on the island's production of cloves could only be sold to the Company. In 1682 the sultan of Bacan sold a number of islands to the VOC for 700 rix-dollars, that is, 1750 guilders. On one of these islands, Obi, the VOC built Fort Den Briel. The sultan also received 80 rix-dollars annually for destroying illegally planted clove trees in his domain.

title: Back Off Bay
variants: Back Off Bay;Bek-af Baij;Back- off Bay
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Badagri
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Pattackerie, een plaats aan de Slavenkust, was het toevluchtsoord van Hendrik Hertog, de WIC-dienaar die in 1732 vanuit het verwoeste Jaquin naar het eiland Appa vertrok en van Appa naar Pattackerie. Tijdens de oorlogen tussen de verschillende vorsten aan de kust en de vorst van Dahomey (vorst van een in het binnenland gelegen rijk van de Slavenkust), maakte Hertog een verkeerde keuze. Hertog koos de kant van de vorst van Dahomey. De inmenging van Hertog in de strijd wekte de woede van een van de vorsten op, die als gevolg daarvan de WIC-post te Jaquin aanviel. De uitwijking van Jaquin naar Appa was maar een tijdelijke oplossing, aangezien Hertog ook voor een aanval op Appa vreesde. Vandaar zijn tweede vlucht naar Pattackerie. Daar aangekomen probeerde hij een fort te laten bouwen. Echter de Heren Negentien, de bewindhebbers van de WIC, besloten tot beëindiging van de investering in de Slavenkust. De slavenhandel nam er drastisch af en Hertog werd in 1738 vermoord.

title: Baghdad
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. During the 17th and 18th centuries the Company maintained regular trading contacts with Baghdad on the Tigris. Around 1676 there was a small VOC base here which remained for some time. Baghdad lay on the caravan route between the Indian Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Bahama's
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Bahrein
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Some time after 1640 the Company decided to rent a house in Bahrein for purchasing pearls. The Dutch VOC employee assigned to the task was Costerus. He was soon captured and his cargo confiscated because he had been taken for a Portuguese, who at that time were enemies of the Arabs. After the misunderstanding had been cleared up, the VOC set up a trade office in the region. However the trade proved unsuccessful. In order to maintain their hold over the pearl trade, the local traders sold their pearls for high prices. The VOC office was closed down again within a relatively short period of time. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Baipar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Baipar was one of the VOC outposts north of Tutucorin.

title: Baleshwar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Balasore, situated on the mouth of the Hougli River in the Bay of Bengal, was a well-known port. It had played host to the first European trading posts. The British established a base there in 1633, the French in 1674 and the Danes in 1676. The British fort was later renamed Fort William in honour of King William III. The VOC also had a trading post and a fort in Balasore. The Dutch established a presence here in 1676 on leaving Pipely. Balasore fell under the aegis of the Directorate of Bengal and functioned as a key link between the VOC trading posts in Bengal and those in Coromandel. Between 1700 and 1789 the settlement played host annually to a surgeon, and sometimes to a bookkeeper.

title: Baliapal
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Company merchants often negotiated the purchase of slaves at Pipeli port. This port city was the first port of call for VOC ships in Bengal. Until 1635 the headquarters of the Company in Bengal was located at Pipeli, but because of the unhealthy climate it was decided to relocate the main base to Houghly. Pipeli remained an import and export centre for this part of Bengal.

title: Balsetoe
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Balsetou was a VOC guard post near to the island of Ambon. It was set up a surveillance station to supervise the clove trade. In this way the activities of the Company's European rivals - its enemies - could be monitored. It was also important to the Company as a way of monitoring the activities of the indigenous inhabitants. The idea was that the cloves grown by the people of Ambon be surrendered to the village chiefs, who in turn would supply the product to the Company.

title: Band-e Kong
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Bandar-e Kong or Congo; The VOC never really had a trading station. However, from 1653 onwards an agent visited almost every year in order to buy pearls. In 1690 the VOC considered establishing a trading station in Congo for the purchase of pearls and gold and silver coins. But due to resistance from the Portuguese, who were intent on defending their interests in Congo, the VOC was forced to pull out of the Congo within that same year.

title: Banda Aceh
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The town of Atjeh was the centre of a large sultanate of the same name extending into the interior of Thailand. In Atjeh itself stood the sultan's palace. The sultans took advantage of the town's natural harbour; whenever foreign ships anchored in the harbour, the sultan put up the price of pepper, Atjeh's most important product. The Company maintained a trading post in Atjeh from 1607 onwards. This post served primarily as a storage depot for pepper and tin. The pepper was grown in northern Sumatra, while the tin came from the mines of Perak, on the west coast of Malaysia, which at that time was part of the sultanate of Atjeh. Atjeh had long been a centre of trade, from which diamonds, gold, pepper and tin were shipped to other countries. During the first decade of the 17th century the Company controlled the pepper trade in Atjeh. The VOC paid for the pepper with fabrics from India, ivory and rice. However, the Company quickly lost control of the pepper trade, because it tried to sell its cotton at a higher price than the Indian traders. Indeed, relations deteriorated to such an extent that the sultan of Atjeh forbade his subjects to sell pepper to the Company. It was only at the end of the 17th century that trade in Atjeh become more profitable, when the sultan granted the pepper monopoly to the VOC. Even before the foundation of the VOC in 1602, Dutch traders had already made contact with the sultan of Atjeh. These initial meetings were far from peaceable. However, once the sultan had begun to tire of the Portuguese presence, his relations with the Company improved. He even sent two envoys to the Dutch Republic in 1602, to find out more about the political state of the Republic. These envoys were the first people from the region to visit Holland. But despite this bold overture, the Company's subsequent agreements with the sultan were not particularly successful; both parties repeatedly breached their contracts.

title: Banda Lontar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Great Banda, also called Lonthor after the main village, is the biggest of the Banda Islands. On this island the Bandanese produced most of the nutmeg and mace. In 1621, Great Banda was violently conquered by Governor General Jan Pieterszoon Coen. The most numerous casualties were those Bandanese who had fled to the mountains and died there of hunger and hardship. An unknown number of Bandanese left the island by boat to settle elsewhere in the region. Around 800 Bandanese were deported to Batavia. 44 orangkaja's (chiefs) suspected of plotting Coen's assassination were arrested, interrogated on the rack, sentenced to death and executed. After the conquest the Bandanese nutmeg gardens were annexed, parceled up and allotted to freeburghers. The parcels are called 'perken', their owners 'perkeniers.' The owners were required to sell their nutmeg and mace to the VOC. Labour on the 'perken' was mostly done by slaves. The perkenier system persisted until 1873.

title: Bandanaira
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC had a trading post on the island of Banda-Neira from 1599. In 1609, Fort Nassau was constructed on the location of an earlier fortification. The construction of the fort and the murder of admiral Pieter Willemsz Verhoeff by Bandanese triggered a war between the VOC and Banda-Neira that same year. The VOC won, after which the Bandanese had to cede the island. In 1612, another fort, named Belgica, was erected on a hilltop behind fort Nassau, in order to protect it from a possible Bandanese landside attack. Fort Nassau was the seat of the 'gouvernement' Banda, which would come to consist of the Banda Islands, the Southeastern Islands and the Southwestern Islands. Banda-Neira and the other Banda Islands, were (virtually) the only place in the world where nutmeg trees grew. Between 1609 and 1621 the VOC conquered all of Banda, including the nutmeg gardens belonging to the Bandanese. In this way the VOC obtained a monopoly on nutmeg and mace. From 1621 onwards, the annexed gardens were parceled up by the VOC and allotted to freeburgers. The parcels were called 'perken', their owners 'perkeniers'. Most of the work in these 'perken' was done by slaves. The 'perkeniers' were required to sell their produce to the VOC. The 'perkenier' system was only abolished in 1873.

title: Bandar-e Abbas
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC set up an office in Gamron, known today as Bandar Abbas, in 1623. It functioned as the head office of the Persian section. The VOC were based here from 1623 to 1659. Thereafter an overseer remained to keep an eye on the trading post for the Company until 1765. In Gamron the VOC purchased wool and attar of roses; and above all silk. Besides spices and cotton fabrics, the VOC also sold porcelain, opium and Japanese lacquer work. The shahs of Persia granted the Company trading concessions in the 17th century in exchange for military support and the opportunity to sell silk to the British as well as to the Dutch. Gamron had a relatively small garrison comprising around 20 European employees and 20 Persian staff. A new VOC lodge was built in the late 17th century, after the original building was severely damaged by earthquakes. Gamron was a highly profitable base for the VOC in the 17th century. But after the Persian kingdom fell to the Afghans in the early 18th century trade came to a standstill. In 1766 the VOC was forced to abandon its efforts in the Persian Gulf in the face of British competition.

title: Bandremoele
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Bandung
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Banggai
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Bangai island, situated on the east side of Sulawesi, was a small island which records show was served by two VOC employees in the year 1705. It appears that the VOC did not stay long on Bangai, for by the 18th century the place is no longer mentioned in the Company's land muster-rolls.

title: Bangka, eiland
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Bangkok
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. On their way up and down the river, merchant ships headed for Ayutthaya had to pass Bangkok, on the River Menam. The castle there served as a tollhouse, where ships passing through had to report where they came from, how many people they had on board and what firearms and merchandise they were carrying. In the 17th century the VOC built a warehouse a few kilometres downstream.

title: Banjarmasin
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The kingdom of Banjarmasin on the Barito River in southern Kalimantan was reputedly founded by Empu Jamatka in 1387. The capital lies on the island Tatas. The kingdom became an important source of diamonds, bezoar stones, and dragon's blood (a plant extract) but was dependent on Java for the supply of rice and was tributary to the Javanese states of Majapahit, Demak, and Mataram, respectively. Its ruler converted to Islam around 1520, and the sultanate received many refugees from the north coast of Java after the fall of Surabaya to Mataram in 1625. In the 17th century pepper, gambier (used for chewing betel), gold, and rattan became major trading commodities, attracting Chinese traders as well as the Dutch and English East India Companies. Both the Dutch and the British attempted to enforce monopolies in the port, but the various agreements with sultans were unenforceable as economic and political power was concentrated in the hands of powerful pepper planters. The Dutch were forced to leave in 1669. The British closed their trading post in 1707. On request of the sultan the VOC sent ships to Banjarmassin again from 1726 onwards. Both parties signed a treaty in 1733, in which the Company got the monopoly on the pepper trade and the obligation to protect the sultan against his enemies. The monopoly was often eluded by smugglers. In 1747 Governor General Gustav Willem van Imhoff ordered a blockade of the harbor for all non-Dutch ships. Two years later the VOC opened a trade post on Tatas. In 1756 the sultan asked the support of the VOC against the Bugis. In the treaty between Sultan Banjermassin and Johan Andreas Paravinci of October 1756, the VOC got permission to build a stone fort to protect her own and the sultans interest: Fort Tatas.

title: Banjoewangie (West-Java)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The land muster-rolls of 1730 refer to Banjawangang as a VOC post falling under the administrative authority of Batavia. It is unclear to which town reference is being made here. It seems unlikely that the reference concerns the place of the same name in eastern Java (known today as Banyuwangi) given that both place names occur in the land muster-rolls of the same year.

title: Bantaeng
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. According to contemporary accounts, Bonthain was an area on Sulawesi's south coast, flanked by the Tino River to the west, the Bonthain mountain to the north and the Kalekongang River to the south. Bonthain traditionally allied itself with Macassar and was ruled by kings. The area was surrounded by rich rice paddies. Thanks to its situation on a big bay, Bonthain was highly suited as a mooring for vessels belonging to neighbouring peoples. VOC records indicate that the populations of Bonthain, Boele and Bera were extremely peaceable in their relations with the Company. The Company appointed a resident to manage the outpost. During the 18th century the outpost grew steadily in size. By 1790 at least 193 VOC employees were stationed in Bonthain and Boelecomba, which lay in a more easterly direction.

title: Banten
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Around 1600 Bantam was Java's most important port. It was the first port of call for Dutch vessels in the Indonesian archipelago. The king of Bantam did not enjoy absolute power but was forced to take into account the wishes of his regent and those of the harbour master. Bantam was a wealthy town with an important market that attracted traders from India, Persia and China. However, the town was forced to relinquish its leading position some years later, when Batavia became the VOC's economic centre in Asia. In the early 17th century Bantam was recognised as the principal trading centre of the Indonesian archipelago. Goods of every kind from all over Asia could be found here. For the VOC, spices - particularly pepper - were the most important commodity. The Company tried in vain to establish a key position through its base here; the English opposed them, as did the local regent who feared the VOC would eventually dominate the market. The conflicts increased, and the Company decided to move on to neighbouring Jacatra, which was later to become Batavia. The Dutch first arrived in Bantam in 1596, at a time when the Portuguese had already built up a strong market position some years previously. The Portuguese had no intention of relinquishing their hold on the town to the Dutch newcomers. The Company's relations with the local rulers of the town were strained, as they opposed the VOC's attempts to dominate the market. Throughout the 17th century new conflicts kept plaguing relations between the VOC and Bantam, from which the Company emerged as the victor each time. In 1756 Bantam finally fell under the Company's control.

title: Banyuwangi
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Between 57 and 83 men were deployed at the VOC post at Banjoewangie on Java's eastern point during the 18th century.

title: Barahanagar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Bernagore lay on the east bank of the Hougly river, some 18 miles south of Chinsura. As was the case in Chinsura and Mirzapore, Bernagore had been leased to the VOC by the Mogul and the Company paid rent for the lands annually. The larger vessels that were unable to reach Hougli because of the shallow waters roundabout anchored in Bernagore or in Falta.

title: Barbara Strand
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Tolcksburg Battery at the St. Barbara Bay, also known as the Spaanse water (Spanish water), was completed in 1636. The battery was part of the larger defensive system of the island. The low battery made of coral and clay mortar, housed a small garrison. The battery fell into disuse shortly after it was built.

title: Barbudo
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Barcadera
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Barus
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Until 1663, the small settlement of Baros fell under the authority of the sultan of Atjeh. The VOC received permission to set up a trading post here in exchange for assistance during the revolt against the sultan. With its numerous rivers, Baros was well situated for the transhipment of products from the interior. These products included camphor and a mixture of resin and fat known as 'harpuis' which was smeared on ships' hulls against marine growths and ship-worm.

title: Batavia (Suriname)
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Batavia was een van de Surinaamse posten aan het Cordonpad. Deze posten werden tussen 1776 en 1778 opgericht om de omliggende plantages te beschermen tegen aanvallen van de Marrons of Bosnegers, gevluchte slaven. De post Batavia lag aan de Coppename rivier.

title: Bato Tulis
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Batoe Oelo
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. According to the land muster-rolls, 15 soldiers were billeted at the fort of Batoeoelo, or Batoe Oelo in the year 1775. The town is situated in West Java.

title: Batticaloa
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Batticaloa, the main town on the eastern coast, was one of Joris van Spilbergen's first ports of call in Ceylon, in 1602. When the VOC began driving out the Portuguese in 1638, Batticaloa was once again first to be conquered. The lagoon behind the fort served as a natural harbour. The fort was later rebuilt. The area around Batecalo, now known as Batticaloa, was rich in a wide variety of trading goods: cotton and raw textiles, rice, honey, elephants, timber, wax, areca (a stimulant), and cinnamon. For many years the VOC blockaded the port of Batticaloa for local traders, and only lifted the blockade after peace had been made with the king of Kandy. The fort was used to combat cinnamon smuggling. Although the VOC tried to establish a monopoly in cinnamon, these efforts were not always successful. In 1638, the VOC and the king of Kandy forged an alliance to capture Batticaloa from the Portuguese. The king ordered the torture and execution of those Ceylonese who had sided with the Portuguese. After capturing the fort, the VOC transferred control to the king, who demolished it. Later, when relations with the king deteriorated badly, the Company blockaded the harbour of Batticaloa.

title: Baubau
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1613 the VOC, represented by Apollonius Scotte, signed its first contract with Bouton. The Company subsequently succeeded in strengthening its power in Bouton by driving out its main competitors Goa, in 1660, and Ternate, in 1667. Relations between the local rulers of the Bouton district and the VOC were generally good.

title: Bawean
parent_name: Bawean Island; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. land muster-rolls for the year 1785, indicate the existence of a VOC post referred to as Bavian: 'op 't Eijlandt Lubok te Bavian'. The land muster-rolls of 1790 refer to the place as 'Baviaan'. It is likely that these references pertain to the island of Bawean, which lay to the north of Madura, East Java. The island, which was also known as 'Liibok' during the VOC era, was not large but was densely populated. It numbered 70 to 80 vessels that plied the waters en route to Java and Borneo.

title: Bekasi
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Bacassie was an outpost of Batavia, situated on the Bekasi River. The VOC built a redoubt here in order to protect the city against enemy attack.

title: Bellepatnam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Benguela
variants: Benguela;Benguela;Sao Felipe de Benguela;S. Felipe de Benguela;Ben Galla
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In 1641 veroverde Cornelis Jol de plaats Benguela aan de kust van het huidige Angola. Hij nam niet alleen deze plaats in, maar veroverde tijdens dezelfde expeditie ook de stad Loanda (São Paolo de Loanda was het grootste Portugese slavendepot aan de Afrikaanse kust) en de eilanden São Thomé en Annobon op de Portugezen. Op dat moment had de WIC het grootste handelsimperium van haar gehele bestaan.

title: Benin City
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Bentota
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Bentota was a small VOC settlement situated at the mouth of the Bentota River, on Ceylon's western coast. The Bentota River acted as a natural boundary between two administrative regions of the VOC: the command post at Galle and the Colombo dessavonij. In Bentotta and nearby Ambalangoda there were several limekilns where coral was processed into lime, subsequently used as a raw material in the manufacture of bricks.

title: Bequia
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Bequia was under French control in the 18th century and during the Seven Years' War with England, the island was used by the fleets of their Spanish and Dutch allies to take on supplies, while British ships were banned. The Treaty of Paris (1763) produced a significant re-alignment in the map of the Caribbean; St. Vincent and the Grenadine islands, including Grenada, were given to the British in exchange for Guadeloupe, Martinique and St. Lucia. The name Petit Martiniquecomes from this era, as does Petit Saint Vincent. In 1779 the French seized the island, despite the Treaty of Paris, but were forced to relinquish control to Britain again soon after. The early 18th century saw the development of a sugar industry and the production of related products including molasses and rum. Other major produce included coffee, indigo and arrowroot. At one point in time, the islands of St. Vincent and the Grenadines were the single largest producer of arrowroot starch in the world. Currently, Hairoun and Vincy strong rum are major export products primarily to the European Union. Under a programme instituted by Great Britain to give land to indigent settlers James Hamilton, father of Alexander Hamilton, moved from St. Croix to Bequia in 1774 where he remained until 1790. The land granted to Hamilton lies along the shore of Southeast Bay. Despite his son's frequent gifts of money and entreaties to immigrate or at least visit him, neither visited the other

title: Berbice
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. - After Essequibo (1616), Berbice constituted the oldest permanent Dutch settlement of the Wild Coast and, because of the divergence of its history and ownership relationships, came to occupy a somewhat special position. - The colony was set up in 1627 under the patronage of the Zeeland merchant Abraham van Pere, whose heirs remained the sole patent holders until 1712. - The Berbice Society, which wielded power from 1720, liberalised economic access to the colony in 1733, opening it up for free trade and freely allocating land to entrepreneurs who were deemed fit. - In the three decades that followed, Berbice became an important plantation colony. - This was disrupted by the major slave rebellion of 1763. The huge stock market crisis in the Republic ten years later, however, was even more detrimental to the Society and would saddle it with permanent financial problems. Even then, however, the colony continued to grow at a steady pace. - In 1795, like all the remaining West Indian colonies, Berbice fell under the auspices of the Dutch Committee for the Affairs of the Colonies and Possessions on the Guinean Coast and in America, following the establishment of the Batavian Republic and the disbanding of the Society.

title: Berg en Dal
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. In the early 18th century, this area was fruitlessly searched for gold under the leadership of self-proclaimed mining expert Salomon Sanders. The land would subsequently be cultivated.

title: Bergen
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Bergen was een van de Nederlandse stadjes in de omgeving van Nieuw-Amsterdam. Op 1 november 1663 roept Peter Stuyvesant, directeur-generaal van Nieuw-Nederland van 1655 tot 1664, de afgevaardigden van diverse Nederlandse en Engelse steden, zoals Bergen, op om naar de 'Gemeene Landts Vergaderinghe' te komen. De spanningen tussen de Engelsen en de Nederlanders in het gebied liepen op. De Engelsen gaven geen gehoor aan Stuyvesants oproep. Een jaar later, in 1664, werd het gebied aan hen overgedragen.

title: Betaal
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Pas Betaal was a crossing point or ferry near to Colombo, opposite present-day Wattala. Both Matuaal and Retaal are variously referred to as a pass or ferry in the VOC land muster-rolls. It is not known where exactly the pass was situated. On the map of Colombo of the Bodel Nijenhuis collection, inv.nr. 33. COLLBN 002-11-065, both passes are mentioned (see P and Q).

title: Beyin
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Bhadrackh
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Bhaij Fals
variants: Bhaij Fals;Bhaijfals;Baai Fals;Valsbaai;C. Falço;Kaap Vals;Cabo Falço
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC's land muster-rolls refer to a separate post by the name of False Bay, but it is unclear which place is meant here. In any case the station in question is not 'Achter de Steenbergen aan de Baai Fals', given that both posts are recorded in the land muster-rolls of the same year, each having a separate garrison. False Bay is a larg bay lying south east of Table Bay and west of the Leeuwenberg. The chief outposts on the bay were Muisenberg, Vishoek and Simon's Bay.

title: Bharuch
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Broothsia, now known as Bharuch, was almost exclusively geared to the manufacture of cotton in the 17th century. The town was famous in particular for its finely woven white fabric, called 'Bafta Brootscha'. Trade was mostly in the hands of Hindus who sold successfully to the English, Portuguese and merchants from the Arab world. The VOC regularly operated a trading post in Bharuch, which came under the jurisdiction of Surat.

title: Bijapur
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Bima
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The Portuguese stayed on in Bima, situated on the eastern side of the island of Soembawa, for some time after the VOC established a presence there. From Bima the Company exported sappan wood to Batavia. This wood was used in the manufacture of paint and medicines.

title: Bimlipatam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Bimlipatnam was ringed by large tracts of land given over to rice fields. These were the principal source of rice for Ceylon. Here, as elsewhere on the Coromandel Coast, the VOC was faced with local rulers who controlled the rice trade. The Company closed its office temporarily in protest at the high prices. Trade was halted altogether after Mogul invasion of Golconda in 1687.

title: Bintauna
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The land muster-rolls of the VOC frequently refer to the small outpost of Binta Oena, which was generally staffed by two to three VOC employees. Like many of the VOC posts in northern Sulawesi, Binta Oena fell under the aegis of the chief comptoir in Ternate.

title: Black Rock
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Aan het zuidelijke einde van de Grote Koerland Baai, op de zogenaamde Black Rock (Hawk´s Bill), werd er in 1628, tijdens de eerste Nederlandse expeditie op het eiland Tobago, een tweede fort gebouwd, naast het iets oudere en grotere fort Nieuw Vlissingen dat ten noorden was gelegen. Het tweede fort was gering van omvang, slechts bewapend met een paar kannonen. Later in 1654, toen zich een kolonie onder leiding van de Hertog van Koerland hier aan de baai vestigde, herbouwden deze kolonisten (de Koerlanders) het fort dat vanaf dat moment fort Bennet genoemd werd.

title: Bloedfort
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. This fort was planned in 1754, but never built

title: Bloemfontein
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Boano
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Boano was an island in front of the coast of Hoamoal (Western Seram), and stood under control of the <kimelaha>, the ruler of Hoamoal with whom the VOC was periodically in conflict. It produced very little cloves, but still regularly came into conflict with the VOC because of the raids that the inhabitants organised on VOC-controlled areas. During the Great Ambon War (1651-1656), the VOC, making use of military force as well as existing political rivalry in the island, managed to bring it to the side of the VOC.

title: Bogor
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Governor-General Van Imhoff built an estate south of Batavia which he named Buitenzorg. This became the country residence of the ruling Governor-General. It was customary for the departing official to sell the estate to his successor for a fixed sum. In the 19th century one of the world's leading botanical institutions, the famous Bogor Botanical Gardens, was created on this estate.

title: Bom Jesus
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Toen Pernambuco, de rijkste capitania (provincie) van Brazilië, door de Nederlanders veroverd werd, trokken de Portugezen landinwaarts naar het westen, onder leiding van de gouverneur Mathias Albuquerque. Zij vestigden zich in de streek Arraial do Bom Jesus en besloten daar een fort te bouwen, forte do Arraial Velho do Bom Jesus, later bekend als fort Real do Bom Jesus. Arraial was gelegen in de omgeving van de Varzea, het meeste rijke gebied van de hele capitania (provincie) van Pernambuco. Deze locatie werd al snel het centrum van de Portugese guerrilla tegen de Nederlandse nieuwkomers. In 1633 poogden de Nederlanders de nederzetting te veroveren maar de aanval mislukte. Later, in 1635, besloten de Nederlanders om Arraial opnieuw aan te vallen, deze keer met succes. Het fort werd verwoest en nooit meer herbouwd. Na de Nederlandse verovering werd Arraial verlaten.

title: Bommelshoek
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Bommelshoek was one of the many VOC posts for livestock in the eastern Cape. It later became known as 'Welbeloond'. Pieter van Dam, who recorded the history of the Company around 1701, notes that in the year 1693, Welbeloond was manned by two Company employees and one slave. The post numbered a flock of 1,000 sheep.

title: Booi
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC had founded a small outpost in the native village of Booi, on the southern coast of the island of Saparua. Throughout the 18th century the post was never manned by more than a single soldier.

title: Borne
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In Borne, an outpost situated on the left bank of Samanca Bay on the southern coast of the island of Sumatra, the VOC maintained a fort named 'Jonge Petrus Albertus'. There were around 19 VOC employees stationed at the fort around 1765.

title: Borslem Island
variants: Borslem Island;eiland Borsselen;eiland Borselen;eiland Borcelen;Inver Island
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Borselen Island, nowadays Borslem Island, was the Dutch West India Company headquarters for the colony of Guyana, until a new post was built on the east bank of the Demarara, just across from the island.

title: Boshof
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Bottom, The
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Boucquetchina
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In Bukit Cina, a little to the north east of the city of Melaka, the Company established an outpost. The area had a source of clear source of drinkig water. Senior Company officials later built their country houses here.

title: Boyolali
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The tiny settlement of Bojolalie near Carta Soura employed a VOC staff of around 20 throughout the 18th century, the land muster-rolls indicate.

title: Brandwacht
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. The Brandwacht ('Fire Watch', a term generally used in the Dutch colonies at that time to indicate a first-alert post) was originally a lookout post on Mot Creek, built in 1685 to keep an eye on the sailing route along the east coast to the mouth of the Surinam River. In the 18th century, it additionally consisted of a redoubt on the eastern bank of the creek, about three-quarters of a kilometre from the mouth, with a separate picket station on the sea coast.

title: Brebes
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Brebes was a VOC post on the northeastern coast of the island of Java, in the kingdom of Cheribon. Brebes also functioned as a border post between the two VOC offices of Semarang to the east and Cheribon to the west.

title: Brooklyn
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In 1646, 21 jaar na de stichting van Nieuw-Amsterdam op het zuidelijke puntje van het eiland Manhattan, werd het dorp Breuckelen gesticht, genoemd naar het stadje Breukelen in Nederland. Tussen Nieuw-Amsterdam en Breukelen werd een veerdienst ingesteld. Volgens enkele bronnen zou Cornelis Dircksen Hooglandt de eerste veerman zijn geweest. In het gebied dat nu Brooklyn wordt genoemd waren in de 17de eeuw vijf Nederlandse dorpen gevestigd: Breukelen, Nieuw Amersfoort, Nieuw Utrecht, Boswyck en Midwout.

title: Buffeljagsrivier
variants: Buffeljagsrivier;Buffeljagds Rivier;Buffeljagtrivier;Buffeljagts Rievier;Rietvalleij aan 't Buffel Jagtrevier;Rietvalleij aan 't Buffelsjagtsrevier;Rietvalley aen d'Buffeljagts Revier;Rietvallij aan de Buffeljagtsrivier;Rietvallij aan de Buffeljagtsrievier;Rietvalley aan de buffeljagtsrevier;Rietvallij aan de Buffel Jagts Rivier
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. On the Buffeljagsriver, southwest of the Cape, the VOC maintained a cattle post named 'Riet Valleij'. The first recorded mention of this name dates back to 1730. Riet Valleij represented the easternmost outpost of the VOC at the Cape. It was founded as a base for bartering cattle with the Koina tribes. Several kilometres away the VOC also established an administrative office, which functioned to bolster the position of the European colonists who had settled here. The post was sold in the late 18th century. Today the town is known as Rooipoort.

title: Buitenverwachting
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Buitenverwachting country house in the Cape Peninsula, west of the Constantia country estates, bears the date 1685 above its entrance gates. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Bullenbaai
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Bulukumba
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Boela Comba, on Sulawesi's southern coast enjoyed the status of kingdom for many years during the VOC era. The area was thickly forested, but while these forests were good for hunting they produced little useful wood. During the west monsoon it was dangerous to enter the harbour at Boela Comba. The officials in charge of the settlement, the vice merchant and the resident, were housed in the VOC fort Carolina at the mouth of the Kalekongang River, together with the rest of the staff.

title: Bungku
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Metal goods from Tambocco, such as swords and axes, were in great demand in the eastern archipelago. The VOC bought these goods to exchange for other products elsewhere. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Buol
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In Bwool in northern Sulawesi, the VOC appointed a corporal who acted as resident of the post. The Company used Bwool as a source of hardwood, then known as 'ligoa' and 'bastert ijzerhout' ('bastard ironwood').

title: Burhanpur
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Burhanpur lay some 80 miles of Surat, on the coast of the Tapti River in the interior. It was a major trade centre where goods came together from various regions, such as Persia, Bengal, Kashmir, Gujarat and Decan. Consequently the VOC established a trading post here, but it soon ran into difficulties due to competition from the British, who had been trading in the region for some time. The VOC post was subsequently discontinued. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Burlington Island
variants: Burlington Island;Bommelerweert;Schoon Eylandt;Carrs Island;Juniosa Island;Hooge Eiland
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Bij de aankomst van de eerste Nederlanders in Nieuw-Nederland na de stichting van de WIC in 1621, werd als hoofdplaats gedacht aan Hoog Eiland (tegenwoordig Burlington Island) in de Delaware Rivier. Het was de eerste nederzetting van de WIC, met Waalse kolonisten, gesticht in 1624. De plaats fungeerde als handelspost voor de aankoop van bont. Vier jaar na de oprichting van de factorij werd de plaats al weer verlaten. Toen in na de bouw van fort Amdesterdam in 1625 de plaats Nieuw-Amsterdam op Manhattan als hoofdplaats ging dienen van Nieuw-Nederland, werd de post op Hoog Eiland verlaten en vervangen door het zuidelijker gelegen fort Nassau.

title: Buru
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The biggest part of the Moluccan islands of Buru and Ceram fell outside the sphere of influence of the Company. On the island of Buru the Company maintained a fort on the Bay of Kajeli, in the north east of the island. After a series of conflicts between the VOC and the population of Buru the Company built a fort by the name of Mandarsjah in 1658. In 1662 it was replaced by the redoubt of Costburg, renamed Oostburg three years later. This redoubt burned down in 1688 as the result of an explosion and subsequently a new wooden fort named Defensie was built there. This fort was built on a square base with four half bastions, two of which with watchtowers. Buru supplied the VOC with carpentry and firewood.

title: Bushehr
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC maintained a trading post here from November 1737 to October 1753. In 1753 the trading post was abandoned as a consequence of a station being stet up at Khark.

title: Bushwick
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In 1660 vroeg een groep Franse immigranten toestemming aan de Nederlandse directeur-generaal Peter Stuyvesant om een dorp te stichten op het Lange Eiland ofwel long Island. Stuyvesant ging akkoord en wees een plek aan tussen Breukelen en Middleburgh (Maspeth). Het nieuwe dorp met de naam Boswijk groeide snel, in tegenstelling tot een aantal andere nieuwe dorpen op het Lange Eiland. Vanwege oplopende spanningen en conflicten tussen de Engelsen en de Nederlanders, ontmoetten de Boswijkers delegaties van andere dorpen in de wijde omgeving op de 'Gemeene Landts Vergaderinghe' te Nieuw-Amsterdam. De Boswijkers en de andere delegaties verzochten om verduidelijking over de grenzen tussen Engels en Nederlands gebied. De vergadering had geen succes. Een jaar later, in 1664, werd het hele gebied aan de Engelsen overgedragen. Boswijk heette vanaf dat moment Bushwick.

title: Butri
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Fort Batenstein werd in 1656 door de WIC gesticht. Het fort lag op een heuvel gelegen in Butre, een plaatsje dat zich aan de Goudkust tussen de plaatsen Dixcove en Takoradi bevond. Als één van de weinige forten aan de Goudkust was deze vesting gedurende de hele 17de en 18de eeuw in handen van één en dezelfde eigenaar, namelijk de WIC. In 1872 kwam het in handen van de Engelsen. Volgens Bosman, die het fort in 1701 bezocht, was het een slecht ontworpen gebouw met vier nutteloze bastions. Naast goud en timmerhout bracht Butre ook suiker op.

title: Cabajé
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Cabedelo
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Ten noorden van Frederiksstad ofwel Filipea, de hoofdstad van het gewest Siara (Cearà) lag het plaatsje Cabedelo in de monding van de rivier Paraiba. Hier hadden de Portugezen drie forten gebouwd. Deze drie forten, die samen een strategische driehoek vormden, stelden de ingang tot de nederzetting vanaf de zee veilig. Een klein fort lag op het eiland Restingues in het midden van de monding van de rivier, terwijl de andere twee waren geplaatst op de noordelijke en zuidelijke punten van de monding, tegenover elkaar.Het fort S. Antonio lag op de noordpunt, fort Catharina op de zuidpunt. Dit fort werd na 1634, toen het gebied onder Nederlands controle viel, gedeeltelijk herbouwd en door gouverneur Johan Maurits herdoopt fort Margaretha, ter ere van zijn zuster.

title: Cabinda
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Tot 1689, maar misschien ook daarna nog, was er in Cabinda een handelsagent van de WIC aanwezig. Net zoals in de nabij gelegen plaatsen Malemba en Cabinda werden ook hier slaven ingekocht. De Nederlanders hadden zich hier, aan de Angolese kust, sinds 1641 gevestigd na de verovering van de kust op de Portugezen. Na het verlies van de belangrijkste plaats aan deze kust, São Paolo de Loanda, werden ook de meeste andere posten van de WIC in dit gebied verlaten. Na 1648 werd er door de WIC niet meer gevaren op plaatsen die zuidelijker lagen dan Congo.

title: Cabo de Santo Agostinho
variants: Cabo de Santo Agostinho;Cabo Sao Agostinho;Kaap St.Augustijn;Caepo S. Augustijn;Cabo de Santo Agostinho
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Al in 1631 probeerden de Nederlanders de Portugees-Braziliaanse vestiging gelegen aan Cabo de Santo Agostinho te veroveren, echter zonder succes. Na deze mislukte aanval werd er nieuwe poging gewaagd in 1634. Toen lukte het om enige strategische plaatsen rondom Cabo Agostinho, zoals de kaap ook wel werd genoemd, in handen te krijgen. In dat jaar werd fort Puntal of Pontael veroverd, in brand gestoken en herbouwd met de naam Van der Dussen. Waarschijnlijk in hetzelfde jaar bouwde de WIC bij Cabo de Santo Agostinho het fort Domburg ofwel Gijsselingh. Een jaar later, in 1635, namen de Nederlanders het aan de kaap gelegen Fort Nazarè of Nazareth in, waarmee geheel Cabo São Agostinho in Nederlandse handen kwam. Dit betekende een zware slag voor de Portugezen. Cabo São Agostinho was een belangrijke exportpost voor het vervoer van suiker. In de omgeving waren veel engenhos (suikermolens) en de haven was een gunstige plek waar de schepen konden ankeren. Door de Nederlandse bezetting werd de kaap afgesloten van het achterland, wat zeer nadelig bleek te zijn voor het Portugese verzet dat juist met de suikerwinsten gefinancierd werd.

title: Cajamue eiland
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. According to several sources, this island was the location of a Dutch fort called Nassau. Due to the changing course of the river and contradictory cartographic evidence, the location of this island cannot be ascertained. However, on Van Meurs' map of Guyana (Koninklijke Bibliotheek 185 B 14 deel II, na p. 528), the region at the confluence of the Xingu and the Amazon Rivers is called 'Cogemine'.

title: Calamatta
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Calicut
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Calicut was a major transshipment port for a wide range of products, and pepper in particular. It was the first port of call in India for Vasco da Gama when he arrived on the subcontinent in 1498. Here too the Dutch encountered the Zamorin of Calicut - the most powerful Hindu ruler on the Malabar Coast - for the first time. During the time that the VOC enforced its monopoly of the pepper trade Calicut served as a smugglers' haven, with local dealers transporting their pepper via inland waterways.

title: Callao
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The Nassau fleet blocked this port in 1624.

title: Callewette
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Calwette was situated to the east of the city of Cochin. The Company established a shipyard here after the Dutch conquered Cochin.

title: Cambamba
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Between 1641 and 1648, the Dutch had succeeded in taking Luanda (the largest Portuguese slave depot of the African Coast) and the surrounding area from the Portuguese. Subsequently, the Dutch organized expeditions upriver, conquering or founding several settlements along the river Kwanza, including Cambamba. - At the mouth of the Cuanza river, i.e. slightly less than a hundred kilometers west of Cambamba, the Dutch turned an earlier small fortification into a full-fledged fort to defend the river mouth. The fort became known as fort Mols, named after one of the three directors of the area appointed by the West India Company. - The island Ensadeira, where the Dutch met with Dutch resistance, was situated somewhere between the rivermouth and Cambamba; quite probably, it is the island which Blaeu maps of the region call 'Masander'. In his description of Africa, Olfert Dapper mentions the island as being 9 leagues (some 50 kilometers) upriver from the coast, and being some four leagues long and half a league wide, and predominantly producing maniok (cassava).

title: Campong Baro
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Canarische Eilanden
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Cannanore
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Under Rijcklof van Goens, the VOC captured the town and fort of Cannanore from the Portuguese in 1663. Because the Portuguese on the Malabar coast had been severely weakened by that time, they offered little resistance to the Company. Cannanore supplied spices such as pepper and cardamom, a spice used in baking cake. In the 18th century look-out posts were set up around Cannanore to combat pepper smuggling by the natives. The Company eventually lost the town and the fort to the English in 1790.

title: Cape Coast
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Fort Carolusburg aan de Goudkust, gebouwd door de Zweden in 1653. Het Zweedse fort Carolusburg wordt een paar jaar na de oprichting betrokken door de Denen. Volgens overlevering wordt het hoofd van deze nieuwe Deense post door de Nederlanders wijsgemaakt dat Denemarken is veroverd en dat het behoud van de Deense eigendommen aan de kust een zinloze zaak is. En zo verkoopt de goedgelovige man de Deense posten aan de Nederlanders. Later zullen de Denen het fort wel weer in bezit nemen, maar uiteindelijk gaat de vesting over in Engelse handen: in 1664 veroverden de Engelsen, onder leiding van Captain Robert Holmes, het fort. De vestiging is sindsdien niet heroverd, ondanks een aanval van Michiel de Ruyter in 1665, een Franse aanval in 1757 en diverse aanvallen van plaatselijke stammen.

title: Cape Comorin
variants: Cape Comorin;Caab Commerijn;Caab Commorijn;Caab Kommorijn;Caeb Commorijn;Caap Commerijn
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1740 the VOC established a so-called 'comptoir', or station at Cape Comorin, on the southern-most tip of the Indian sub-continent. The village fell under the aegis of the rajah of Tutucorin. It was a fishing village that served as a transhipment port for may VOC goods.

title: Cape Town
variants: Cape Town;Cabo de Goede Hoop;Caap de Goede Hoop;Caap;Cabo de Gude Hoop;Caap de Bonn Esperance;Kaap de Goede Hoop;Kaapstad
parent_name: Peninsula; Cape of Good Hope (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Since the Cape of Good Hope was the point at which the VOC ships passed one another on their outward and homeward journeys, in 1652 a staging and provisioning post was set up there by Jan van Riebeeck. After some years the town began expanding rapidly since ships sailing under different flags also began using the VOC facilities. Farms sprang up around the settlement to support this expansion. Besides VOC employees and large numbers of Asian and African slaves, the population consisted of free entrepreneurs and craftsmen who carried on a flourishing trade with the numerous seafarers. The refreshment station at Table Bay was never intended as a profit-making venture for the VOC. The Cape could only become self-supporting with the aid of a large population of white farmers. Until the late 17th century the European population was confined to the area between Cape Town and the first mountain ranges of the south-western Cape, an area of roughly 70 by 100 kilometres. But after 1720 they began to spread out across the interior. Between 1720 and the end of the 18th century the colony grew to roughly ten times its former size, while the white population increased from 2,000 to 15,000. Cape Town was established by the VOC as a provisioning and staging post. Its purpose was to supply the Company's ships with fresh produce. There was also a hospital. To minimise costs the VOC kept the settlement as small as possible. Farms around the settlement supplied the VOC with meat, dairy and agricultural produce, including wine, at fixed prices. During the 17th century some of the livestock was acquired through barter with the Hottentots (the Khoi-khoi and San tribes). Later, the white colonists took up livestock farming too. As the European population expanded, they drove the Khoi-khoi and San tribes from their lands. These tribes lived by hunting and cattle farming. From around 1775 the eastern colonists clashed with the Xhosa as both sought to lay claim to fertile summer pastures. The Commander in Cape Town was based at the Castle of Good Hope from where he represented the interests of the entire colonised area of southern Africa as well as the island of Mauritius while a settlement existed there between 1638 and 1710. In the 18th century Cape Town was raised to the status of a governor's province until it was captured by the British in 1795.

title: Caracasbaai
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Cariemabaath
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Like Rajamahal and Murshidabad, Carimabad was one of the places in Bengal where coins were minted. For this reason the mint in Bengal was known as 'carimabad' until 1778. The silver used to make the coins was imported direct from the Netherlands once a year.

title: Carita
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Tjerita was a tiny VOC outpost situated on the West Coast of Java. Throughout the 18th century there were usually three VOC employees stationed there.

title: Carresoela
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Cartabo
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. De Essequibo rivier ligt in het noorden van Zuid-Amerika, tegenwoordig Brits Guyana. Al vanaf het begin van de 17de eeuw werd dit gebied door de Nederlanders bevaren. In de loop der tijd ving men aan met de verbouw van suikerriet. Ook werd er handel gedreven in orianeverf, maaraan-olie en diverse houtsoorten. Deze producten werden met de indianen uit het binnenland geruild tegen Europese producten. Aan de westelijke oever van de Essequibo, waar de rivieren Cayouni en Mazarouni samenvloeien, lag een plaats genaamd Cartabo. Rond 1770 waren er ongeveer 12 à 15 huizen in het plaatsje. Cartabo lag tegenover het eiland waarop fort Kyk Overal gesitueerd was, de hoofdplaats van de kolonie. Het dorpje was gelegen aan een particuliere plantage met dezelfde naam, in de omgeving van een grote plantage van de West-Indische Compagnie waar cassave werd verbouwd. In 1716 werd besloten om hier een nieuw commandeurshuis te bouwen dat vanaf dat moment bekend stond als 'Huis Nabij', waarschijnlijk omdat dit huis nabij fort Kijk Overal lag. Tussen 1718 en 1739 werd 'Huis Nabij' te Cartabo het nieuwe bestuurscentrum van deze kolonie.

title: Cassewinica kreek
variants: Cassewinica kreek;Cassewine kreek;Casiwinica kreek;Caswinica kreek;Casawinica kreek
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. The Cassewinica creek is a branch of the Commewijne river and joins its stream from the south.

title: Castela
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Castela, also known by the names Gamlamo or Gammelamme, was a major city on the west coast of the island of Ternate. The first fort was built by the Portuguese in the 16th century. Behind the walls of the fort lay the town, with its churches, schools and houses. In 1575 a local ruler came to power. He was overthrown in 1606 when the Spanish conquered Gamlamo. In subsequent years the city, now known as Nostra Senhora del Rosario, flourished. In 1663 the Spaniards were driven out, the fort destroyed and the town taken over by the Dutch.

title: Castella
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Castello was a small island south of Cochin. The Portuguese built a redoubt here. The coconut plantations at Castello, then known as 'klappertuinen', were leased by the Company to the inhabitants of Cochin. The vessels that passed Castella and attempted the secret transport of pepper, were subject to inspection by the VOC.

title: Castro
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Met de verovering van Brazilië hoopten de Heren XIX, het bestuur van de West-Indische Compagnie, dat er ook andere streken van Zuid-Amerika onder Nederlandse invloed zouden komen. Er werd een expeditie naar Chili georganiseerd zodat de WIC zelf het goud en zilver zou kunnen halen, dat eerder alsmaar in Spaanse handen terechtkwam. De expeditie, onder leiding van Brouwer en Herckmans, vertrok in 1642 vanuit Nederland, via Recife, naar Chili. Het werd nooit een succes. Het lukte de WIC niet om zich er langer dan een paar maanden te vestigen. Het eerste doel van de expeditie was het eiland Chiloe, een strategisch punt van waar uit de Zuid-Amerikaanse kust aangevallen kon worden. Op het eiland bestond een Spaanse nederzetting, Castro en een fort, genaamd Carelmapu. Het fort werd veroverd en het dorp Castro verwoest. Toen Brouwer, een van de hoofden van de expeditie, op het eiland overleed, werd besloten om naar Valdivia te vertrekken, een vestiging aan de Chileense kust ten noorden van Castro en het eiland Chiloé.

title: Caswienica (kreek)
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. By the late eighteenth century the area around this creek was cultivated.

title: Caswinika rivier
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Cayenne
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In Cayenne, de hoofdstad van Frans Guyana, stichtten de Fransen in 1624 de eerste Europese volksplanting (kolonie) aan de rivier Sinamari. In 1626 legden zij ook aan de rivier Conanama een volksplanting aan. Ter bescherming van het gebied werd er een fort gebouwd, fort Ceperou, aan de noordoostelijke punt van de monding van de Cayenne rivier. Rondom het fort ontwikkelde zich, tijdens de Franse tijd, een vestiging die zich spoedig tot de stad Cayenne ontwikkelde, de hoofdplaats van de Franse volksplanting. De conflicten tussen de Fransen en de indianen namen in zulke hevige vorm toe dat de Fransen rond 1653 gedwongen waren de stad te verlaten. Uit verschillende bronnen blijkt dat de eerste Nederlanders al rond 1615 de kust van Cayenne hebben aangedaan. Een groep Nederlanders, bestaande uit ongeveer 280 kolonisten, vestigde zich onder leiding van Theodoor Claessen aan de rivier Cayenne. Hun aanwezigheid duurde niet lang: de kolonisten verhuisden naar de nieuwe kolonie Suriname. In 1627 werd er door Claude Prevost, in opdracht van de WIC-kamer Zeeland, een nieuwe poging tot kolonisatie gewaagd, die niet langer dan vijf jaar zou duren. Twee jaar later, in 1634, zouden enkele kolonisten uit de kolonie Essequibo zich wederom in de omgeving van de rivier Cayenne vestigen, om precies te zijn bij het eiland Mecoria, iets ten noorden van de tegenwoordige stad Cayenne; zij vingen aan met de teelt van tabak. Onder leiding van David Pietersz. de Vries werd een nieuwe expeditie georganiseerd. Deze groep verbleef een jaar in een oud Frans fort, dat zij uitbreidden. De belangrijkste Nederlandse expeditie in het gebied Cayenne vond plaats rond 1657. Jan Claessen Langendijck nam, met ongeveer 40 à 50 kolonisten, zijn intrek in het verlaten Franse fort Ceperou (in 1650 door de Fransen gebouwd) aan de noordoostelijke punt van de monding van de rivier Cayenne. De Fransen hadden in 1653 deze vestiging moeten verlaten door conflicten met de plaatselijke bevolking. De kolonie verwelkomde de joden die uit Brazilië waren gevlucht onder leiding van David Nassy in 1658. De Nederlandse kolonie in Cayenne werd in 1659 aan de WIC-Kamer van Amsterdam overgedragen. Pas in 1664 slaagden de Fransen erin om het fort Ceperou (die zij later fort S. Louis zouden noemen) en de nederzetting Cayenne weer in te nemen. In dezelfde periode dat Langendijck in Cayenne neerstreek, was er onder leiding van David Nassy een joodse kolonie opgebloeid in dit gebied. Ook deze kolonie viel, evenals Cayenne, in Franse handen. Met de Vrede van Breda werd besloten dat Cayenne Frans bezit zou blijven. Toch probeerde Jacob Binckes in 1676 Cayenne opnieuw te overvallen en het belangrijke fort Ceperou, nu St. Louis, te veroveren. Na zeven maanden kwamen de Fransen weer terug en heroverden definitief de vestiging en nederzetting.

title: Cayouni rivier, post aan de
variants: post aan de Cayouni rivier;post aan de Cayuni
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Ceder kreek
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Celam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC built the small fort of Culenborg in the compound at Selamme or Selaman on the northern point of the island of Lonthor. It was built in 1636 on the recommendation of the governor general, Antonie van Diemen. When Van Diemen visited the compound in 1638 he named the fort after the city of his birth. Its situation on top of a hill meant the fort functioned as a key surveillance point. Some three to eight soldiers were generally stationed here.

title: Chankanai
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The VOC regarded the presence of the Ceylonese Catholics, converted by the Portuguese, as a serious threat. By means of an active Protestant mission the Company hoped to counter this threat and create a bond with its new subjects. Religious education formed a cornerstone of this policy. Lessons were given in church halls and the results booked were a source of enormous satisfaction to the Company clergy. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Chapra
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. At the VOC base in Chapra the saltpetre purchased in neighbouring Patna was processed at the Company refinery. The saltpetre was destined for the European market, as it was an essential ingredient in the manufacture of gunpowder. As such the demand for saltpetre mushroomed during wartime. The Company's country estate and gardens at Chapra probably served for the cultivation of vegetables for VOC employees. The reservoir functioned not only as a supply of drinking water, but also provided for the irrigation of the gardens.

title: Charlotte Amelia
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Charlotte Amalie is de hoofdstad van het eiland Saint Thomas dat deel uitmaakt van de Maagdeneilanden (USA). Deze plaats heette in de 18de eeuw Taphoes ofwel 'Negerhollands Taphuus', door de vele kroegen die hier te vinden waren. Hoewel het gebied in feite een Deense kolonie was, hebben zich hier in de loop van de 17de eeuw ook Nederlanders gevestigd, die suiker en tabaksplantages aanlegden.

title: Charlotteville
variants: Charlotteville;Charlotteville;Jan de Moor Bay;Jan de Moors Cuilsacq
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Charlotteville, in het noordoosten van het eiland Tobago is volgens Wiechen de oudste nederzetting op Tobago. Rond 1628 werd er een groep Zeeuwse kolonen door burgermeester van Vlissingen Jan de Moor naar Tobago gezonden met het doel het eiland te koloniseren. Het eiland werd toen New Walcheren herdoopt en het plekje, dat nu Charlotteville heet, diende als verversingplaats. De baai bij de stad Charlotteville is bekend met de naam Jan de Moor Bay, als teken van de aanwezigheid van de Zeeuwse kolonie.

title: Chavakachcheri
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The church at Chavakachcheri was the local centre of the Protestant faith. Local inhabitants were taught in the church hall. As many as 1,000 children attended school in Chavakachcheri, although there were only three teachers. The teachers compensated for the lack of staff by organising the older pupils to teach the younger ones. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Chendamangalam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Cheremgalam was one of the many small military VOC outposts on the Malabar Coast. It was situated at the mouth of the Periyar River, opposite Cranganore. The mouth of the river was reinforced in a bid to combat pepper smuggling.

title: Chilaw
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Silauw was situated on the West Coast of Sri Lanka. The settlement was primarily intended as a barracks, but was also used as a harbour. The Silauw population mainly comprised fishermen who dived for pearls.

title: Chiloè Island
variants: Chiloè Island;Ilha do Chile;isla de Chiloè
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. De verovering van Brazilië had de Heren XIX doen hopen dat er ook andere streken van Zuid-Amerika onder Nederlandse invloed konden worden onderworpen. De West-Indische Compagnie hoopte met de expeditie naar Chili zelf aan het goud en zilver te kunnen komen dat voorheen alsmaar in Spaanse handen was. De expeditie, onder leiding van Brouwer en Herckmans, vertrok in 1642 vanuit Nederland. Via Recife, de hoofdplaats van Nederlands-Brazilië, werd naar Chili gereisd. De expeditie werd geen succes. Het lukte de WIC niet om zich er langer dan een paar maanden te vestigen. Het eerste doel was het eiland Chiloe, een strategisch punt van waaruit de Zuid-Amerikaanse kust aangevallen kon worden. Op het eiland bestond een Spaanse nederzetting, Castro en een fort, genaamd Carelmapu. Het fort werd veroverd en het dorp Castro verwoest. Toen de Nederlander Brouwer op het eiland overleed werd besloten naar Valdivia te vertrekken, een vestiging aan de Chileense kust ten noorden van Castro en het eiland Chiloé.

title: Chinco
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The West coast of Sumatra was an important source of pepper . The VOC opened a trading post but the arrival of the Europeans let to growing tensions with the indigenous population. The company decided in 1667 to move her lodge to the small island Cingkuk or Pulau Tjinkoek before the west coast of Sumatra. It was a very strategic location. The sailing route along the coast passed the island, which at its north coast had a good roadstead where the ships could lay at anchor. Traders in pepper and gold visited the island The lodge, which was built on a rocky hill in the middle of the island, was surrounded by a palisade. In 1679 a stone warehouse was built and a stone wall of five meter high and 0,75 m thick. People could enter the enclosure by two gates: one in the north wall and the other at the south side. Francois Valentijn mentioned that the island devoured people because of the great heat, the insalubrious humidity and the poisonous vapors. Pulau Cingkuk should have become the main office of the VOC on the west coast of Sumatra, but in 1670 the company choose for Padang, which was much healthier than the island. During the Fourth Anglo Dutch War (1780-1784) all the offices of on the West coast of Sumatra surrendered after the arrival of ships of the Est India Company. They were returned to the VOC after the peace in Europe was signed. The same thing happened during the wars between Great Britain and France and its allies (1795-1816) In 1818 the Dutch returned to Pulau Cingkuk and rebuilt the trade buildings, but the island lost most of its importance to Padang. The remains of the buildings are now turned into a historical tourist spot. Strange enough the explanation signs on the island mention wrongly that the ruins are the remains of a Portuguese fort.

title: Chinnecallette Delle
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. This VOC station was situated on the eastern coast of the island, south of Batticaloa. It was attacked by the King of Kandy's armies in 1672. The VOC fort was built on a square base with four bastions.

title: Chittagong
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location (Koninlijke Bibliotheek, inv.nr. 185 A 5 deel V, I, na p. 146) featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Chowghat
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Around 1718 the company gained permission from the rajah of Cochin to build afor in Chowghat. However, his opponent, the rajah of Calicut, claimed the land and took the fort. Some years later William Bakker Jacobszoon recaptured the fort, after which it was known as 'Fort William' or 'Fort Wilhelmus'.

title: Christiansted
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Saint Croix is samen met Saint Thomas een van de Amerikaanse Maagdeneilanden. Op Saint Croix vestigde zich rond 1625 een groep Nederlandse kolonisten. Deze plaats staat tegenwoordig bekend als Christiansted. In 1636 kreeg Jan Snouck van de kamer Zeeland toestemming om een patroonschap in dit gebied te vestigen. Later besloten de kolonisten om dit eiland te verlaten en te verhuizen naar Sint Eustatius.

title: Chunchura
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Tjutjura, now known as Chunchura functioned as the headquarters of the VOC in Bengal. Originally situated in the neighbouring town of Houghly, the base was relocated in 1656. The two names were subsequently used indiscriminately. This base was said to be the most beautiful in Asia. The town was notorious for its corrupt VOC officials whose only aim was to get rich as quickly as possible by trading for their own account - much to the displeasure of the VOC's central administration in Batavia. The fort was known for its size and strength. It bore the name of 'Gustavus' after Gustaaf Willem van Imhoff, who held the post of governor-general from 1743 to 1750. Situated close to the fort was a shipyard and a burial ground. In the 18th century the director ordered a church and a school to be built for the local population. This meant that many of the Company's employees were more involved with their own private trade - to the concern of the VOC's central administration at Batavia. The VOC complex at Houghly and Chinsura expanded rapidly in the late 17th century. There were warehouses for cotton, opium, ginger and hemp. The popular Bengal silk was also stored in Chinsura from where it was shipped to Batavia and Japan. Another Bengali product was sugar, which was sold in Persia at a great profit. In Chinsura the Company operated an unusual agreement with the nawab, the local representative of the Mogul emperor. In effect, the Company rented the city. The local administration was not in the hands of the governor, but of the fiscal, who functioned as a kind of mayor. His task was to protect the Company's property and to administer justice over the local population.
