The VOC's Bengali bases fell under the jurisdiction of the Coromandel governor until 1655, after which Bengal became an independent directorate with its headquarters in Chinsura.

title: Chundikkulam
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The Portuguese, who were driven out of Ceylon in 1658, had built a large number of churches. The church at Chundikkulam is typical of the Portuguese architecture. The Company did not let the churches go to waste. Teachers were taken on and in the same churches which had once echoed to the Catholic mass, religious teachers now taught Protestantism to the local inhabitants. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Cibinong
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Cilincing
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Cipanas
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Cipir/Pulau Kahyangan
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Cuijper was a small island in the Bay of Batavia. It harboured several large warehouses for the storage of goods. The VOC staff that worked here during the day travelled to the nearby island of Onrust to spend the night. At night Cuijper was guarded by just two men.

title: Cirebon
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. During the 18th century the Company cultivated coffee in Cheribon, sending the first shipments to the Dutch Republic in 1713. However, a glut soon developed, so that coffee production was no longer viable. The coffee plantations were destroyed, while pepper cultivation gained a new lease of life.

title: Cisarua
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Clapmuts
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. One of the mountain peaks between Stellenbosch and Paarl was christened Clapmuts in 1657 by the fiscal A. Gabbema. The post was originally established for making hay. The indigenous Koina peoples were given from 1676 to 1680 to move their settlements and livestock elsewhere because the VOC had commandeered the grasslands in order to make hay for its horses. The region surrounding the outpost was rich in meadowlands and numbered many farms. According to an illustration by Thibault the engineer, executed in 1787, there was also a post house. For some considerable time, however, the Clapmuts region remained sparsely populated.

title: Clevia Plantage
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. - This 'excellently productive' coffee plantation was managed by W.A. Steenbergen and W.H. Saffin. halfway the eighteenth century. - On 20 May 1885 the forestry expert Justus Wilhelm Gonggryp was born there. - It is now a neighbourhood of the city of Paramaribo.

title: Cochin
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Portugal's base in Cochin dated from as early as 1503. There the Portuguese built Fort Manuel, the first European fort in India. Around a century and a half later, Cochin was captured by the VOC under the command of Rijcklof van Goens. Cochin subsequently expanded to become the Company's main base on the Malabar coast. The rajah of Cochin granted the Company a monopoly in pepper and cinnamon.A commander was based in Cochin to administer the whole of the Malabar coast on behalf of the VOC. However, the town was too large to enable it to be defended against enemies so it was reduced in size to within the surrounding walls. Many of the original Portuguese buildings were demolished or converted into warehouses. The VOC also built a hospital in Cochin, together with an orphanage and terraced housing for its workers and soldiers.In 1676 the Company acquired the pepper monopoly on the Malabar coast. But even this failed to give it control of all pepper production. However, this did not give it control of all pepper production. Because English merchants paid higher prices for their pepper, local traders preferred to sell to them rather than to the VOC. Corruption within the VOC ranks, as well as pepper smuggling to places outside the VOC's monopoly, caused profits to dwindle away completely in the 18th century.In 1663 Rijcklof van Goens dealt a telling blow to the Portuguese. One of the descendants of the old rajah applied to the VOC for aid against the Portuguese and his overlord, the ruler of Cochin. At first the Company only took Cochin because of its strategic importance - the Portuguese presence in the Malabar region was seen as a threat to the nearby island of Ceylon, which the VOC had recently acquired. From 1661 the Malabar coast was captured from the Portuguese piece by piece. Malabar remained under the jurisdiction of the governor of Ceylon until in 1663 it became an independent section under a commander based in Cochin.In 1795 Cochin fell to the English.

title: Cocos eilanden
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Coculusbaai
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Coermotibo (Kreek)
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The area around this river was partly cultivated by the late 18th century.

title: Coesowinie rivier
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. By the late eighteenth century, Karaboeker Indians lived to the west of this river.

title: Colesberg
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Colombo
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Colombo, capital of Ceylon, was a busy trading and administrative centre during the VOC era. From Colombo the VOC pursued a policy aimed at spreading the Protestant faith among the Ceylonese population. The availability of a printer's in Colombo that published the Christian scriptures in the local language made it easier to bridge the gap with the local population. Nowhere else in Asia was the VOC's involvement in the administration of a region as long lasting and intensive as it was in Ceylon. The Company was a sovereign power on the island. Colombo was severely damaged during its conquest by the Company in 1656 and had to be rebuilt. The new town was divided into a fort and an urban section. The urban part of Colombo became a busy multicultural trading centre, where many Dutch settled permanently as free citizens after retiring from the VOC. Colombo was the central storage depot for cinnamon, Ceylon's most important product. The VOC established an extensive organisation to harvest and transport cinnamon, within which specific tasks were allotted to the various castes in Ceylonese society. The Company also introduced pepper and coffee cultivation to Ceylon. However the cultivation of coffee ended in failure due to poor organisation. The VOC administration in Ceylon was engaged in a continuous war of attrition with the kingdom of Kandy. This friction came to a head on two occasions: first under Governor Rijcklof van Goens, who aimed to make Ceylon the VOC's central power base in Asia - against the wishes of the king, and indeed against those of Batavia. The second was in 1760, when war broke out between Kandy and the Company. The VOC won this war. Every year delegations from both side visited one another. Colombo was the capital of Ceylon, a Company government which also covered part of the southern tip of India until 1663. Ceylon was further divided into two departments or 'commandements', Galle and Jaffna. Each was headed by its own commander, subject to the governor in Colombo. In 1795 Ceylon was captured by the English.

title: Colombo Gammo
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The land muster-rolls of the VOC for the years 1765 and 1775 list Colombo Gamma as a VOC-outpost staffed by a single official. Where the outpost was situated is not known, but the classification of the land muster-rolls indicate it was somewhere in the area around Jaffnapatnam.

title: Comaribo
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Comaribo was the name of a landmark mountain at the mouth of the Wiapoca river (now the Oiapoque, which forms the border of French Guyana and Brazil.) As such it can be found on many 17th century maps of the region. It is now known as Montagne d'Argent.

title: Cometawana kreek
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Commer
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Commer was one of the districts on the island of Lonthor, situated on the island's western side. It had a watering hole where later the small fort of Watervlied was built.

title: Commewijne Rivier
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. The second main river for the Surinamese plantation economy.

title: Compagnie Bay
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Concordia baai
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Concordia, post
variants: post Concordia;post bij plantage Stevenburg;Concordia post aan de Canje rivier
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Conjemere
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Conjemere, also known as Kunimedu, lay 13 miles north of Pondicherry. Little is known of this place other than that the Dutch attempted to take over the trading post from the British.

title: Constantia
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Constantia was one of the VOC's country estates in the Cape and was known for its gardens, vineyards and orchards. Simon van der Stel, who became governor of the Cape in 1691, had a country house here. After his death in 1712 the highly fertile Constantia was subdivided into Groot Constantia and Klein Constantia. The wine produced here was said to be the finest the Cape had to offer. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Coppename rivier
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The Coppename river begins in the Wilhelmina Mountains, and joins with the Saramacca just before it debouches into the Atlantic. Although the river was explored and charted in the 18th century, cultivation of the area only started by the very end of that century.

title: Corantijne Rivier
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The surroundings of this river was not yet cultivated by the end of the Eighteenth Century.

title: Corisco, Island
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Corisco is a small island off the coast of Gabon and Equatorial Guinea. C 1680, the WIC had a trading post trading in slaves there. As the post was loss-giving, it was soon abandoned again.

title: Coronie
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Corre Corre baai
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Cossimbazar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Kazimbazar was the site of one of the VOC's principal bases in the Bengal region. This was where the opperkoopman or senior merchant was posted. Silver rupees, the Mogul coinage, were minted here. In addition, Kazimbazar was an important centre for the purchase and manufacture of raw silk, mainly destined for the Japanese market. This base had its own silk factory, run by special silk controllers.

title: Cottica (rivier)
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. This river originates in the hills surrounding the town of Moengo and flows westwards where it eventually enters the Commewijne River.

title: Covelong
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Crabbebaai
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Cranganur
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Cranganore was the first place on the Malabar coast captured by the VOC from the Portuguese. The Dutch aimed to use the town as a base from which to attack and capture other bases in the region. The fleet with which the VOC attacked the Malabar coast consisted of 18 ships manned by 1050 soldiers. Because of the shortage of European soldiers, the Company seconded a garrison from Ambon for the assault.

title: Cuddalore
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Tengapatnam, also known as Cuddalore, was situated on the souther Coromandel Coast, about 70 miles north of Nagapatnam. The town should not be confused with the place of the same name on the south Indian coast near Trivandrum. In 1608 the Dutch were granted permission to use an old fort as a place of trade. Because of the fort's impractibility the town was abandoned in favour of Thiruppapuliyur further south. Later the VOC was to build a lodge in Tengapatnam where the chief resided along with other VOC employees. The lodge was situated in the centre of the village, surrounded by a wall with four bastions. Tengapatnam was a key location for the purchase of 'lijnwaten' but also functioned as a leisure destination for the merchants. In 1647 the Company was granted permission to build a fort there manned by 60 people.

title: Cuijlen de
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1676 the outpost of De Kuylen was a well-known resting-place for expeditions into the interior. In January of the year 1680 governor Simon van der Stel decided to build a simple house there which would serve to accommodate travellers during their journey from the Cape to Hottentots-Holland. Pieter van Dam, who recorded the history of the Company around 1701, notes that in the year 1693 De Kuylen was manned by nine Company employees and two slave boys.

title: Daljosaphat
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Daman
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Damar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1652 the VOC settlement on the island of Dammer was attacked by people from the neighbouring island. Nine Company employees, including a native of Maccassar, were murdered. A year earlier the VOC had forced the Damme population to destroy more than 14,000 nutmeg trees on the nearby island of Nila, in a move aimed at preventing competing traders from buying the nutmeg and driving up the price. The attack led the Dutch to establish a post elsewhere, on the nearby island of Babar. Later the outpost on Dammer, known as Wilhelmus, was restored.

title: Damar-Besar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Edam was one of the small islands in the Bay of Batavia, not far from the islands of Cuijper, Purmerendt and Onrust. The governor-general had a country house built there. In addition there was a carpenter's yard and a cemetery.

title: Dasseneiland
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Dassen Island lies in Saldanha Bay, above Robben Island. It was situated roughly 100 kilometres north of the Cape colony and was used as a staging post for passing VOC ships. In particular, large numbers of seals were caught there. At the end of the 17th century a military post was set up on the island.

title: De Hoop
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Delft
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Delft island
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The land muster-rolls of the year 1765 make mention of an island called Delft. The island boasted a tiny settlement manned by a trio of soldiers. The island fell under the administrative control of Jaffnapatnam.

title: Demak
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC was able to obtain large quantities of rice in Demak, which it needed to provision Batavia, Ceylon and the Molucca Islands. A common practice used by the Company to keep prices down was to blockade rivers after the rice harvest. Other traders would only be able to export rice from Demak after the VOC had bought sufficient rice at the lowest price.

title: Demerara, rivier
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. This river had a central role in the plantation economy in present-day Guyana. The WIC settled on the island of Borselen and along the river banks in the eighteenth century.

title: Dender
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The small fort of Dannex, or Morgenster (Morning Star) guarded the Dender nutmeg plantation on the northern coast of the island of Lonthor. It was built in 1626 on the recommendation of Governor Willem J. Admiraal. All the small forts built on Lonthor around this time had a weak construction. The hardwood beams soon went rotten, as a result of which the forts soon collapsed. The fortifications were intended to help keep the rebellious plantation slaves under control.

title: Devil's Harwar
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Dhaka
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Decca, the contemporary Bangladeshi capital of Dhaka, was situated on the eastern mouth of the Ganges River. Until 1704 Decca was the seat of the Nawab of Bengal, Sjah Estachan. From 1664 the Nawab functioned as the viceroy of Bengal. He sent an emissary to the administration of the Company in Batavia requesting aid in his battle against the Arrakan. Both the Dutch and the English established a presence in Decca because, along with Malda in the north of the Ganges delta, the town constituted the centre of the textile district. The settlement comprised several wattle houses with mud roots. According to the traveller and writer Tavernier, who visited the area around 1665, Decca boasted an attractive house that was built by the Dutch and which was used for storing goods.

title: Diu
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Dixcove
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Dodinga
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Dodingo, now known as Dodinga, lay to the right of the island of Ternate on the Halmahera coast. According to Pieter van Dam, who recorded the history of the VOC in 1701, Dodingo was badly suited to agriculture. Here a neighbouring tribe known as the Alfoer had once built a small fort in a bid to prevent skirmishes between the Company and the Tidorese. Later, in 1713, under Governor David van Peterson, Dodinga was occupied by the VOC in a move to prevent disputes over Ternate and Tidore. The occupation meant the Company was able effectively to protect the bay of Dodinga, in which the islands of Ternate and Tidore lay.

title: Drakenstein
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Drakenstein, the name of which derives from the visit paid to the region by Baron van Rheede tot Drakenstein in 1685, was founded in that same year. Between 1685 and 1690 many French Huguenots settled here. For this reason most of the farms in the district carry French names such as La Motte, Bien Donné and Rhone. It was a prosperous district where agriculture was the most important activity. The area's principal products were grain, fruit and wine.

title: Draksharam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Daatcheron was situated a little way to the north east of Masulipatnam. For a long time the Company maintained a lodge here which mainly bought textiles. The trading post was abandoned in 1686.

title: Dwars in de weg
variants: Dwars in de weg;Dwars in de wegh;Dwaers in de weg;Dwaars in de weg
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. One of the islands in Kottiyar Bay (the bay of Trinconomale) was referred to by the Dutch as 'Dwaers in de weg' ('Bang in the way'). The tiny island with its battery was situated opposite the fort of Oostenburg in Trinconomale. Dwaers in de weg was also known as 'Isle du soleil' or 'island in the sun'. It gained this name from the French when they arrived in the harbour in 1762 and attempted to establish a settlement there.

title: Edappalli
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Edappalli, also known as Ellengallur and Repolom, was a tiny kingdom. This kingdom owned lands scattered along the entire Malabar Coast. While it was not an important trade location, it was unique thanks to the free and easy character of the city, where one could easily seek refuge in the temples and pagodas. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Edatouritti
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Elephant Pass
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. During the 17th century the Company was engaged in a war of attrition with the king of Kandy, who had close ties with Ceylon's Buddhist population. There was a narrow tongue of land at Elephant Pass a fort was built to guard the border with the king's territory. Elephants captured on Ceylon were herded past here to Jaffna to be sold in India, hence the name Elephant Pass.

title: Elmina
variants: Elmina;Elmina;Mina;S. George del Mina;La Mina;St. George d'Elmina
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Al in 1482 vestigden de Portugezen zich in São Jorge da Mina, ofwel Elmina aan de Goudkust. Tien jaar daarvoor waren immers de rijke goudlanden ontdekt. De naam Elmina betekent letterlijk: 'de mijn'. De Portugese handel werd zo omvangrijk, dat de plaatselijke handelaren hulp nodig hadden bij het transport van de goederen naar het binnenland, zoals bij het transport van lakens, linnen en koper. Om aan deze vraag te voldoen zetten de Portugezen in het begin van de 16de eeuw een handelsnetwerk van slaven op. Toen de goudmarkt instortte doordat het goud uit Mexico goedkoper werd, verslapte de Portugese macht aan de Goudkust zodanig dat Nederlandse aanvallen niet langer meer afgeweerd konden worden. Vanaf 1637 wordt Elmina het hoofdkwartier van de Nederlanders aan de Goudkust. Dat blijft zo tot 1872-1873 als de Nederlanders het gebied verlaten. Tijdens de Nederlandse aanwezigheid groeide Elmina uit tot 15.000 in de 18de eeuw. Vooral de handel in goud en slaven was voor de WIC van grote betekenis. De omvang van het fort Elmina geeft duidelijk aan hoe belangrijk deze handelspost -dé doorvoerhaven van slaven naar de nieuwe wereld- aan de Goudkust was. Volgens Barbot, die het fort in 1682 bezocht, kende dit fort geen gelijkwaardige variant aan de Goudkust.Het WIC-bestuur in Elmina bemerkte dat een goede verstandshouding met de Ashanti de handel vergemakkelijkte. De Ashanti bestonden uit diverse stammen uit het achterland van de Goudkust. Zij hadden zich op het einde van de 17de eeuw verenigd. Tot aan het einde van de Nederlandse aanwezigheid op de Goudkust in 1872, was het proberen de banden met de Ashanti in stand te houden een belangrijk doel van de Nederlanders.Na de verovering van Elmina op de Portugezen bouwden de Nederlanders een tweede fort, genaamd Coenraadsburg ofwel St. Jago. Deze vestiging werd neergezet op de heuvel tegenover fort Elmina, waar eerder een kerkje van de Portugezen stond. De Portugese kerk werd omgebouwd tot een veilinghal.

title: Elsjes Coraal
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Elsjes Coraal, later also known as Elsieskraal, was established as a VOC post around 1688. It boasted a pen for as many as 4,000 sheep. Pieter van Dam, who recorded the history of the Company around 1701, notes that in the year 1693 Elsieskraal employed just two men and had 765 head of livestock.

title: Eluthumadduval
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Particularly in northern Ceylon many of the local population had been converted to Catholicism by the Portugeuse. As the principal European power in the region after 1658 the VOC saw it as imperative that Protestantism be promoted in its place to gain the loyalty of its new subjects. To this end it opened schools for the provision of religious education. The school at Eluthumadduval numbered around 650 pupils. Here the Company also had stables for elephants which were sold to supply the armies of the Indian princes. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Enkhuizen
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Epe
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. According to Postma, the WIC had a trading post in Epe or Appa. According to Den Heijer, this place was named Appa by the Dutchman Hendrik Hartog. Hartog had worked in another place with the same name, but further west (Epe or Appa 1 in this database), but had to flee from there in 1738 due to wars between the local rulers. Appa 1 and the WIC fort there was destroyed by the enemies of the king of Dahomey, whose side Hartog had chosen in the conflict. Hartog then moved operations to Appa 2, some 120 kilometres east of Pattackerie.

title: Epira
variants: Epira;post Ephraim;Post Ephraim;Buitenpost van de Corentyn
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Ephraim was een buitenpost gelegen aan de linkeroever van de Corantijnrivier. Deze post lag tegenover de post Aurearis, en diende om het gebied tussen Berbice en Suriname te scheiden en de verbindingen tussen de twee regio´s te beschermen.

title: Erang
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Erang was a settlement on Hoamoal (Western Seram), a clove-producing region ruled by the <kimelaha>, the leader of Hoamoal with whom the VOC was periodically in conflict. The inhabitants of Erang and the surrounding villages had a reputation of selling their cloves to traders from Makassar and Java, which was in violation with the treaties with the VOC. For this reason, VOC troops attacked Erang in 1633, destroying the settlement and the surrounding clove plantations. In 1652, during the Great Ambon War (1651-1656), the settlement was attacked and destroyed again. At the end of the war, the entire peninsula was depopulated, and the people living there forced to relocate.

title: Erkelenchene
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Erkelenchene was situated on the eastern coast of the island of Ceylon, south of Trinconomale. The VOC built a small fort here.

title: Esfahan
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Ispahan, now known as Esfahan, was the capital of the kingdom of Persia. Ispahan lay on the caravan route between Central Asia and the Persian Gulf. The VOC's trade in Persia depended on its political relations with the shah, who held court here. The VOC bought silk from the shah in exchange for spices and military protection. The VOC were based here from 1623 to 1746, although after 1741 manufacturing activities were very low key. In trade Isfahan barely had a role to play after 1670. The trading station served principally as a means of maintaining relations with the royal court. The VOC was obliged to maintain its office in Ispahan due to the endless negotiations with the shah about trading concessions. The shah gave the VOC the use of this splendid house with adjoining gardens for as long as the Company continued to trade in Persia. In 1722 Ispahan was conquered by the Afghans. Trading came to a halt and in 1747 the VOC base was closed. The head office of the VOC's Persian directorate was located in Esfahan from 1623 to 1638.

title: Essaouira
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Essequibo
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. This was a Dutch colony on the Essequibo River in the Guiana region on the north coast of South America from 1616 to 1814. The colony formed a part of the colonies that are known under the collective name of Dutch Guiana.

title: Factorij J. van Roubergen
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. J. van Roubergen, een Zeeuwse handelaar uit Vlissingen, stond aan het hoofd van een particuliere handelspost aan de Loango-Angola kust. De handelspost werd de factorij J. van Roubergen genoemd. Van Roubergen arriveerde rond de jaren vijftig en zestig van de 17de eeuw aan deze kust en dreef er handel. Hij staat ook wel bekend als een lorrendraaier ofwel smokkelaar. Het is niet geheel duidelijk waar de factorij gelegen was. De plaats kan aan de kust van Angola, Gabon of Congo gelegen hebben.

title: Ferdonando d'Noronho eiland
variants: Ferdonando d'Noronho eiland;Ferdonando de Noronha eiland
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The Lisbon merchant Fernão de Loronha held not only Fernando de Noronha island as a hereditary captaincy but also (from 1503 to around 1512) a commercial monopoly on trade in Brazil. Between 1503 and 1512, Noronha's agents set up a string of warehouses (feitorias) along the Brazilian coast, and engaged in trade with the indigenous peoples in Brazil for brazilwood, a native red dye wood highly valued by European clothmakers. Fernando de Noronha island was the central collection point of this network. Brazilwood, continuously harvested by the coastal Indians and delivered to the various coastal warehouses, was shipped to the central warehouse on Fernando de Noronha island, which was intermittently visited by a larger transport ship that would carry the collected loads back to Europe. After the expiration of Loronha's commercial charter in 1512, the organization of the brazilwood enterprise was taken over by the Portuguese crown, but Loronha and his descendents retained private ownership of Fernando de Noronha island itself as a hereditary captaincy, at least down to the 1560s.

title: Fernando de Noronha
variants: Fernando de Noronha;Noronha;Fernao de Noronha;Fernando de Noronha
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Ten oosten van de Braziliaanse kust, ongeveer op de hoogte van de stad Fortaleza, ligt de archipel Fernando de Noronha. Deze kleine eilanden werden door de WIC in 1630 in bezit genomen. In datzelfde jaar bouwden de Nederlanders een fort in het noorden van het grootste eiland. Waarschijnlijk stond het fort op een heuvel aan de baai van Santo Antonio, de belangrijkste ankerplaats van deze eilanden waar later de Portugezen dit fort hebben herbouwd. Het fort, bekend met de Portugese naam Forte de (Nossa Senhora de) Remedios, was in 1654, het jaar van de Nederlandse capitulatie, de laatste versterking die door de Nederlanders in Brazilië werd verlaten. Het gebouw diende ook als hospitaal voor gewonde soldaten, een functie die ook later door de Portugezen werd behouden. De eilanden Fernando de Noronha bleken al snel van weinig belang te zijn omdat ze weinig opleverden. Bovendien werden de eilanden geteisterd door ratten die het verbouwen van allerlei gewassen onmogelijk maakten. De WIC plaatste Gillis Venant (met een paar slaven en 23.000 gulden) op het eiland en gaf hem de opdracht mee het gewas indigo, dat uit het oosten kwam, te gaan verbouwen. Dit bleek geen succes. Er wordt in een document van de WIC (in een brief van 26 maart 1634 van Willem Joostensz. Glimmer. Nr. 50 folio 56, zie 'Oude WIC-archief' in het Nationaal Archief, Den Haag) gesproken over fort Ceeburgh dat zou liggen op een van de eilanden Fernando de Noronha.

title: Flag Island
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Flatbush
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Midwout was een van de plaatsjes waar de eerste Nederlanders zich vestigden na de oprichting van het naburig gelegen Nieuw-Amsterdam. Tegenwoordig zou het dorp gelegen hebben in de wijk Brooklyn, oftewel Breukelen.

title: Flatlands
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In 1639 kocht een handvol inwoners van Nieuw-Amsterdam vruchtbare stukken land in de westpunt van het Lange Eiland ofwel Long Island. Hieruit kwam het dorp Nieuw-Amersfoort voort. Elf jaar later kreeg het eerder gestichte dorp Nieuw-Amersfoort stadsrechten. Toen Nieuw-Amersfoort overging in Engelse handen, kreeg het de naam Flatlands.

title: Flushing
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Tijdens de Nederlandse bewindsperiode op Manhattan ging het bestuur akkoord met de vestiging van een religieuze groep Engelsen in het dorpje Vlissingen. Het dorp viel onder Nederlands gezag en was gelegen aan de noodwestzijde van het Lange Eiland (Long Island). Onder deze Engelsen bevond zich een groep Quakers. Zij oefenden hun geloof publiekelijk uit. Dit was in strijd met wat het WIC-bestuur in Nieuw-Nederland als 'staatsreligie' had afgekondigd: het Gereformeerde geloof. Deze afkondiging was op haar beurt in tegenspraak met de reglementen van de Unie van Utrecht, namelijk dat iedere burger zijn eigen geloof mag uitoefenen. De Engelse activist John Bowne wist dit en besprak de zaak in Nederland, waar het WIC-bestuur hem gelijk gaf.

title: Fombetokke
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Fort Bay
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Fortaleza
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In 1637 the Portuguese-owned region of Cearà or Siara, situated to the north of Pernambuco, was conquered by the Dutch West-India Company (WIC) without much resistance. Indigenous tribes had requested Dutch help in their fight against the Portuguese in the region, who grew sugar cane there. For the WIC, the area proved to be more attractive for winning salt than for growing sugar cane. When the Dutch conquered the region in 1637, the Portuguese fort Siara had been there for quite a few years. The Dutch abandoned Siara by the end of 1643. An epidemic of smallpox and the forced labour led the indigenous population to revolt against the Dutch. The Dutch population in Siara was entirely wiped out. In April 1649, Siara was retaken by the WIC. A new fort was erected, named Fort Schoonenburgh. The WIC's main interest there was in the silver mines in the vicinity. Siara was subsequently ceded to Portugal as part of the Dutch surrender of their Brazilian territories in 1654.

title: Franschhoek
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Franschhoek became home to around 200 French Huguenots who had initially fled to the Netherlands after the revocation of the edict of Nantes in 1685. Via the VOC they landed at the Cape, where the Dutch wished to found a colony. The French gained free passage to the Cape, provided they first swore allegiance to the Company. In the Huguenot district, as the area around Franschhoek was known, the French built farms and established vineyards. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Freedland
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. De Engelsman Thomas Pell stichtte in 1654 het dorp Westchester, nu in het meest zuidelijke deel van The Bronx. De Engelsen bezetten steeds meer land dat de Nederlanders eerder van de Indianen hadden gekocht. Rond 1656 vormde dit steeds meer een probleem voor Peter Stuyvesant, de toenmalige gouverneur van Nieuw-Nederland. Om die reden nam Stuyvesant Westchester in en herdoopte de plaats in Vreedland, land van Vrede. Later werd het dorp Oostdorp genoemd aangezien het ten oosten lag van het Nederlandse handelscentrum Nieuw-Amsterdam.

title: Fuik Baai
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Fuzhou
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. After the VOC was driven out of Taiwan in 1662, it tried to gain access to the porcelain and silk trade at the port of Fuzhou, which was then also known as Hocksiew. However, the Company's attempts to trade there were hampered by a string of bureaucratic restrictions. As early as 1655 a Dutch delegation had visited the Imperial court in Peking (Beijing), but had had little opportunity to discuss trading conditions. A visit of this kind was regarded solely as a token of the respect to which the emperor was entitled. In 1666 a second delegation was sent to Peking Beijing. It was led by the ambassador Pieter van Hoorn. But aside from some dazzling descriptions of China, this journey also yielded nothing. Although the trading post at Fuzhou barely made a profit, the VOC kept it on until 1681.

title: Galela
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Galela was a major centre in northern Halmamera. The lake and bay on which Galela is situated carry the same name. Galela was known for providing the best quality sap from the sago tree, for its coconut palms and for its bay rich in fish.

title: Galle
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. From 1640 onwards, the VOC maintained a presence in Galle, the main port in southern Ceylon. Ships needed a pilot to reach the harbour here because the entrance to the bay was full of treacherous rocks. The VOC extended and strengthened the fort at Galle, which the Portuguese had abandoned. Every year on December 25 the great homeward-bound fleet set sail from Galle laden with merchandise for the Dutch Republic. These ships met the VOC fleet from Batavia at the Cape of Good Hope from whence they embarked on the Atlantic crossing together. Galle was one of the big transhipment ports where Asian products were collected and shipped out to the Dutch Republic. In 1771 the cargo of one ship bound for Holland comprised pepper, coffee, cardamom, sappan wood, myrrh, catechu (a remedy), and cinnamon from Ceylon. It also carried pepper, coffee, textiles, cowrie shells, saltpetre and figs from other regions. The cowrie shells were used as currency in the slave trade in Africa. Rice was imported into Galle. The Company forged an alliance with the king of Kandy to drive the Portuguese out of Ceylon. But once the Portuguese hold was broken the Company and the king became adversaries. As the Sinhalese monarch, the king continued to have great influence over the VOC's new subjects. Relations improved after 1687 when the new king of Kandy recognised the Company's sovereignty over Ceylon in addition to its trading interests. From 1640 onwards Galle functioned as the VOC's administrative centre on Ceylon, until Colombo was captured from the Portuguese in 1656. Galle subsequently became one of the two departments, or 'commandements', into which the government of Ceylon was divided, falling under the jurisdiction of the governor in Colombo.

title: Galoe
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Galoe, a small post that fell under the aegis of the VOC headquarters at Cirebon in 1765, employed only a single VOC official that year. The exact location of the place is unclear; however the area surrounding today's Pangandaran on the south coast of Java was known at the time as Galoeh.

title: Gansche Craal
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. This outpost was situated some 50 kilometres north of the Cape of Good Hope. The outpost comprised a housing complex, a stable for the horses and livestock and a warehouse. Beyond the complex were extensive gardens with a fountain. In 1791 the outpost, together with its 24 slaves and 280 livestock, was sold to two Dutch brothers.

title: Gelderland
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Georgetown
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Geser
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Until 1660 the inhabitants of Geser resisted the presence of the Company, which forbade them to sell their mace, nutmeg and cloves to other traders. The Company built a small fort at Geser, which was later abandoned when peace was finally signed. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Gibraltar
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In 1501, Gibraltar passed back to the Spanish Crown, and Isabella I of Castile issued a Royal Warrant granting Gibraltar the coat of arms that it still uses today. In 1704, during the War of the Spanish Succession, a combined Anglo-Dutch fleet, representing the Grand Alliance, captured the town of Gibraltar on behalf of the Archduke Charles of Austria in his campaign to become King of Spain. The occupation of the town by Alliance forces caused the exodus of the population to the surrounding area of the Campo de Gibraltar. As the Alliance's campaign faltered, the 1713 Treaty of Utrecht was negotiated and ceded control of Gibraltar to Britain to secure Britain's withdrawal from the war. Unsuccessful attempts by Spanish monarchs to regain Gibraltar were made with the siege of 1727 and again with the Great Siege of Gibraltar (1779 to 1783), during the American War of Independence.

title: Gintota
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Like Bentota, Ambalangoda and many other small settlements, Gintota was a VOC guard post between Gale and Colombo. A group of Laskars, local soldiers in the service of the Company, was responsible for guarding the station and its immediate environs. In addition they served to carry all the news from Colombo to the next guard post.

title: Girie
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Gitaislam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. This town was spelled in a variety of ways: Thoccho, Tocheho, Toseho, Tosseho or Tossehoe. It was situated on the Halmahera mainland, across the water from the island of Makian. The region produced sago, a daily staple for the majority of the population in the Moluccas.

title: Gloucester City
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Het eerste Nederlandse postje aan de Delaware Rivier, gesticht in 1624, was gelegen op Hoog Eiland, nu Burlington Island. Deze rivier werd door de Nederlanders de Zuid Rivier genoemd, aangezien de rivier de 'hoofdweg' van het zuidelijke gebied van Nieuw-Nederland vormde. Daartegenover stond de Hudson Rivier die de Noord Rivier werd genoemd. Toen na de bouw van fort Amsterdam in 1625 de plaats Nieuw-Amsterdam op Manhattan als hoofdplaats ging dienen van Nieuw-Nederland, werd de post op Hoog Eiland verlaten en vervangen door het zuidelijker gelegen fort Nassau. Dit fort Nassau zou ook in 1626 gebouwd zijn. Hier kochten de Nederlanders bont van de Lenni Lenape indianen uit de regio. Rond 1651 besloot Peter Stuyvesant, directeur-generaal van Nieuw-Nederland, fort Nassau te verlaten.

title: Goa (India)
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Goa (Sulawesi)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The land muster-rolls of the year 1740 mention the city of Goa, where 17 VOC employees were stationed. The reference probably pertains to the residence of the king of Goa, who in the mid-17th century ruled over the sultanate of Macassar, under whose aegis the city of Macassar fell. According to Stavorinus, a contemporary writer, the king of Goa was a peaceful ruler, allowing Malays to settle in the region and practice their religion. This tolerance of other peoples resulted in competition, which hampered the Company's trade relations. For this reason the VOC exploited the disputes that arose between Goa and the neighbouring king of Bone, which fell under the sultanate of Goa. The Company engineered an accord with Bone its battle for the city of Macassar, which was taken by Speelman in 1667.

title: Goed Begin, Logie
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Goenaville
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Goenaville was one of the places along the Kelani River where the VOC built minor forts. It was a small fort, not strongly built, and manned by VOC troops of Dutch and Ceylonese origin.

title: Goeree Island
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Het eilandje Goeree werd door koning Biram in 1617 aan de Nederlanders geschonken. Gelegen in de beschutting van de baai van Cabo Verde, bleek Goeree een prima plaats voor de Nederlanders om er een factorij en twee forten, Nassau en Orange, op te richten. In 1663 verliest de WIC het eiland voor een korte periode aan de Engelsen. In 1677 valt het in handen van de Fransen. Daarmee verviel voor de Nederlanders de handel in dit gebied, die hier toch al niet van groot belang was voor de WIC.

title: Gogodon
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Golepallem
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Gollepallem was a village where the VOC maintained its own warehouse, leased from the local ruler. Here the woven cloth produced in the surrounding villages was bleached. For this reason Pieter van Dam, whose history of the VOC was published in 1701, referred to Gollepallem as a laundry village.

title: Golkonda
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. After some initial difficulties, the VOC established friendly ties with Golconda towards the end of the 17th century. This is evidenced by the fact that one Christmas Eve the king of Golconda visited the Dutch church in Masulipatnum. The relationship came to an abrupt end with the Mogul invasion of 1687. Golconda was occupied and the king was taken prisoner.

title: Gonçalo Álvares eiland
variants: Gonçalo Álvares eiland;Gough eiland;Diego Alvarez eiland
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The details of the discovery of Gough Island are unclear, but the most likely occasion is July 1505 by the Portuguese explorer Gonçalo Álvares. Maps during the next three centuries named the island after him. On some later maps, this was erroneously given as Diego Alvarez. According to some historians, the English merchant Anthony de la Roché was the first to land on the island, in the austral autumn of 1675. Charles Gough rediscovered the island on 3 March 1732, thinking it was Gonçalo Álvares, although he found it to be 400 miles further to the east of where it was mapped. This turned out to be correct, and since then, the name 'Gough's Island' became prevalent. In the intervening years, the island was also sighted by several VOC vessels, including the Oranje in 1656.

title: Goram
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Groups of islands east of the far eastern end of Seram.

title: Gorontalo
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1678 the Sultan of Ternate relinquished his claims over Gorontalo to the VOC. In 1681 the governor of the Moluccas, Robertus Padtbrugge, brought Gorontalo under the direct control of the Company, The Company didn't want to be involved in the unstable territory too much, and the main reason the remained in the area was to keep it free of spice trees and European rivals, to control the busy indigenous shipping and to offer protection against pirates. Their merchants bought rice and sold Indian textiles. The interest of the company dramatically increased after the discovery of gold in the mountains of Gorontalo in 1720. During the 1770s, however, it became clear to the VOC that its policy of sea patrols, small forts and diplomacy weren't enough to control the gold trade. The local rulers used the protection of the VOC to enrich themselves by selling the gold to Indonesian traders.

title: Gouverneurseiland
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. The island the Native Americans called “Pagganck” (“nut trees”) is one of the locations where colonists under the jurisdiction of the Dutch West India Company first settled in 1623/1624. Little first-hand information is available about the activities of the colonists,

title: Graaff Reinet
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The town of Graaff Reinet was founded around the turn of the 18th century, under the leadership of Governor De Graaff. It was his modern ideas that led to Graaff Reinet and Stellenbosch becoming the centre of a civilian uprising against the authority of the Company and the local population. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Grand Popo
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Gravesend
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Lady Deborah Moody was de eerste vrouw die een vestiging stichtte in Nieuw-Nederland. Zij hing het anababtistische geloof aan, dat in Engeland zoveel problemen veroorzaakte dat zij hoopte in 'de nieuwe wereld' beter zou kunnen slagen. Ze vertrok naar Massachusetts Bay in 1639, maar zag dat de godsdienstvrijheden daar net zo gering waren als in haar moederland. Een uitnodiging van de Nederlandse gouverneur Willem Kieft om een kleine kolonie te stichten op het Lange Eiland, ofwel Long Island, kwam dan ook goed uit. De inwoners zouden vrij zijn hun eigen geloof te belijden. Het dorp viel onder Nederlands bestuur.

title: Grenada
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. In 1649 a French expedition of 203 men from Martinique led by Jacques du Parquet founded a permanent settlement on Grenada. Within months this led to conflict with the local islanders which lasted until 1654 when the island was completely subjugated by the French.[11] The indigenous islanders who survived either left for neighbouring islands or retreated to remoter parts of Grenada where they were marginalised—the last distinct communities disappeared during the 1700s. Warfare continued during the 1600s between the French on Grenada and the Caribs of present-day Dominica and St. Vincent and the Grenadines. The French named their new colony La Grenade, and the economy was initially based on sugar cane and indigo. The French established a capital known as Fort Royal (later St. George). To shelter from hurricanes the French navy would often take refuge in the capital's natural harbour, as no nearby French islands had a natural harbour to compare with that of Fort Royal. The British captured Grenada during the Seven Years' War in 1762.

title: Gresik
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Grissee was an important port and storage depot for food, pepper and textiles. The Dutch had difficulty in establishing a firm foothold here because they did not have the particular textiles the Javanese wanted; nor could they compete with the low prices of the Portuguese. The trading post was closed down when the Company found that it could not prevent its competitors from exporting.

title: Groene Cloof
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The outpost at Groene Cloof was established in a bid to repel attacks by the Hottentot peoples. The region, which had originally been inhabited by the Cochoqua tribe of herdsmen, was extremely rich in natural vegetation and was known for its broad valley. Over the 10 years from 1673 to 1683 the VOC succeeded in driving the Cochoqua from the region through a combination of war, annexation and taxes. Groene Cloof was used to step up livestock numbers and to help provide food supplies for the Cape of Good Hope. The post comprised a walled complex with a post house, a warehouse, a shop and livery stables. It was surrounded by extensive gardens with a fountain. When the post was abandoned in 1790, it was inhabited by nine European colonists and 21 slaves.

title: Groningen
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Groningen was een van de posten van het Cordonpad, dat tussen 1776 en 1778 werd opgericht. Het was in wezen een stelsel van militairen posten die van het beginpunt aan de Suriname rivier (post Gelderland bij de Joodse Savanne) naar de rivier Commewijne en vandaar langs de Cottica kreek tot aan de zee liep. Dit postenstelsel werd geïnitieerd met als doel het weglopen van vele slaven uit de plantages te voorkomen, maar ook om de plantages te beschermen tegen aanvallen van gevluchte slaven, die onder leiding van Boni in opstand waren gekomen. Boni was een weggelopen slaaf die in de 18de eeuw een opstand organiseerde in Suriname, bekend als de Boni oorlogen. Deze vonden plaats tussen 1765 en 1793 en vormden een groot probleem voor het WIC-bestuur in het welvarende Suriname. De post Groningen lag aan de Saramacca rivier en werd in 1790 opgericht tijdens het bewind van Jan Gerhard Wickers.

title: Groote Schuur
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. At Groote Schuur, 15 kilometres east of the Fort of Good Hope, Van Riebeeck built a grain store. The place was also known as 'de Schuur'. Groote Schuur was also used as a place of worship around 1663. In 1666 the place offered work to 25 colonists and a large number of slaves, both male and female. The grain store had originally been built with the aim of providing grain for the settlement in Cape Town and the VOC ships that put in there on their way to the east. Later it became a trading post for wood, among other things. The trading post was closed down in 1788.

title: Grote Berg
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. A fort was planned here in 1751 but never constructed.

title: Guadeloupe
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. First colonized by French settlers in 1635, Guadeloupe remained a French colony for most of the early modern period, although it was occupied by the English for some time during the Seven Years War and during the French Revolutionary Wars.

title: Gulegule
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The kings of Goeli-Goeli and Geser joined forces to fight against the Company. Goeli-Goeli served as a focus for people who had fled the iron rule of the Company. Although at first the population appeared to be implacable, in 1661 these villages nevertheless signed a peace agreement with the VOC. The Company had earlier been granted permission to build a fort at this end of Seram; the fort was named 'Oosteinde', or 'East End'.

title: Gunung Api
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The small island of Gunung Api is situated near the larger island of Neira. Gunung Api means 'Fire mountain' or volcano. After this volcano erupted in 1691, the supply of nutmeg and mace on Gunung Api, as well as on the neighbouring islands of Neira and Lonthor, declined drastically. This resulted in a substantial rise in the price of these spices, which were exclusive to Banda.

title: Hakmana
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Hakmana lay north east of Mature on a tributary of the Tangale River. It was a small VOC outpost intended as a support base for the small fort at Katuwana in the interior. Together with the fort at Akurressa, Hakmana was founded to improve and safeguard the link between the coast and the border town of Katuwana.

title: Hambantota
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The Hambantota station was situated in southern Ceylon, east of Tangale. It was the final VOC station in the south of the island. In the 19th century the British erected a tower on the remains of a Dutch fort from 1765. Hambantota operated chiefly as an entrepot, and was of strategic importance in guarding the salt pans and access to the cinnamon plantations. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Hammenhiel
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Fort Hammenhiel was situated on a small island halfway along the only water route to Jaffna. It represented an important part of the Jaffna defences. Because it had no supply of fresh water in times of siege the Portuguese were forced to surrender to the VOC in 1658 after the Company cut supply lines.

title: Hanoi
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In the 17th century the northern part of what is now Vietnam belonged to the kingdom of Tonkin. The country was a major silk producer. The silk which the VOC bought there was particularly valuable for trade with Japan. Towards the end of the 1630s, the Company signed an agreement with the king of Tonkin and opened a trading post in or near today's Hanoi. The VOC maintained a trading post in Tonkin from 1636 to 1699. This trading post was run by an 'opperhoofd' or supervisor.

title: Hardenbroek, post bij plantage
variants: post bij plantage Hardenbroek;post aan de Wikkie Kreek;post aan de Wikky Creek
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Harlem
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Haarlem was de oude naam van de huidige wijk Harlem op het New Yorkse eiland Manhattan. Het was de tweede vestiging van de WIC op Manhattan. In 1658 besloot het WIC-bestuur te Nieuw-Amsterdam, op de zuidpunt van Manhattan, dat er een tweede plaats gesticht moest worden op de noordpunt van het eiland: Haarlem. Deze nieuwe plaats zou de Nederlanders moeten helpen het eiland te verdedigen tegen invallen aan de noordzijde door Engelsen en Indianen. De Indianen noemden het gebied Muscoota, dat 'vlak land, geschikt voor landbouw' betekent.

title: Hartford
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In 1633 besloot Wouter van Twiller, gouverneur van Nieuw-Nederland, om Jacob van Curler op expeditie te sturen naar de Verse Rivier, tegenwoordig de Connecticut River. De Nederlanders handelden daarvoor al met de Indianen van dit gebied, maar omdat de Engelsen zich mengden in de handel besloot Van Twiller haast te maken met het stichten van een post. Hij was geïnstrueerd om direct een handelspost op te richten met de naam Huis ter Hope. Daarnaast moest hij het versterken met twee kanonnen. Ondanks de bouw van deze post vestigden de Engelsen zich in de buurt. Huis ter Hope bleef slechts een buitenpost waardoor de Nederlanders hun zeggenschap in het gebied kwijtraakten.

title: Haruku
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Fort Zeelandia was situated on the island of Haruku, also known as Oma. Together with the islands of Nusalaut and Saparua, Haruku fell within the district, or 'gouvernement', of Ambon. The governor of Ambon was the head of the Christian and Islamic national law courts, on which the local rulers also sat. All except four of the villages on Haruku had been converted to Christianity by the Portuguese.

title: Hatoena
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Hatoenoeko
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1600, two years before the VOC was founded, the Dutch built the fort of Verre here in order to oppose the Portuguese who controlled trade in the area. The fort, named after the Compagnie van Verre, was built with the aid of the local population. They called the fort Kota Warwijck, after the first Dutch seafarer to have set foot on Ambon. The fort was soon abandoned. However, the VOC's land muster-rolls of the 18th century indicate that Hatoenoekoe remained occupied by the Company, although no more than two or three people were ever stationed there.

title: Hatuwa
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC maintained a small fort by the name of Hoorn in the village of Hatoea on the island of Oma. Today, the name of the village in this area is Pelauw.

title: Havana
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Hempstead
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In 1643 vestigde zich een groep van dertig tot veertig Engelse families in het plaatsje Hempstead, ofwel Heemstede. Zij kregen toestemming hiertoe van de toenmalige Nederlandse gouverneur van het gebied, Willem Kieft. Het dorp had zijn eigen rechtspraak en zijn eigen kerk, maar viel onder Nederlands bewind. De dorpsbewoners zwoeren trouw aan het Nederlandse bestuur en verplichtten zich tot een groei van 100 families in 1649.

title: Hijili
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Hila
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The first Dutch fort on the island of Ambon, called 'Kasteel van Verre', was built close to Hila, in the village of Hatoenoekoe. The inhabitants of Hila helped the Dutch to build the fort, which was completed in 1600. They hoped that the Company would be able to offer resistance to the aggressive trading activities of the Portuguese. Later in the 17th century, the Company built 'Fort Amsterdam' in Hila.

title: Hinetelle
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. - Henatelu was an indigenous village on the north coast of Western Seram, or Hoamoal. Officially, the population of this region was indirectly ruled by the Sultan of Ternate and therefore allied to the VOC. In practice, the relationship between its inhabitants and the VOC was complicated and fractious, as this clove-producing region did not like the VOC's attempts to controle the clove trade. The entire region was ultimately depopulated in the Great Ambon War (1651-1656) and the village ceased to exist. - The indicated location is approximate.

title: Hirado
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1609 the VOC was granted a trading permit from the Shogun of Japan giving the Company access to Japanese ports and waters. The VOC was also permitted to set up a base on the small Japanese island of Hirado, known as Firando by Europeans at that time. Each year the head of the trading post there was required to pay his respects to the Shogun in Edo, today's Tokyo. Because the Shoguns were keenly interested in Dutch cannon, an iron foundry was built on Firando. From 1609 to 1641 Firando served as an important port and storage depot for trade in Chinese territorial waters. The main trading product was Chinese silk, which was exchanged for precious metals in Japan. At the end of the 1630s free trade in Japan came to an end. In 1641 the VOC was required to move its base to the small island of Deshima in the bay of Nagasaki, where it was subject to stringent rules and surveillance imposed by the Japanese government.

title: Hispaniola
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. - Christopher Columbus landed on the island during his first voyage across the Atlantic in 1492, but in subsequent years, as Spain's attention shifted to the mainland. In the 17th century, pirates and privateers of various nationalities had bases on the island. In 1665, French colonization of the island was officially recognized by King Louis XIV and the the French colony was given the name Saint-Domingue. In the 1697 Treaty of Ryswick, Spain formally ceded the western third of the island to France. Saint-Domingue quickly came to overshadow the east in both wealth and population. Nicknamed the 'Pearl of the Antilles,' it became the richest and most prosperous colony in the West Indies. - During the French Revolution, Spain ceded the eastern two-thirds of the island of Hispaniola, later to become the Dominican Republic. The French side, meanwhile, revolted against Spanish rule and became the independent state of Haiti.

title: Hitu-lama
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The king of Hitoe, the northern part of the island of Ambon, held court at Hiettolama. The Company did no business with this king, but dealt instead with Captain Hitoe, who wielded the real power. At first Captain Hitoe was an implacable enemy of the Company, but later negotiation became possible; the VOC could have the clove monopoly provided they did not attempt to convert the population to Christianity. Contrary to the agreement, Captain Hitoe traded with the Ternate islanders, who were Muslims like himself. Religious differences played an important role in trade on Ambon and the Company was continuously plagued by difficulties in compelling the rebellious Muslim villages to sell their cloves exclusively to the VOC.

title: Hog Island
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Hoi An
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Honkoop
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Hoognodig
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Hoop op Constantia
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Hoop op Constantia was a wine farm not far from Groot Constantia. The farm was assigned to Pieter de Meijer in 1716. The farm of Klein Constantia was situated close by. The two farms are never recorded separately in documents, but are referred to as a single entity. The entrance to Hoop op Constantia bears the date 1685. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Hoorn
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Hormoz
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. With the aid of the English, the duke of shiraz drove the Portuguese out of their fortress on the island of Hormuz in 1622. Bandar Abbas subsequently took over as the principal staple market in the Gulf. The VOC debated at various intervals whether to occupy Hormuz in order to protect its shipping in the Gulf, but finally decided not to do so. Meanwhile, the Company continued to trade regularly with and at Hormuz. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Hottentots-Holland
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Hottentots-Holland lay to the east of False Bay, a 15-hour journey from the Cape. There were two kraals, or villages, in Hottentots-Holland, numbering 500 to 600 men each. Pieter van Dam, who recorded the history of the VOC around 1701, notes that in the year 1693 the Company employed nine people there as well as 11 slave boys, 10 slave girls and an unspecified number of children.

title: Hougly
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Tjutjura, now known as Chunchura functioned as the headquarters of the VOC in Bengal. Originally situated in the neighbouring town of Houghly, the base was relocated in 1656. The two names were subsequently used indiscriminately. This base was said to be the most beautiful in Asia. The town was notorious for its corrupt VOC officials whose only aim was to get rich as quickly as possible by trading for their own account - much to the displeasure of the VOC's central administration in Batavia. The fort was known for its size and strength. It bore the name of 'Gustavus' after Gustaaf Willem van Imhoff, who held the post of governor-general from 1743 to 1750. Situated close to the fort was a shipyard and a burial ground. In the 18th century the director ordered a church and a school to be built for the local population. This meant that many of the Company's employees were more involved with their own private trade - to the concern of the VOC's central administration at Batavia. The VOC complex at Houghly and Chinsura expanded rapidly in the late 17th century. There were warehouses for cotton, opium, ginger and hemp. The popular Bengal silk was also stored in Chinsura from where it was shipped to Batavia and Japan. Another Bengali product was sugar, which was sold in Persia at a great profit. In Chinsura the Company operated an unusual agreement with the nawab, the local representative of the Mogul emperor. In effect, the Company rented the city. The local administration was not in the hands of the governor, but of the fiscal, who functioned as a kind of mayor. His task was to protect the Company's property and to administer justice over the local population. The VOC's Bengali bases fell under the jurisdiction of the Coromandel governor until 1655, after which Bengal became an independent directorate with its headquarters in Chinsura.

title: Houtbay
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Houttuin
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Huangpu
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Whampoa, an island situated in the Zhujiang river, served as the harbour of Canton. A Dutch warehouse was built here, on leased ground. All European vessels bound for Canton were required to anchor at Whampoa.

title: Hughesburg
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Hulong
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Hulong was a settlement in the interior of Hoamoal (Western Seram), a clove-producing region ruled by the <kimelaha>, the leader of Hoamoal with whom the VOC was periodically in conflict. At the end of the Great Ambon War (1651-1656), the entire peninsula was depopulated, and the people living there forced to relocate.

title: Hultsdorf
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The settlement is named after a general Hulft who lived and worked in this village just outside Colombo in 1656 during his period of service in Ceylon. During this period Hullfsdorp functioned as the headquarters of the dessave of Colombo. The dessave was the most senior official in the so-called 'dessavonij', the administrative district of Colombo. These days Hullfsdorp is a neighbourhood in Colombo, which is known for the Wolvendaal church built by the Company there in 1746.

title: Hurley
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Nieu Dorp, tegenwoordig bekend in de Verenigde Staten onder de naam Hurley, was gelegen vlakbij Wiltwijck (nu Kingston) aan de Hudsonrivier. Dit dorp werd in 1661 door een aantal Waalse en Nederlandse gezinnen gesticht. In Hurley zijn er nog steeds oude gebouwen uit de 18de eeuw te zien. De meeste van deze huizen en gebouwen bevinden zich langs de belangrijkste straat en dragen nog een Nederlandse naam.

title: Hutumuri
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In Hutumuri, on the eastern coast of Leitimor on the island of Ambon, the VOC set up an additional guard post to combat clove smuggling. In addition to this surveillance function, Hutumuri also produced 'kruithout', also known as 'kayoe marong'.

title: Icoerwa
variants: Icoerwa;post aan de rivier Canjé;Post van Limit;Hicorva
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Amidst the privately owned plantations, many maps of the Canjé river show a 'Company post', sometimes also called the 'post Hicorva' after the adjacent Hicorva creek, in roughly this location. On NG-478 (Rijksmuseum), this post demarcates the border between the colonies of Berbice and Surinam.

title: Igarassu
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Igarassu, in de staat Pernambuco, iets ten zuiden van het eiland Itamaracà, was een van de eerste Portugese nederzettingen in Brazilië. De kleine, door de Portugezen gebouwde kerk op het plein van Igarassu is nog steeds in goede staat en wordt door toeristen van over de hele wereld bezocht. Na de val van Olinda in 1630, vluchtten vele Portugese families naar Igarassu om zich daar te vestigen. Drie jaar later, in 1633, viel ook dit dorpje in Nederlandse handen: het werd door de WIC verwoest en geplunderd. In Igarassù was de zetel van een schepenbank gevestigd. Tevens was het dorp het centrum van een district met acht suikermolens. Een van de eerste gebouwen van de plaats waren een Franciscanenklooster en de kerk São Damiao e Costa.

title: Ilha Grande de Curupá
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Imotappi
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Indragiri
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Indramayu
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. This VOC post in Java dates back to 1681. It lay at the mouth of the Cimanuk River and was staffed by employees who supervised and monitored several warehouses where the harvests of grain and rice were stored. Its situation on the river meant Indramajoe was surrounded by fertile land. In the 18th century no more than four VOC employees were stationed there. At one point the records refer to the presence of a raft builder in the service of the Company.

title: Indrapura
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Indrapoera was situated on the West Coast of Sumatra between Padang and Benkoelen. Around 1659 the VOC set up an office here. The VOC signed contracts with the ruler of Indrapoera, which gave it the sole rights to all pepper harvested in the region. In 1702 the settlement was overrun and the people massacred, but in 1716 the VOC established a new lodge after having negotiated a new contract with the local ruler.

title: Ipojuca
variants: Ipojuca;Pojuca;Posuica;Sao Miguel de Ipojuca;S. Miguel de Ipojuca
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Irakam
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Iranativu, North and South
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. 'The Two Brothers' was the name given to two tiny islands north of Ceylon. The VOC's land muster-rolls show that for most of the 18th century the Company posted two officials there. It is not clear which islands are being referred to, but they could be the two that were known as Enkhuizen and Hoorn in the 18th century.

title: Isla la Tortuga
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Na verovering van de Venezuelaanse zoutpannen van Punta de Araya door de Spanjaarden, waar de Nederlanders zout haalden, moesten zij zich richten op nieuwe plaatsen om zout te winnen. De keuze viel op het nabij gelegen eiland La Tortuga. In 1630 arriveerden de Nederlanders daar voor het eerst, waar zij in der loop der tijd een versterking van aarde en hout bouwden om het eiland te beschermen tegen regelmatige aanvallen van de Spanjaarden. De strijd bleef bestaan. De zoutpannen en het fort werden verschillende keren door de concurrenten verwoest.

title: Itamaracà eiland
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Ten noorden van de stad Recife, de hoofdstad van Nederlands-Brazilië, ligt het eiland Itamaracà. Tijdens de 17de eeuw was het eiland Itamaracà een zelfstandig gewest in bestuurlijk opzicht. Rond 1633 was het geheel door de WIC bezet. Het eiland, een zeer belangrijke bron van voedsel en verversingen voor de latere hoofdstad van de WIC Recife, bleek heel vruchtbaar te zijn: verschillende soorten fruit groeiden in overvloed, er was vers water en een gedeelte van het eiland was ook geschikt voor het verbouwen van voedsel. In 1630 lukte de Nederlanders het Portugese fort de Santa Cruz te veroveren dat langs de kust van het eiland lag. De Portugezen trokken zich terug in de heuvels in een plaats genaamd Nossa Senhora da Conceicao. Na de verovering werd het fortje aan het strand door de Nederlanders herdoopt in fort Oranje ofwel Orange. Het was aanvankelijk een zeer bescheiden vestiging met enkel een palissade, maar het was gelegen op een strategisch punt en waardoor het een degelijke bescherming gaf aan de ingang van het eiland. In 1633, toen kolonel van Schoppe en zijn soldaten vanuit fort Oranje de Portugezen van het eiland verdreven, werd de voormalig Portugese plaats in de heuvels Nossa Senhora da Conceicao door de Nederlandser versterkt. Zodoende ontstond daar in 1633 de nederzetting Van Schoppestad. Aan de noordelijke kant van het eiland was er nog een bastion ter verdediging. Fort Oranje, dat begin 21ste eeuw gerestaureerd is, werd door de jaren heen verbouwd tot een stevige vierhoekige vestiging. Binnen het fort was er ruimte voor een wapenkamer en waren er barakken voor de soldaten.

title: Jaffna
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Jaffna was a busy trading city and the main centre in northern Ceylon. The last bastion of the Portuguese on the island, it fell to the Company in 1658. For the time being the VOC had eliminated all its European competitors on the island. The Company rebuilt much of Jaffna. The Portuguese fort made way for a new one designed according to the latest military principles. The result was an almost impregnable citadel, perhaps the strongest VOC fort in Asia. Construction work, which began in 1660, was finally completed some 130 years later, in 1792. The fort was an important link, guarding the sea lanes to and from India. In Jaffna fort the VOC built a church, known as 'Kruys' (Cross) church. With its layout in the form of a Greek cross, it was typical of Calvinist architecture. Women attending the church services would have their slaves bring chairs which would be taken away again afterwards. The church was built in 1706 and could accommodate 600 people. In the Jaffna region, too, Protestantism was preached with enthusiasm, but the native population often had little idea of the difference between Protestantism and Catholicism.
