In the busy trading town of Jaffna the merchants maintained close contacts with the mainland. The main products of the town and region were cotton, clothes, pearls and elephants. The elephants were sold for the armies of Indian princes. The animals were captured by driving them into a fenced enclosure from where they were taken one by one to be bound and even sometimes to be baptised. After eight days of being tied up an elephant would be more or less tame and ready to be trained. In northern Ceylon the Company enjoyed a certain measure of territorial authority; a unique position for an organisation primarily concerned with trade which (except on Formosa) generally left local rulers in control. On Ceylon this authority involved the Company was responsible for collecting taxes from the local population, among other things. Because the Company levied far higher taxes than was customary, the local inhabitants rose up against the VOC in 1676. However the Company crushed the rebellion and implemented the levy anyway. Jaffna was also the capital of one of the 'commandementen', or departments, into which Ceylon was divided and fell under the jurisdiction of the governor in Colombo.

title: Jailolo
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The Dutch and Spanish maintained various settlements on the on Halmaheira's western coast. In the early 17th century the Dutch built a castle there, that was conquered by the Spanish in 1611.

title: Jakarta
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Bantam was the Company's first base in Asia. After relations with the local rulers worsened, the Company relocated to neighbouring Jacatra, a vassal state of Bantam. The ensuing war was won by the VOC. In 1619, Governor-General Jan Pieterszoon Coen built the new city of Batavia on the ruins of Jacatra. This coastal town became the seat of the East Indies Council, the Company's administrative centre in Asia. The castle at Batavia was the first building visible from the sea. The governor-general and his councillors lived in this coastal fortress together with workers and a garrison of 1200 men. Batavia was the vibrant centre of the VOC's business in Asia; here the Company kept the accounts for all its trading bases and the East Indies Council held its meetings. Official receptions were also held at the castle. Batavia was steeped in European culture, with its small bridges over canals and warehouses along the waterfront. It also boasted numerous European institutions, such as orphanages, churches and hospitals. By 1700 the town had grown enormously: it had 70,000 inhabitants, of whom only 6,000 were of non-Asian origin. Batavia took over Bantam's function as a trading centre in the early 17th century. It became the largest port in Java, and a storage depot for goods from all over Asia. It was also the distribution centre for the money and goods coming out of Europe. Products from the Company's various trading bases were transported to Batavia, and from there they were shipped to Holland. Batavia also played an important role in the trade between the Asian countries. The castle at Batavia was where Company officials met to discuss trade and administrative affairs. It was here that the decisions were made with regard to what the factories and trading posts in Asia needed from the home country, and it was here that the annual reports - the General Missives - were written. VOC trading policies for officials at trading bases was also decided in Batavia. The administrators of this enormous trading network were accountable only to the 'Heeren XVII'. Supreme authority in the VOC in Asia was held by the East Indies Council which was chaired by the Governor General and based in Batavia. The Council served as the link between the different trading bases and the mother country.

title: Jamaica
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Rond 1656 werd op het Lange Eiland, ofwel Long Island, het dorpje Jamaica gesticht. Hier woonden enkel Engelse ingezetenen. Jamaica was een van de 'Engelse' dorpen op Long Island die vielen onder Nederlands bestuur. Dit bestuur zetelde in Nieuw-Amsterdam op het naburige schiereiland Manhattan.

title: Jambi
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The Company had a trading post in Jambi as early as 1615. The town was an important source of pepper. In the early 17th century the Company's main competitors were the Portuguese and the Chinese; but the English were also formidable rivals in the battle for pepper from Jambi. Nevertheless, in 1643 the VOC managed to obtain the pepper monopoly in exchange for protecting the town.

title: Jamestown
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. James town was the first English settlement on the American mainland, in the region the English called Virginia.

title: Jan Pietersz. kolonie
variants: Jan Pietersz. kolonie;Jan Pietersz. Kolonie aan de Oiapoque;Jan Pietersz. Kolonie aan de Wiapoco
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Jaquim
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Jaquin was een van de meest winstgevende posten van de West-Indische Compagnie aan de Slavenkust. Bekend en geprezen werd het hoofd van de post, Hendrik Hertog; hij stond bekend als een bekwaam handelaar in slaven. Om het handelsgebied uit te breiden onderhandelde Hertog met diverse partijen en mengde hij zich in de plaatselijke politieke strijd. Hij sloot zich echter bij de verkeerde kant aan. In plaats van uitbreiding van Jaquin, werd de vestiging aangevallen. Hertog sloeg in 1732 op de vlucht naar het nabij gelegen eiland Appa. Op het eiland Appa richtte hij vervolgens de bestaande handelspost in als een nieuw slavencentrum. In 1733 wordt wederom in de factorij van Jaquin geïnvesteerd om de handel nieuw leven in te blazen. De hernieuwde factorij krijgt de naam 'Zeelandia'. Hertog weet de handel heel even op te starten. Het WIC-bestuur komt er in 1735 achter dat de door hem ingekochte slaven op de Slavenkust duurder blijken te zijn dan die van de Goudkust, terwijl ze in Suriname dezelfde prijs opbrengen. Dat doet Hertog de das om. Vanaf dat moment worden de slavenschepen weer direct naar Elmina aan de Goudkust gestuurd, in plaats van naar de Slavenkust.

title: Jcourouwa, post
variants: post Jcourouwa;post aan de Jcourouwa Kreek;post aan de Icourouwa
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Aan de monding van de rivier Berbice was er, vanaf 1627, sprake van Nederlandse aanwezigheid. Tegenwoordig ligt dit gebied in Guyana. Toen de Nederlanders zich in het gebied rondom de rivier Berbice vestigden, werden er verschillende posten en plantages aangelegd langs de oever van de rivier en haar kreken. Een van de belangrijkste zijrievieren van de Berbice rivier was de Canjé rivier, die in de monding van de Berbice uitmondde. Langs deze rivier werden plantages aangelegd en enige posten. Een van die posten had de naam Jcourouwa, omdat het op een punt gebouwd was waar de kreek Jcourouwa in de Canjé rivier stroomde. Tijdens de opstand van de slaven in 1763 werd deze post verlaten.

title: Jenkin´s Bay
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Jepara
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The port town of Japara was one of the first VOC posts on Java (1614). The VOC initially bought rice here to sell on the Spice Islands. During a conflict with the Mataram kingdom in 1618, the VOC factory was attacked. In retaliation, the VOC destroyed the town. The VOC only returned in 1651, when the town became the main VOC post in Mataram. In 1677 the town was the base of operations of the Company's armies, under command of Cornelis Speelman, during the rebellion of Trunajaya against the susuhunan. In 1708 the headquarters of the VOC on the north coast of Java moved to Semarang, and Japara became of lesser importance. Around 1719 the lodige in Japara was replaced with a small fort with four half-bastions, and a small aquare fort was built on the opposite side of the river.

title: Jersey City
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In 1630 startte Michiel Reyniersz Pauw, een van de bewindhebbers van de WIC, een kolonie met de naam Pavonia, bij Manhattan. Het land, gekocht van de Lenni Lenape indianen, was zeer vruchtbaar. De kolonie Pavonia, een van de eerste permanent bewoonde vestigingen in New Jersey, is een gebied dat tegenwoordig deel uitmaakt van Jersey City en de wijk Hoboken. Pavonia was een zogenaamd patroonschap. Patroonschappen werden door de WIC verleend aan een soort van plantagehouders, met het verschil dat een plantage meestal uit een hoofdhuishouden bestaat en een patroonschap uit huishoudens van ten minste 50 kolonisten. Het patroonschap werkte over het algemeen niet erg goed.

title: Jiddah
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Djeddah, today known as Jiddah, was the port of Mecca, the focus of Islamic pilgrimage. At the beginning of the 17th century, the VOC attempted to trade Far Eastern spices and other goods for coffee and silver in Jedda. The town fell within the jurisdiction of the VOC resident in Mocha, now Al-Mukha. Disappointing results led the Company to cease trading in Jedda in 1655. However, it did continue to derive revenues from transporting pilgrims there. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Joal-Fadiout
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Joal was een van de plaatsen aan de kust van het tegenwoordige Senegal, waar de Nederlanders rond 1633 een factorij hadden. Joal werd rond 1678, tegelijkertijd met andere plaatsen in Senegal, zoals Portudal en Rufisque, door de Fransen veroverd op de Nederlanders. Ook Arguin, een klein eiland gelegen in de gelijknamige baai aan de kust van Mauritanië, namen de Fransen over. Hierdoor nam de WIC-handel in Arabische gom, bezoarstenen, grijze amber en struisvogelveren af. Nadat de Fransen het gebied hadden overgenomen, probeerden de Nederlanders hun macht aan de Senegalese kust te herstellen. De leider van de Franse Compagnie du Senegal, de Fransman Jean Ducasse, gooide het op een akkoordje met de plaatselijke machthebbers om te voorkomen dat de Nederlanders weer voet aan wal konden zetten. Met als gevolg dat de Nederlandse handelsposten in Senegal vernietigd werden.

title: Joao Pessoa
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Ten noorden van de gewesten Pernambuco en Itamaracà - in het tegenwoordige Brazilië - lligt het gewest Paraiba. In 1585 lukte het de Portugezen de Fransen uit dit gebied te verdrijven. Ten noorden van de rivier Paraiba stichtten zij een nederzetting die ter ere van de koning van Spanje en Portugal, Philipz of Filipea werd genaamd, de huidige stad Joao Pessoa. In Paraiba bevonden zich veel 'engenhos', molens waar suiker werd geproduceerd. Bovendien leverde deze streek ook mandioca - het basisvoedsel voor de kolonie-, katoen, tabak en leer. In de omgeving van de plaats bouwden de Portugezen drie forten om de nederzetting te beschermen. Alle drie waren gelegen aan de noordkant, aan de binnenkant van de monding van de rivier Paraiba. Fort Margaretha - eerder genoemd fort Catharina- en fort S. Antonio lagen bij Cabe Dello (Cabedelo), terwijl op het kleine eiland Restingues een klein driehoekig fort gesitueerd was, fort Restinga. In Frederiksstad zelf diende een oud Franciscanenklooster als fortificatie. Er was tevens een toren om de ingang van de haven te verdedigen. De Nederlanders veroverden Paraiba en de nederzetting Filipea in 1634 en hernoemde de vestiging Frederiksstad.

title: Jodensavanne
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. De Joodse Savanne ofwel het 'Joods Dorp', lag stroomopwaarts aan de oostelijke oever van de rivier Suriname. De naam is ontleend aan de vele gevluchte joden die hier kwamen wonen tussen 1650 en 1664. In deze periode werd Nederlands-Brazilië veroverd door de Portugezen, hetgeen vele joden deed vluchten naar andere bestemmingen. Ze trokken naar gebieden rondom de Cayenne en de Suriname rivier, waar Nederlanders gevestigd waren. In Suriname kregen zij van de Engelsen stukken land om te verbouwen. De nieuwkomers bouwden hier in 1665 hun eerste synagoge en tijdens het gouvernement van Sommelsdijck in 1685, een tweede synagoge, opgetrokken uit baksteen. Daarmee werd de plaats voor een lange periode het centrum van de joodse gemeenschap in deze regio. In de loop van de 18de eeuw, toen Paramaribo steeds groter werd als hoofdplaats van de Nederlandse kolonie, werd de Joodse Savanne door vele mensen verlaten in plaats voor een grotere een beter gelegen vestiging aan de monding van de rivier Suriname. Door een brand in de 19de eeuw kwam er een definitief einde aan deze belangrijke nederzetting.

title: Juwana
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Joana, a VOC post on the northeastern coast of Java, fell under the VOC headquarters at Semarang. The outpost was set up in order to combat the secret trade in rice and sugar. The post further functioned as a place of refuge for vessels during the west monsoon. In charge of this residence was a vice merchant who was charged with ensuring that Joana supplied the Company with rice, wood, and to a lesser extent indigo and cotton yarns. The VOC station was situated on the banks of the Joana River, one of the biggest and busiest in Java. The Company redoubt boasted four half bastions which housed rice warehouses, barracks for the troops and the kitchens for the residence. In later years the resident built his living quarters outside the redoubt.

title: Kaapverdië
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In 1462, Portuguese settlers arrived at Santiago and founded a settlement they called Ribeira Grande (now called Cidade Velha, to avoid being confused with the town of Ribeira Grande on the Santo Antão island). Ribeira Grande was the first permanent European settlement in the tropics. In the 16th century, the archipelago prospered from the Atlantic slave trade. Pirates occasionally attacked the Portuguese settlements. Sir Francis Drake, an English corsair privateering under a letter of marque granted by the English crown, twice sacked the (then) capital Ribeira Grande in 1585 when it was a part of the Iberian Union. After a French attack in 1712, the town declined in importance relative to nearby Praia, which became the capital in 1770.

title: Kachchai
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The Dutch presence in Kachchai made itself felt through the church and the church hall, which served as a school. The Dutch clergyman Baldaeus led the congregations of northern Ceylon between 1656 and 1665. He compiled a book with a detailed description of Ceylon. Like other Company employees, clergymen were required to serve for five years, excluding the journey. For married employees the term was ten years.

title: Kaddaiparichchan
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The Dutch won permission from the king to build a settlement on the Bay of Cotia, where Trinconomale is also situated, as early as 1612. But it was to take until 1668 before the Company really established a base there.

title: Kaibobo
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The inhabitants of Kaibobo are reported to have remained faithful to the VOC from the year 1605, when Castle Victoria on Ambon was conquered. The Company assisted this village against Loehoe, a nearby enemy village, and in exchange it gained permission to conduct free trade with the Kaibobo villagers. Kaibobo was one of the most important native villages on the southern coast of West Ceram. In contrast to most of the rest of Ambon, the residents of Kaibobo were soon converted to Christianity. The local population supplied services to the VOC. The men of Kaibobo were called up in turn to serve at the Zeelandia redoubt on the island of Oma with ten men on average working there per month. The work they were required to do varied, but it mainly comprised building fortifications or supplying the raw materials for construction. Around 1687 the VOC, aided by the local population, built a church in Kaibobo. The town supplied the wood used by the VOC in stockades, or wooden fences, for nearby settlements. Pieter van Dam, who recorded the history of the VOC around 1701, maintains that the village boasted a barricade by the name of Den Bosch, built in 1695.

title: Kakinada
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Jaggernaijkpoeram, also known as Kakinada, lay on the Coromandel Coast between Bimlipatnam and Masulipatnam. In the 18th century it counted as one of the VOC's key bases in this area.

title: Kalbut
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Caliboentoe, today known as Kalbut, was situated in east Java near Panarokan. It had a fort manned by seven to 20 troops.

title: Kalpitya
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The garrison at Fort Kalpitya had to ensure that no traders broke the VOC's cinnamon monopoly. The fort's position at the harbour entrance meant that the VOC could blockade Kalpitya harbour. This tactic was also used to put pressure on the king of Kandy when the Company came into conflict with him.

title: Kalutara
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The fort at Kalutara lay at the mouth of the River Kalu. This river had a strategically important role to play in transporting products from the Ceylonese interior. The Company wanted to guard this access point. Like Negombo, Kalutara was important in the cinnamon trade.

title: Kandy
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC administration in Ceylon was engaged in a continuous war of attrition with the kingdom of Kandy. This friction came to a head on two occasions: first under Governor Rijcklof van Goens, who aimed to make Ceylon the VOC's central power base in Asia - against the wishes of the king, and indeed against those of Batavia. The second was in 1760, when war broke out between Kandy and the Company. The VOC won this war. Every year delegations from both side visited one another.

title: Kanton/Guangzhou
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1652 the VOC sent a delegation to Canton to look into the possibilities for trade there. The court in Peking had repeatedly responded negatively to any overtures from the warlike Dutch, but the merchants in Canton showed more interest. During the 17th century the Company only sailed to Canton occasionally, to buy silk and porcelain. This changed when Europe began drinking tea in the 18th century. In the 18th century the VOC rented permanent premises in Canton, next to the building occupied by the British. Europeans were obliged to do business with the merchants who worked together in organisations known as 'Hongs' with an exclusive licence from the Chinese government to trade with foreigners. However, in spite of the monopoly of the powerful Hongs and the high taxes on trade, the profits that could be made in the tea trade gave the Europeans every reason to remain in Canton. Tea and porcelain were the principal products purchased by the VOC in Canton. For some time the Company sailed directly from Holland to Canton. By cutting out the halfway house in Batavia, where the tea was often stored for long periods of time, the Company was able to supply fresh tea to Europe. But leaving the tea trade to Batavia meant that the VOC was able to pay in China with spices, rather than with silver or with lengths of fabric from the Dutch Republic. European merchants were confined to their warehouses and trading offices along the quay outside the city walls, and were forbidden to enter Canton itself. Through the Hong merchants, the Chinese government exercised a tight control over the foreigners' trade and behaviour. All transactions were carried out through a merchant who was also authorised to collect taxes for the government and to ensure compliance wit the rules. The Europeans had little or no direct contact with the Chinese authorities.

title: Karaikal
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. At Karikal the Company maintained an office trading in cloves, pepper and especially cotton fabrics which were often cheaper here than at Pulicat on the Coromandel Coast. But the base declined amid the drought and famine engendered by a war in the area around Karikal and eventually had to be disbanded.

title: Karaitivu
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Karpata
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Kartasura
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. In 1680 Sunan Amangkurat II established his court at Kartasura. At the time, there was a rivalling court at Pleret, ruled by Prins Puger. Both claimed to be the ruler of Mataram. The VOC backed Amangkurat and helped defeat Puger, after which Kartasura became the undisputed capital of Mataram. The kings who reigned from Kartasura were: Amangkurat II (1677-1703), Amangkurat III, Pakubuwana I (1704-1719) and Amangkurat IV (1719-1727). Pakubuwana II (1727-1729 was the last ruler who lived in the palace of Kartasura. In 1742 the Chinese revolted against the sultan, who fled to Ponogoro in West Java. There he got support from the VOC and adipati Cakraningrat of West-Madura. Kartasura was retaken and the rebellion suppressed, but the craton was demolished and no longer sacred Pakubuwana II decided to build a new palace and capital in the village Sala (Solo, Surakarta). On February 17, 1745, the monarch moved to his new craton.

title: Kartosuro
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Carta Soura lay in the Javanese interior and was the headquarters of the Susuhunan, the suzerain of the Mataram region in central Java. This sovereign ruled over a large number of regents, who were required to attend the court at Carta Soura once a year. When conflicts arose with these regents, the suzerain applied for the help and protection of the VOC. The Company decided to aid the Susuhunan and despatched 200 soldiers to be stationed at Carta Soera to safeguard the Company's interests and those of the Susuhunan. However, relations between the suzerain and the Company remained in a state of flux.

title: Kattaiveli
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The northern Ceylonese town of Kattaivelli also had its Portuguese church. The Dutch introduced the Protestant faith. During the Portuguese period a crucifix served as a focus of worship, but when the VOC came the Kattaivelli crucifix fell victim to the Calvinist aversion to Catholic symbols. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Katuwana
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. To defend the interior of southern Ceylon against the king of Kandy, the VOC built a number of jungle forts of which Katuwana was one. Because the European VOC soldiers were unable to withstand the extreme climatic conditions, the Company relied mainly on local soldiers to man this fort. But in any case the fort was so small that there was hardly room to swivel a cannon.

title: Kay Bay
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Kayalpatnam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Cailpatnam lay on India's eastern coast, below Tuticorin. Immediately after the Portuguese drove the Dutch out of the neighbouring area, known as Madura, the Company built a lodge and a warehouse for storing products.

title: Kayankulam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The Company signed a trading agreement with Kayankulam as early as 1643. This led to a new trading base here some years later; the VOC's first base on the Malabar coast. The Company subsequently built a warehouse next to the base for storing pepper.

title: Kayeli
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Kayeli was one of the few villages on the island of Buru that had surrendered to the Company. Most of the villages on Buru belonged to the realm of the king of Ternate. Since clove cultivation on Buru was limited, Kayeli was of strategic rather than commercial value.

title: Kediri
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Keelung
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Shortly after the VOC had established itself on the west coast of Formosa, the Spaniards established a rivalling colony on northern Taiwan. On the island Keelung (now known as Heping Island) they built fort San Salvador. After 1636, when the Spanish governer of the Philippines decided to withdraw most of the Spanish troops from Taiwan, the VOC saw a chance to drive the Spaniards from the island. In 1642, it succeeded in conquering the Spanish forts on northern Taiwan. - In 1662, the VOC abandoned northern Taiwan in the wake of the invasion of Southwestern Taiwan by the Chinese warlord Koxinga. In 1664, during the alliance between the Qing and the VOC, it was briefly re-occupied, and the forts were rebuilt. As the trade with China did not revive, the post was once again abandoned in 1668.

title: Kema
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1755 the VOC stationed three people at its post in Kema, which was situated south of Manado. As the century wore on the number of employees at Kema grew. By 1779 the outpost numbered 14 people.

title: Kerman
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Kirman, a town lying in the southern Persian province of the same name, was known for its wool trade. From 1658 onwards the VOC bought goat's wool (cork) here from Armenian agents in its service, who travelled there from Gamron. A trading post was based in a rented house around 1690. It was subsequently closed down in 1725, reestablished in 1732 before being abandoned once more in 1740. The VOC continued to buy fine goat's wool, but from Gamron.

title: Keta
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Het fortje Singelenburgh te Keta lag ten oosten van Accra, tussen de Goudkust en de Slavenkust. Van het fort is niet veel meer bekend dan dat rond 1730 het WIC-bestuur, dat zich in het hoofdkwartier te Elmina bevond, het fort niet wenste te vernieuwen wegens de continue strijd tussen de plaatselijke vorsten. Daarnaast was in Keta en omgeving behoorlijke concurrentie gaande tussen de Nederlandse Compagnie en de Deense.

title: Kets Mandui
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The land muster-rolls of 1755 mention three settlements falling under the aegis of the headquarters at Suratte. One of these was Kets Mandui, where six VOC officials were stationed. The latter-day location of this settlement is unclear.

title: Khambhat
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Khambat, or Cambaya, was a moderately sized trading town situated on a river not far from the coast. It was inaccessible for larger vessels as at ebb tide the river virtually ran dry. In 1617 the VOC opened a trading base in Khambat, but this base was permanently manned only until 1634. According to the local inhabitants, the subsequent decline in trade resulted from the arrival of the Dutch and English, who had driven out the Portuguese. The VOC mainly bought cotton fabrics in Khambat. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Khanakul
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post. The town is indicated with a dutch flag on the map in Koninklijke Bibliotheek, Den Haag, inv. nr. 185 A 5 deel V, first book, after p. 146.

title: Kharg
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. After 1750 the VOC wanted to set up a lodge at Kharg, an island in the north of the Persian Gulf near Basra. In Kareek, as Kharg was also known, Javanese sugar and Indian textiles were offered for sale. A trading post was set up in Khark in fort Mosselsteijn in November 1753. This fort was built between November 1753 and December 1754. However it soon transpired the outpost was unprofitable, partly as a result of the high costs of building and manning the fort there, known as Mosselstein. The VOC left Khark on January 1, 1766 when the fort was handed over to Mir Mohanna, head of the coastal settlement, Bandar-e Rig.

title: Khum Peam Lvek
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The village of Lauweck in Cambodia was situated along the Mekong River near Phnom Penh and Oudong or Udong, the old capital. As early as 1609 the VOC was already undertaking occasional expeditions from Pattani to Cambodia to buy goods such as deer hides and ray skins, which were in great demand in Japan. The company set up a trading post at Lauweck in 1620, but the trade there proved disappointing, and just two years later the company shut the post down. The Lauweck trading post was reopened on three further occasions, but in 1667 the VOC left Cambodia for good.Besides deer hides and ray skins, Cambodia functioned mainly as a source of provisions for Batavia such as rice, butter, salted pork, and lard. The Company also bought benzoic resin, gum lacquer, ivory and gold, in exchange for which it mostly supplied cotton fabrics.Lauweck was not a busy trading port; the majority of the population made their living from agriculture. Because there was little money in circulation, trading usually took the form of barter.The Company's officials in Cambodia frequently fell victim to attacks, raids and epidemics. As such the VOC was in almost constant negotiation with the king of Cambodia about reparations. In 1644 a VOC delegation sailed up the river to Phnom Penh. Meanwhile a fortified dam with 50 guns was built behind them. The Company suffered heavy losses in the ensuing battle but nevertheless resumed relations with Cambodia some ten years later.

title: Kilakkarai
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Kilkare was a small VOC outpost north of Tutucorin. The Company lodge at Kilkare was a large and long building. It remained in VOC ownership for around 37 years, until 1795.

title: Kindua
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location (Koninlijke Bibliotheek, inv.nr. 185 A 5 deel V, I, na p. 146) featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Kingston
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Esopus, ofwel Sopus, lag halverwege twee Nederlandse posten: fort Oranje te Beverwijck en fort Amsterdam bij Nieuw-Amsterdam, aan de Hudson rivier. Hier vestigde zich, rond 1652, een groep van ongeveer 60 man. Zij waren afkomstig van het meer noordelijk gelegen fort Oranje. Zij noemden het plaatsje Esopus, naar de Esopus kreek, die uitmondde in de Hudson rivier. De oevers bleken uitermate goed geschikt landbouwgebied, iets dat de Indianen lange tijd terug al hadden ontdekt. De aanvankelijk goede verstandhouding tussen de Indianen en de nieuwkomers veranderde; de zogenaamde Esopus oorlogen braken uit. In 1657 liet Peter Stuyvesant, de directeur-generaal van Nieuw-Nederland, een palissade bouwen rondom het dorp. Hij hernoemde het dorp: Wiltwyck. De naam Kingston kreeg het in pas 1669, onder Engels bewind.

title: Kirinda
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Kirinde was a small settlement located on the southern coast of Ceylon. In the VOC land muster-rolls of 1775, Kirinde is listed as one of Galle's four outposts. It was manned by just one Company official.

title: Kisar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1668 the VOC built a small fort by the name of 'Delft' or 'Delftshaven' on the island of Kisser, eight miles east of Timor. Dr F.W. Stapel, who edited Pieter Van Dam's description of the VOC and published it in 1927, refers to the 'Mestiezen of Kissar'. This was a population group on the island whose ancestors were VOC employees who married Kissar women.

title: Knip Baai
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Koemacca kreek
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Kohao
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In the native village of Kohao, situated on the north coast of the island of Saparua between Pia and Hatuane, the VOC had set up a small outpost. Throughout the 18th century the outpost was never manned by more than a single soldier.

title: Kokinaan
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In the land muster-rolls of 1735 this VOC outpost is named as Kokienaan. In that year Kokienaan numbered three VOC workers. It fell under the aegis of the head comptoir on the Coromandel Coast.

title: Komenda
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. De Nederlanders richtten in 1688, in het plaatsje Komenda aan de Goudkust, fort Vredenburgh op. Komenda lag aan de monding van de gelijknamige rivier, iets ten westen van Elmina (waar het hoofdkwartier van de Nederlanders sinds 1637 lag). In Komenda stond toen al een Engels fort. Beide forten hadden vier bastions.

title: Kondaichchi
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Kopay
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. As in the rest of northern Ceylon, the churches opened schools in which local children were given a Protestant religious education. At Kopay a system was employed whereby the older children taught the younger ones. The Company considered religious education a form of government. It was intended to bind its subjects to the Company. On Ceylon, where the VOC exercised territorial authority, it was engaged in more than just trade. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Kota Tingi
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Kotaagung
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Lampong Samanca lay on the southern tip of Sumatra in the Bay of Samanca. It was situated in the Lampon district and fell under the aegis of the sultanate of Bantam. Lampong produced the pepper on which the VOC held a monopoly. The Company maintained a station here that was disbanded in 1795. The small fort at Samanca had two bastions and was surrounded by a moat. Between 15 and 20 troops were stationed here.

title: Kpone
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In het plaatsje Kpone was een Nederlands fortje zonder naam. Kpone, of Ponni, lag iets ten oosten van Accra aan de Goudkust en werd in 1706 gesticht.

title: Krabbetago (Kreek)
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. By the late eighteenth century the area around this creek was cultivated.

title: Kraton Yogyakarta
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The king of Mataram ruled over his kingdom from the palace in Djokjakarta. Through his conquest of the coastal territories in the 17th century, he controlled virtually all of Java. However, internal divisions and the increasing power of the Company weakened the king's position. He became increasingly dependent on the VOC, which provided the king with military and financial support against his rebellious vassals. In 1743 the king ceded his kingdom to the Company, which thus became the unchallenged ruler of Java.

title: Kronendal
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Kronendal country house, situated in the Hout Bay area south of the Cape of Good Hope, was assigned to Willem van Dieden in 1681 and later to Pieter van der Westhuizen. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Kuala Kedah
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Kuala Linggi
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In deze kustplaats zijn nog de restanten te vinden van fort Philippina. Het fort had een omtrek van ca. 200 meter. Het fort, dat werd gebouwd in 1756/7, is genoemd naar de dochter van gouverneur-generaal Jacob Mossel.

title: Kuala Selangor
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Selangor, on the west coast of the Malaysian peninsula, was captured by Jacob Pieter van Braam in 1784. The former ruler of Siak, Muhammad Ali, aided Van Braam in overrunning the town. The Company established two forts and a battery in the town: Altingburg, Utrecht en 'Van Braams batterij'. Muhammad Ali was appointed as a regent in exchange for protecting the rights of the VOC. No Chinese or other European ships were allowed to put at anchor and the tin had to be sold to the VOC at fixed prices.

title: Kundapura
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1667 the VOC set up a trading base in Barseloor. This town's sole importance was as a source of rice, with which the VOC provisioned its other bases on the Malabar coast. Following problems with local traders, the base closed 15 years later.

title: Kupang
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Koepang on the island of Timor was captured in 1619. Fort Concordia was built in the first half of the 17th century. In 1655 the VOC's headquarters were relocated from Solor to Koepang, otherwise known as Fort Concordia. Koepang was to remain the VOC's headquarters for the Timor region until 1796. Relations between the Company and the Portuguese, who were also based on Timor, were extemely poor. During the 18th century the Company's employees were involved in the torture of the Timor people, while kidnapping and slave trading (which had existed previously) were the order of the day. The garrison fell into a deplorable state. For both the Dutch and the Portuguese, Timor was and remained a settlement of little importance.

title: Kwandang
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In Guandang, on Sulawesi's northern coast, the Company maintained an outpost over which a resident had been appointed chief. At times during the 18th century this outpost sometimes expanded into a settlement with 25 staff.

title: Kyk Overal
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. De Essequibo (ofwel Isekepe genoemd in de 18de eeuw) rivier ligt in het noorden van Zuid-Amerika, nu Brits Guyana. Al vanaf het begin van de 17de eeuw werd dit gebied door de Nederlanders bevaren. In de loop der tijd ving men aan met de verbouw van suikerriet. Ook werd er handel gedreven in orianeverf, maaraan-olie en diverse houtsoorten. Deze producten werden met de indianen uit het binnenland geruild tegen Europese producten. Aan de Essequibo rivier werd er al in het begin van de 17de eeuw een volksplanting of een patroonschap opgericht door de heer Joost van der Hooge, met de naam Nova Zelandia. Dit soort patroonschappen werden door de WIC verleend aan eigenaren van land, vergelijkbaar met plantagehouders. Met het verschil dat een plantage meestal uit één hoofdhuishouden bestaat en een patroonschap uit veel meer huishoudens. Van der Hooge trof een oudere Portugese versterking aan. Op de poort van het gebouw was het symbool van het Portugese rijk te zien. Van der Hooge herdoopte dit fort met de naam 'fort ter Hooge'. Later kreeg het de naam 'Kijk Overal'. De versterking lag op een klein eiland stroomopwaarts de Essequibo, op de samenvloeiing van de Cayuni en Mazaruni rivier. Vanaf het begin van de 17de eeuw werd deze streek, waar drie rivieren samenvloeien, geweid aan suikerplantages. 3 à 4 plantages behoorden de WIC toe; 12 à 15 aan particuliere planters. Verder stroomopwaarts van de rivier Cayouni schijnt er ook een kleine post te hebben gelegen waar paarden gekocht werden van kooplieden uit Spaans Guyana. Tot 1657 werd er aan deze kolonie geen speciale aandacht geschonken. Pas in 1657 begon een nieuwe fase van kolonisatie van het gebied. In dat jaar werd het bestuur van de regio aan de Directie der Nieuwe Colonie op Isekepe gegeven. Deze directie bestond uit bestuursleden die de steden Middelburg, Veere en Vlissingen vertegenwoordigden. De nieuwe kolonie had vanaf dat moment de naam Nova Zeelandia. Essequibo en Pomeroon werden in 1666 door de Engelsen aangevallen. Pomeroon werd door de Engelsen veroverd en verlaten, maar Essequibo werd teruggewonnen en in 1669 kwam de kolonie rechtsstreek in handen van de WIC. De post Kijk Overal bleef tot 1718 hoofdplaats van de kolonie en zetel van de commandeur. In 1718 werd de hoofdplaats naar de vestiging Cartabo verplaatst, tegenover Fort Kijk Overal, en in 1739 naar fort Zeelandia, op het Vlaggeneiland.

title: Lacij
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The Halve Maan redoubt presided over the nutmeg groves on the southern coast of the island of Lonthor. Built in 1620, it was ringed by a low wall of coral.

title: Laha
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Muslims whom the VOC had driven out of Nusaniwe and other villages of Leitimor founded Laha, situated on the bay of Ambon opposite Ambon City, after 1620. The VOC built fortifications there, as Laha offered prime moorings for vessels visiting the bay during the west monsoons. Laha was surrounded by sago forest. The sago produced here formed the staple diet of the inhabitants of the Moluccan islands.

title: Lampong Toulang Bauang
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The Tulangbawang is a river in southern Sumatra. During the VOC era it functioned as the border between the districts of Bantam and Palembang. The area supplied the best quality pepper to the VOC. Around 1738 the Company set up an observation post on the Tulangbawang River called Valkenoog or Valkenburg for the surveillance of the Company's pepper shipments. As a result of several local uprisings around 1750 it became impossible for the VOC to store up sufficient pepper for the return trip to the Netherlands. In order to avoid delaying the fleet's departure, the VOC was forced to buy in the far more expensive Malabar pepper.

title: Land van Waveren
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Towards the end of the 17th century the most farflung outposts of the VOC falling under the Cape of Good Hope were Saldanha Bay in the north, Clapmuts in the north-east and Hottentots Holland in the east. During this period it became imperative the Company extend its borders in order to furnish the free burghers with new land on which to farm. Consequently a valley north east of the Cape was annexed, which became known as ' 't Land van Waveren'. This Waveren valley, as the region was also known, proved suitable for arable farming, livestock and vineyards. Due to problems with the indigenous tribes in the region, the livestock in 't Land van Waveren was driven to the post of Riet Vallei during the winter months, where the cold was less extreme. In 1743 the post was sold to a burgher called P. de Vos in a transaction presided over by the then governor, Swellengrebel. De Vos renamed the town Nooitgedacht.

title: Langebaan
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Laoutang
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The nutmeg groves on the eastern coast of the island of Lonthor boasted a redoubt that served to protect the small bay.

title: Lar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. From 1631 the VOC maintained a house in Lar. This base fell under the VOC's Persian section. Lar was used as an oasis by caravans travelling from Esfahan to Gamron (known today as Bandar Abbas). Unlike Gamron, Lar had enough water and grass for the camels. Company officials often stayed here for several months, until the VOC ships arrived at Gamron. Due to the hot and arid climate, living conditions were severe.

title: Larike
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Larike was, until 1617, under the regime of Captain Hitoe, whose headquarters were based in Hila. The Company promised to aid the inhabitants of Larike against this hostile captain, but in exchange for this aid the VOC demanded a trading post. Cloves from the surrounding area were traded in Larike, where 'Fort Rotterdam' was situated.

title: Lawayang
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Fort Henricus on the island of Solor was built by the Portuguese in the second half of the 16th century. The VOC captured the fort in 1613. The settlement at Solor was aimed at controlling or gaining a monopoly on the trade in sandalwood, which was imported from Portuguese East Timor. In 1616 it was abandoned. In September 1618 the territory was occupied once more and the actual fort of Frederik Hendrik (also known as Hendricus or Henricus) was built. In 1628 the fort was abandoned once more, only to be reoccupied in 1646 as a result of The Hague truce, which forced the VOC to define its various territorial claims. From 1655 staffing at the fort was reduced to two woodsmen, or gunners, and in 1760 the fort was finally abandoned altogether.

title: Laäla
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Laala was a settlement on Hoamoal (Western Seram), a clove-producing region ruled by the <kimelaha>, de ruler of Hoamoal with whom the VOC was periodically in conflict. At the beginning of the Great Ambon War (1651-1656) the VOC's wooden fortification near Laala was taken in a suprise attack. During the subsequent conflict, Laala was heavily fortified with Makasar help. After a siege in September 1654, it was, however, taken in a brutal manner. After the end of the war, the entire peninsula was depopulated and its inhabitants forced to resettle elsewhere.

title: Leeukop
parent_name: Peninsula; Cape of Good Hope (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Leewenkop was situated on the Leeuwenberg mountain on the Cape's western coast. It was originally established as a signal post and a surveillance point for the coastal defences. Around 1657 Van Riebeeck earmarked it as the location to set up fire beacons. Right up until the end of the VOC era Leeuwenkop remained a strategic outpost, in part because it offered a view of both Robben Island and Dassen Island.

title: Leguan Island
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Leti
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A small VOC post employing three to four personnel occupied Lethij, now known as Leti and situated a little east of the island of Timor. According to a description dating back to 1694, the staff included two 'schildergasten'. These were ordinary soldiers.

title: Lewes
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. - Swanendael was bought from the native Americans by a certain Gillis Hossett, working for Samuel Godijn. The latter was a director of the <Noordse Compagnie>, a whaling company operating mostly in the Arctic region around Spitsbergen. Swanendael was one of the first patroonships in New Netherland. The first colonists arrived here in 1631, but the village was destroyed by the indigenous population the next year. - In roughly the same location, a fort was established in 1659 that is generally known as the 'Compagniesfort' The location of the fort was called Whorekill. The surrounding area was bought by the Dutch in 1663, but conquered by the English the next year.

title: Liang
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Most of the VOC outposts in Amboina were established in strategic locations in order to protect the clove islands against attack from other European powers. The outposts were also intended as surveillance points to monitor Asian shipping and the island residents. This was aimed at ensuring that the Ambon villagers surrendered their cloves harvest to their village chiefs, who in turn were required to supply the product to the Company. Liang was a native village on the northeastern coast of the island of Ambon, with a redoubt. In 1635 110 men were stationed at the redoubt.

title: Lima
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Lima was also known as Negorij Lima, a name that says something about the village's origins: 'lima' means five and 'negorij' means village. Five tiny villages grew together to form a single town. The Company built a redoubt, 'Haarlem', in Negorij Lima on the northwestern coast of Ambon in 1655. The primary function of the blockhouse was to combat piracy by the Alfoer, the oldest indigenous inhabitants of Amboina and the surrounding area.

title: Limbangan
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The town of Limbangan, situated near Cheribon on Java, is named as a VOC settlement in the land muster-rolls of 1765. The post was manned by just a single VOC official.

title: Limboto
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Limbotte was situated a little to the north of Gorontalo in northern Sulawesi. The Company frequently ran into problems with the Spanish here. The Company had established a presence in northern Sulawesi in order to safeguard its monopoly position on the island archipelagos of Ambon and Banda. The trade in spices was not a motivating factor, as the quality of the available spices was inferior to those of Ambon and Banda.

title: Lisabata
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Lisabata was situated on the north coast of Seram. The settlement was moved several times in the course of its history, and in the mid-17th century, was at Hatu Patola. During the Great Ambon War (1651-1656) is was allies to the <kimelaha> and its supporters. For this reason, the last surviving Makasar allies of the <kimelaha> tried to make their way there in the hope of subsequently finding a way back to Makassar. In August 1655 their path was blocked by VOC troops and their Alfur allies. The Makasars were defeated and scattered throughout the interior

title: Lissidi
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Lesidi was a settlement on Hoamoal (Western Seram), a clove-producing area ruler by the <kimelaha>, the political leader of the peninsula, with whom the VOC was regularly in conflict. Like Kambelo slightly to its south, Lesidi had the reputation of selling its cloves to traders from Makassar and Java, which regularly brought it into conflict with the VOC. At the end of the Great Ambon War (1651-1656), the entire peninsula was depopulated, and its inhabitants forced to resettle.

title: Loango
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Vanaf het begin van de 17de eeuw had de WIC een loge in Loango-Boary, een post gelegen in de regio ten noorden van de Congo rivier, ook wel bekend als Loango. Tot 1670 handelden de Nederlanders hier in ivoor en koper. Ook al werd vanaf 1670 de slavenhandel in dit gebied meer lucratief, de handel in zijn totaliteit bleek voor de Compagnie een tegenvaller. De loge werd rond 1684 verlaten. In 1721 besloot de WIC de loge te heropenen, maar ongeveer vijf jaar later werd het door de lokale bevolking ingenomen.

title: Loji
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1682 the sultan of Bacan sold a number of islands to the VOC for 700 rix-dollars, that is, 1750 guilders. On one of these islands, Obi, the VOC built Fort Den Briel. The sultan also received 80 rix-dollars annually for destroying illegally planted clove trees in his domain.

title: Loki
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Loki was a settlement on Hoamoal (Western Seram), a clove-producing region ruled by the <kimelaha>, the leader of Hoamoal with whom the VOC was periodically in conflict. During the Great Ambon War (1651-1656), the <kimelaha>, along with other local leaders, took up residence in a fort in the hills over Loki. In response, the VOC attacked and destroyed both the fort and the settlement in October 1652. At the end of the war, the entire peninsula was depopulated, and the people living there forced to relocate.

title: Luanda
variants: Luanda;Loanda;Sao Paulo de Luanda;S. Paulo de Luanda
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. São Paolo de Loanda was het grootste Portugese slavendepot aan de Afrikaanse kust. In 1641 veroverden de Nederlanders de stad Loanda aan de kust van Angola. De veroveraars herdoopten het Portugese fort met de naam Aardenburgh. Al eerder deed de WIC in 1624 een poging Loanda te veroveren, maar door onvoldoende manschappen en schepen mislukte de aanval. Tussen 1641 en 1648 beheerden de Nederlanders er de slavenhandel. In deze periode werd het gebied Loango-Angola bestuurd door een gouverneur die in São Paolo de Loanda zijn zetel had en niet vanuit Elmina, waar de WIC haar hoofdbestuur voor de Afrikaanse westkust had.Het gebied bleek eerder verlies dan winst op te leveren: Tussen 1641 en 1648 werden er slechts 14.000 slaven uit Loanda getransporteerd. Na 1648 werd er door de WIC niet meer gevaren op plaatsen die zuidelijker lagen dan Congo.

title: Lucelle
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Lusiela was a settlement on Hoamoal (Western Seram), a clove-producing region ruled by the <kimelaha>, the leader of Hoamoal with whom the VOC was periodically in conflict. . At the end of the Great Ambon War (1651-1656), the entire peninsula was depopulated, and the people living there forced to relocate.

title: Luhu
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Luhu was traditionally the residence of the <kimelaha>, the ruler of Hoamoal (Western Seram), who officially ruled the area in the name of Ternate. As such, the VOC had a fraught relationship with Luhu: in times of peace there was a fortified trading post. However, due to shifting VOC policy and the regular tensions and conflicts with the <kimelaha>, it was often abandoned. During the Great Ambon War, there was ample fighting around Luhu, for example in 1654, when the VOC wanted to destroy the sago groves growing near the river Kahouli. At the end of the war, the entire peninsula was depopulated, and the people living there forced to relocate.

title: Lumajang
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. During the 18th century the VOC post at Lamadjang in the interior of Java's eastern point deployed between 18 and 32 men.

title: Macao
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Machilipatnam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Masulipatnam had long been a major town, attracting merchants from all over the world. Encouraged by the propitious trading conditions, the VOC established a base here for purchasing cotton fabrics. Despite difficulties with the local authorities, Masulipatnam remained one of the VOC's principal bases on the Coromandel Coast.

title: Madalagam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Various land muster-rolls of the VOC make reference to the settlement of Madilagam, also spelled as Madalagam Caro en Madigalam. The village lay on the Malabar Coast, near Porca and Chettua, but the latter day situation of this place is still unclear.

title: Madeira
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Madras
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Magelhaen, Straat van
variants: Straat van Magelhaen;Straat van Magellaan;Straat van Magelhaes
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Strait between Tierra del Fuego and Patagonia, charted in 1520 by the Portuguese explorer Ferdinand Magellan, who was looking for a southwestern passage to Asia on an expedition initiated by the Spanish crown. After its discovery, Tierra del Fuego was reckoned to be part of a great southern continent, so that the Magellan Strait was considered the only passage from the Atlantic to the Pacific. In 1616, a Dutch expedition under Schouten and Le Maire would sail south of Tierra del Fuego, thus disproving this notion.

title: Mahagama
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Mahagama was said to have been situated somewhere between Yala and Walawe on the south-eastern coast of Ceylon. The town could be that of Magame, which is indicated as such on the map of Ceylon contained in François Valentijn's book. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Mahebourg
parent_name: Mauritius; Cape of Good Hope (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The island of Mauritius was used by Dutch ships as a staging post from the end of the 16th century, but it was not until 1637 that the 'Heeren XVII' decided the Company should take possession of the island. A fort was built and manned by 50 to 80 VOC employees, as well as slaves, exiles and convicts. In 1657 the 'Hooge regeering' (Supreme Government) of the VOC in Batavia decided to abandon the island and transfer the population to the Cape of Good Hope. However, in the face of looming French competition the Company decided in 1664 to reoccupy the base. In 1710 the island was left for good. Mauritius was highly suitable as a staging post because it was exceptionally fertile. The island also had a wealth of bird life - including the dodo - as well as turtles and manatees, which were hunted on a large scale. Pigs, deer and goats were also left behind on the island as livestock. The island was particularly important as a source of ebony, large quantities of which were felled in the interior. Plantations were established producing sugar cane, rice, vegetables and fruit.

title: Makassar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The trade entrepot of Makassar played an important role in intra-Asian trade in the 17th century and as such proved a formidable competitor for Batavia as a trading centre in the early 17th century. The trade centred on cloves, nutmeg and mace imported from the Molucca Islands, Ambon and Banda. From 1607 the VOC had a trading base in Makassar, where it focused initially on trade in cloves. From 1615 onwards, Makassar and the VOC increasingly got into conflict as the VOC tried to impose a spice monopoly in the Moluccas. The state of Gowa-Tallo, of which Makassar was the capital, supported wars and rebellions in the Moluccas that stood up to the VOC's monopolistic ambitions with regard to the spices produced there. Makassar itself became an important trading city in these same spices, selling to both European and Asian traders, thus thwarting Dutch monopolistic ambitions. In a series of conflicts, the VOC was increasingly able to keep the traders operating from Makassar from accessing the spices. After a surprise attack in 1660, it was able to force the rulers to evict the large Portuguese community. In 1667-1669, in cooperation with its local ally, Arung Palakka, it definitively managed to break the power of Gowa-Tallo, and install their ally Arung Palakka as the most powerful ruler of the region. This ended Makasar involvement in the spice trade. The VOC kept the Makasar fortification Ujung Pandang for itself, turning it into Fort Rotterdam, and a Dutch quarter arose in its vicinity. From this situation, Makassar would gradually attain the character of a VOC colony, and would become a 'gouvernement' in the 18th century.

title: Makian
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The island of Makian in the North Molucca Islands had a good harbour and was well-planted with clove trees. In 1608 the VOC captured it from the Spanish and gave to the sultan of Ternate on condition that all the cloves should be supplied to the VOC. Here, as on the other islands of the Moluccas, the local population suffered under the violent measures used by the VOC to protect its trade monopoly. Illegally planted clove trees would be felled by VOC workers during so-called 'hongi raids', while supplying cloves to foreign merchants other than those of the VOC carried a heavy penalty.

title: Malang
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Malang, situated on Java's eastern point, was overrun by the VOC in 1767. Throughout the 18th century the VOC settlement was never manned by more than 20 people.

title: Maldah
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Malda, situated south east of Ragiamahal, produced fine 'lijnwaten' or cotton stuffs. The VOC abandoned its trading post here relatively quickly as it was beset by problems such as the poor relations with the local authorities and the substandard accommodation. In addition it transpired that the fine cotton stuffs could also be obtained in Hougly.

title: Malembo
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Malembo was een van de plaatsen aan de Angolese kust die de WIC in 1641 veroverde op de Portugezen. Het was tevens een van de laatste plaatsen aan de Angolakust die de WIC behield. Omdat de handel voor een lange tijd geen grote winsten opleverde, besloten de bewindhebbers van de WIC de handelspost in 1684 te sluiten. De handel (ivoor, koper, verfhout en slaven) werd vanaf dat moment direct vanaf de schepen gevoerd.

title: Mallakam
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The church in the village of Mallakam was never completed by the Portuguese, who established themselves on Ceylon prior to the arrival before the arrival of the VOC. After conquering the area in 1658 the Company finished it and turned it into a Protestant church. However, Protestantism failed to take root in the area: the congregation remained small and religious education in the local school was not very successful. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Malmesbury
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The writer O.F. Mentzel, who recorded the settlements at the Cape around the turn of the 18th century, called Zwartland the fifth district of the Cape. The area, whose name derived from its black earth, was situated above Land van Waveren and Groenecloof. The local church dates from 1745. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Malpa
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The land muster-rolls of 1700 refer to the small VOC outpost of Malca. Malca lay on the Malabar Coast, probably somewhere between Porca and Cranganore.

title: Malwanne
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Maltuane was situated on the Kelani River, north of Colombo. The Portuguese fort here was renovated following the conquest of the area by the Dutch. The land muster-rolls refer to the area as 'op Malwanne en in 's Comp: Pannebackerij'.

title: Mama (kreek)
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. By the late eighteenth century the area around this creek was cultivated.

title: Mamala
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC established a post in Mamala, on the northern coast of the island of Ambon, as early as 1601. The town boasted a pottery, and together with Hitulama was one of the most active trading centres in the Hitu region on the northern Ambon peninsula.

title: Manado
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. During the VOC era Manado, in northern Sulawesi, was a residence with a limited number of staff. Here the Dutch were plagued by problems with the Spanish. During the period that G. Maetsuycker was governor (1653-78) the VOC set up a trading post in Manado. Alongside a stone lodge the Company also built a massive redoubt by the name of Fort Amsterdam. The fort was built after 1657, when the Company was called in to do battle with the Spanish. Manado chiefly traded tortoiseshell.

title: Manapaar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Manapaar was one of the VOC settlements south of Tutucorin. It was rich in coral reefs and known for its pearl fishing.

title: Mandagetto
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Mangalore
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Mangalore lay 120 kilometres north of Cannanore. This town was situated on the border of the southern coastal strip of Malabar and the northern coastal strip of Canara. Following the Dutch conquest of the Malabar Coast the Dutch occupied the fort built here by the Portuguese. In 1722 the VOC constructed a new lodge. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Manicoorde
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Manicorde was one of the many small military outposts maintained by the VOC along the Malabar Coast. It was situated six miles south of the city of Cochin and was habitually staffed by a couple of VOC employees from Cochin. The VOC employees on the Malabar Coast were often of the Christian faith and hailed from the region between Cochin and Manicorde. They were taken on as soldiers and as messengers.

title: Manila
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Manipa
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. - Manipa was an island in front of the coast of Hoamoal (Western Seram), a clove-producing region, and under the control of the <kimelaha>, the leader of Hoamoal with whom the VOC was periodically in conflict. The mutual relations between the VOC and the inhabitants of the island were generally bad, and the island was the target of several Dutch military expeditions in the course of the 17th century. - Manipa was deliberately destroyed ecologically at the beginning of the Great Ambon War (1651-1656): in retaliation for the surprise attacks on VOC posts in March 1651, of which the one on Manipa was the most brutal, the island was turned into “an eternal wasteland” by cutting all the trees that were useful to the human population of the island. At the end of the war, the remaining inhabitants were forced to resettle around the Dutch fort Wantrouw on the south coast of the island.

title: Manipay
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Baldaeus, the Dutch preacher who headed the congregations of northern Ceylon between 1656 and 1665, regularly toured his parish. He described the people of Manipay as unfriendly with little enthusiasm for the Christian faith. In general the Company's clerical appointees were intended to ensure proper morals on merchant ships and at trading posts. In the first instance they were there to tend to the needs of the Company staff. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Mannar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC captured the island of Mannar in 1658. Mannar was one of the last Portuguese strongholds in Ceylon and the Portuguese put up a strong defence, but to no avail. The VOC secured the island and for the time being it ruled supreme in Ceylon, unchallenged by any of its European competitors. The island of Mannar lay close to the Indian coast. A visitor in 1658 called it an earthly paradise. The fort had every convenience; each of the soldiers had a young Ceylonese servant to look after his weaponry, and a woman to prepare his meals. The Company introduced Protestantism here. Mannar was a rich island. Particularly profitable was the trade in pearls which were plentiful in the waters around the island. Pearl fishing was organised on a major scale under the strict supervision of the VOC. In addition Mannar was a source of cotton and clothing, red textile dye, fish and elephants. The fort at Mannar played a key role in the defence of the sea route to India and the VOC's trading interests. Built by the Portuguese, the fort remained largely unchanged under the Company.

title: Mantota
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Mantota was situated between mainland Ceylon and the island of Manaar. VOC sources indicated that the area around Mantota was prosperous.

title: Mapane (kreek)
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. By the late eighteenth century, the area around this creek was cultivated.

title: Maparany
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Mapulegam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Mapulegam was situated north east of Galle in the Ceylonese interior. The town was a border post between the command past at Galle and the kingdom of Kandy. The VOC built a simple fort here to guard the border.

title: Maputo
variants: Maputo;Rio de Lagoa;Rio Delagoa;Lagoa;Rio de LaGoa;Rio de la goa
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1721 the VOC built a fort in Delagoa bay, on the River Maputa. This fort was named Lijdzaamheid, or 'Endurance', in 1726. It was intended as a base for gold and copper prospecting, but the region proved very unhealthy and there was a constant threat of pirates. In 1730 the fort was abandoned by the Company.

title: Marawila
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Marbongh
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Marechal Deodoro
variants: Marechal Deodoro;Alagoa do Sul;Allegoa do Sul;Vila S. Maria da Madalena
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Marichchukkaddi
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The land muster-rolls of 1725 and 1733 refer to a VOC station near the little town of Martikatte. This town must have been situated near Mentotte and Aripo, on Ceylon's western coast. It is not entirely certain whether the town corresponds with today's Marichchukkaddi.

title: Mariewoera (kreek)
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. By the late eighteenth century, the area around this creek was cultivated.

title: Maroantsetra
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1641 the VOC ordered an exploration of Madagascar and the surrounding islands, whereby setting up standards would claim them for the Company. A small base was established in the Bay of Antogil at the north east coast. The local ruler agreed to submit to the sovereignty of the Dutch Republic and to supply slaves. Trading posts were also set up in other places such as Fombetokke. However, the results were disappointing and in 1646 the VOC administrators in Batavia decided to withdraw their people from the island.

title: Maronda
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Maronda was a sea station east of Batavia. Today it is part of Jakarta.

title: Maros
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The region of Maros, through which a river runs by the same name, was situated in the southern Sulawesi interior, to the north of the city of Macassar. Maros was at the head of the kingdoms of Bonthain, Boela Comba and Bera. Around 370 native villages fell under the authority of Maros. The VOC occupied the region in 1668 following a conflict with the people of Macassar. The Company already had an outpost on the Maros River, guarded by a simple wooden fort. A resident had been appointed as vice merchant, and was charged with monitoring the area along with several soldiers.

title: Marowijne, rivier
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. This creek was explored in the second half of the seventeenth century and was considered to be the border between the French and Dutch colony.

title: Marshall kreek
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. By the late eighteenth century the area around this creek was already cultivated.

title: Martaban
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. According to the author Pieter van Dam, the VOC maintained a so-called 'comptoir' in Martavaan some 40 years before he embarked on his history of the Company, 'Beschryvinge van de Oostindische Compagnie'. This would date the settlement around 1660. However this trading post on the West Coast of Birma was soon abandoned due to a ban imposed by the local ruler.

title: Martinique
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. - Martinique was charted by Columbus in 1493, but Spain had little interest in the territory. It became a french territory in the 1635, in spite of a revolt of the indigenous Carib population the following year. Many early settlers were Huguenots, seeking greater religious freedom overseas, and as a consequence, the French crown briefly deported Huguenots who refused to convert here in the years 1686-1688. In spite of the Crown's efforts, it remained strongly Huguenot. - Martinique changed hands between the British and French several times during the Seven Years' War and the Napoleonic Wars, but it was ultimately traded back to France and remains a French overseas territory to this day.

title: Maspeth
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Gouverneur Willem Kieft, die naarstig op zoek was naar mensen die zich wilden vestigen in de omgeving van Nieuw-Amsterdam, gaf in 1642 de Engelse dominee Francis Doughty toestemming om een dorpje te stichten op het Lange Eiland, oftewel Long Island, dat viel onder Nederlands bewind. Dominee Doughty noemde het dorp Maspeth. Al een jaar na de stichting vielen Indianen het dorp aan. Zo kwam snel een einde aan het dorp Maspeth. Echter, negen jaar later probeerde een nieuwe Engelse groep het opnieuw. Zij noemden de plaats Middleburgh. Toen Engeland het hele gebied Nieuw-Nederland in 1664 overnam kreeg de plaats haar derde naam: Hastings. Maar de bewoners van het dorp zelf noemden de plaats Newtown. Het dorp is opgeslokt in de tegenwoordige wijk Queens.

title: Matapica (kreek en kust)
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. After 1757 several canals were dug in this area, after which the number of plantations substantially increased.

title: Matara
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Matara was a major bonded warehouse in southern Ceylon. The principal commodities were elephants and cinnamon. Elephants were captured by chasing them into a trap, from which they could be removed one by one and tied up. Subsequently the elephants would be baptised in accordance with Ceylonese custom. A wild elephant would be put in with tame ones. The elephants were sold to Indian rajahs who deployed them in times of war as living tanks. The VOC exercised territorial authority in Matara and could therefore levy taxes. A tightening of the tax regulations in 1760 sparked an uprising against the VOC by the local population. The rebels were aided by the king of Kandy, with whom the VOC had for some time been in conflict. The Company won the war, but suffered a great loss of prestige. For this reason a bigger fort was subsequently built in Matara.

title: Matricotta
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC's land muster-rolls for the year 1691 refer to the village of Matricotta, which lay on the Malabar Coast in the region of Castello and St. Andries. The latter-day location of this particular village is still unclear.

title: Matuaal
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Matuaal was a crossing point or ferry north of Colombo. Both Matuaal and Retaal are referred to interchangeably as a pass or ferry in the VOC land muster-rolls. The coast line has since shifted, so that present-day Mutwal is directly on the seashore.

title: Maurisstad
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In 1630, toen de Nederlanders het Braziliaanse eiland Antonio Vaz (een eiland dat gelegen was naast Recife en tegenwoordig een wijk is met de naam Santo Antonio) op de Portugezen veroverden, troffen zij er een klein bolwerk, een klooster en enkele huizen aan. Het klooster werd ingenomen en de Nederlanders besloten drie nieuwe forten te bouwen om Recife, dat nieuwe hoofdstad werd van Nederlands-Brazilië, beter te kunnen verdedigen tegen mogelijke aanvallen uit de Varzéa, de streek landinwaarts waar de meeste Portugezen naar toe waren gevlucht.Deze forten waren: fort Waardenburgh, fort Frederik Hendrick en fort Ernestus. Bij dit laatste fort werd het bestaande klooster van Santo Antonio geïncorporeerd. Omdat Recife langzamerhand overbevolkt raakte, werd er vanaf 1638 aan de uitbreiding van de stad op het nabijgelegen eiland gewerkt. Na de verwoesting van de nabijgelegen stad Olinda - de hoofdstad van de Portugezen -, werden de stenen en materialen van het afbreken hergebruikt om Mauritsstad op te richten, de nieuwe naam van het eiland Antonio Vaz. Men begon met het noordelijke gedeelte van het eiland. Er ontstonden grachten en kanalen, nieuwe straten, de eerste residentie voor de gouverneur Johan Maurits, de grote markt, het stadhuis, koopmanskantoren, magazijnen, een wapenhuis en kerken.
