description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Porto Calvo was een van de eerste Portugese nederzettingen in de tegenwoordige Braziliaanse staat Alagoas. Deze post was gelegen ten zuiden van Recife en Cabo de Santo Agostinho en ten noorden van Alagoa do Sul (nu Marechal Deodoro). Toen de Nederlanders in Porto Calvo in 1635 arriveerden, waren er zeven of acht engenhos, molens die suiker produceerden. De Portugezen hadden een jaar ervoor, in 1634, een groot fort gebouwd op een heuvel vlak bij het dorp, genaamd Povoacao, later Bom Sucesso ofwel Boaventura. Het fort werd in '35 veroverd en uitgebreid door de Nederlanders. In hetzelfde jaar nog zorgde de Portugees Mathias de Albuquerque ervoor dat het fort weer onder Portugees bestuur viel. Direct daarna werd een man met de naam Calabar, een mesties, gevangengenomen en terechtgesteld. Hij werd ervan beschuldigd zijn eigen volk te hebben verraden vanwege zijn vermeende hulp aan de Nederlanders.Het fort werd in 1637, met de komst van gouverneur Johan Maurits van Nassau, door de Nederlanders ingenomen en bleef onder controle van de West-Indische Compagnie tot 1645. In dat jaar heroverden de Portugezen Porto Calvo voor de tweede keer. Het fort werd verwoest en verlaten. Naast dit fort Bom Sucesso, was er volgens Nieuhoff een tweede fort in Porto Calvo, genaamd Igreja Nova ofwel Nieuwe Kerk, omdat het op de ruïnes van een kerk was gebouwd. Er is door de Nederlanders ook aan een derde fort gewerkt dat echter nooit voltooid werd. Niet ver van Porto Calvo ligt Uniao dos Palamares. Deze plaats raakte in de 17de eeuw bekend door de grote slavenopstand die hier en in het omringende gebied, dat nu Alagoas heet, uitbrak. Al vanaf het begin van de 17de eeuw ontstond in Uniao dos Palamares een van de grootste quilombos die er ooit in Brazilië hebben bestaan. Quilombos waren gemeenschappen gevormd door slaven die van de plantages langs de kust waren gevlucht en zich in het binnenland hadden verscholen. De reden dat Uniao dos Palamares tussen 1630 en 1654 uitgroeide tot een van de grootste quilombos had te maken met de oorlogen tussen de Portugezen en de Nederlanders die het hele gebied tot een grote chaos hadden gebracht. Na de Nederlandse capitulatie besloot de Portugese regering om het probleem van de gevluchte slaven definitief op te lossen. Dat was niet eenvoudig. Ondanks verschillende expedities die vanuit Recife, de hoofdstad van Pernambuco, werden gestuurd slaagde men er niet in Uniao dos Palmares te veroveren. Na 1670 werd de strijd van de slaven succesvol dankzij de charismatische persoonlijkheid van Zumbi, leider van de slavengemeenschap en van de oorlog tegen de Portugezen. In 1690 werden de Palmarinos, zoals deze slavengemeenschap genoemd werd, verslagen en Zumbi, hun leider, vermoord. Hiermee was de Portugese macht in Brazilië, na de herovering op de Nederlandse WIC van 1654, hersteld.

title: Porto Marie
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Porto Marie was the name of a fort on the southwest coast of Curaçao, built before 1774. Forts like these were built to protect the bays serving as natural harbours for the Dutch ships. Porto Marie would have been slightly north of the bay of St. Marie.

title: Portudal
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Portudal, ofwel Porto d'Ale, was een plaatsje aan de kust van het tegenwoordige Senegal, alwaar de Nederlanders in het midden van de 17de eeuw een factorij hadden. De factorij leverde de WIC ivoor en slaven, zij het niet in enorme hoeveelheden.

title: Pos Cabay
variants: Pos Cabay;bij St. Annabaai Poos Cabaai;St. Annabaai;Schottegat;Santa Annabaai
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Aan de oostelijke zijde van het Schottengat, de binnenbaai van de St. Annabaai, werd in 1634 het eerste Nederlandse legerkamp gebouwd op Curaçao. Het legerkamp werd 'het Retranchement' genoemd, maar hette ook wel 'het kamp bij de Vijgenboom'. Met de bouw van deze post konden de waterputten worden beschermd tegen aanvallen van indianen. De post, die werd gebouwd met gebruik van materialen uit Nederland, was bedoeld voor 200 manschappen. Omdat deze nooit arriveerden werd het fort in 1635 al weer gesloopt. In plaats van dit fort kwam een nieuwe fortificatie: Wilschutsborg.

title: Post aan de rivier Maningaar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Post aan de rivier Manumbagh
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Post aan den berg
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Preangerlanden
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In the lands around Preanger, on the southern coast of West Java, coffee cultivation was introduced around 1700. The soil was exceptionally suitable for growing coffee due to the favourable situation in the hills in the interior, the benign climate and the protection afforded against the sea winds. As with most of the other products in which the VOC traded, the Company left the cultivation of the coffee to the local population. The Javanese rulers were required to ensure that their subjects grew coffee beans. The VOC monitored and controlled the cultivation of the beans and the quality of the crops by using self-appointed 'coffee sergeants'. In a series of treaties concluded with the sultanate of Mataram, agreements about the supply of products were made in 1705.

title: Pretoria
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Prince's Island
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Fort Wilhelmus werd in 1625 of 1626 gebouwd door Waalse kolonisten op een eiland dat Prinseneiland of Moordenaarseiland werd genoemd. Deze eilanden komen niet voor op contemporaine kaarten, maar er is wel een kaart bekend waarop de Delaware Rivier als de 'Willems Rivier' wordt aangeduid. De locatie van het fort is niet bekend. Wel weet men dat het fort werd bezet door 16 man die de doorvaart over de Delaware Rivier moesten controleren, daardoor neemt men aan dat het fort vermoedelijk aan de monding van de rivier lag.

title: Princes Town
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In 1725 veroverde de WIC het fort van de eigenaar John Conny, opperhoofd van de Ahanta. Het fort werd door de Nederlanders 'Fort Hollandia' genaamd en lag ongeveer vijf kilometer ten oosten van fort St. Antonio in Axim. John Conny had het fort ongeveer acht jaar in bezit gehad. Hij had het, op zijn beurt, in 1717 overgenomen van de Brandenburg Compagnie. Deze Duitse compagnie stichtte de vestiging in 1683. De Duitsers noemden hun fort, de enige grote Duitse vestiging aan de Goudkust, Gross Friedrichsburg.

title: Principe
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Balthazar de Moucheron organiseerde in 1598 een vloot van vijf schepen, onder leiding van Joris van Spilbergen, Julius Cleerhagen, Gerard Strijbosch en Cornelis de Moucheron. Dit deed hij in samenwerking met de Staten-Generaal. Het doel was om met deze vloot het eiland Principe, dat voor de kust van Gabon ligt, te veroveren en om er een verversingsstation op te richten voor de schepen op weg naar Indië. Dit lukte. Op 10 augustus 1598 werd het eiland zonder problemen veroverd. Maar de Nederlanders verbleven er niet lang: de eilandbewoners riepen hulp in van troepen van het eiland São Thomé om de Hollanders te verdrijven. Principe werd voor een tweede maal in 1641 door de Nederlanders bezet.

title: Prins Willem Frederick
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Province Island (?)
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. De Nederlandse handelspost die Arent Corssens in 1633 bouwde, was eerder een eenvoudig onderkomen dan een permanente post. Deze post lag aan een rivier die de Nederlanders Schuykill noemden. De post werd door de Zweden afgebroken en zij bouwden er een fort dat zij fort Nya Korsholm noemden. Echter in 1655 namen de Nederlanders het fort weer over. Tegenwoordig denkt men dat het fort ooit gelegen zou kunnen hebben op Province Island.

title: Puger
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The land muster-rolls of 1770 refer to the VOC outpost of Poeger. In that year 69 VOC employees were stationed there. Poeger fell under the 'Java's northern coast' district, which in 1770 numbered 1849 people in the service of the VOC.

title: Pulicat
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. During the first decades of the 17th century the Dutch tried to create new possibilities for trade on the Coromandel Coast. The main reason was the tremendous demand for Pulicat textiles in the Moluccas. In 1610 Pulicat became the principal base on the Coromandel Coast, grouping a number of sub-trading stations. Together these trading stations formed a cartel, cutting out Portuguese competition and the local rulers. During the first half of the 17th century the VOC became increasingly involved in the endless civil wars surrounding the succession to the throne in this area. After some initial friction with the local authorities at Pulicat the Company gained permission to establish a fort. According to the treaty the local ruler would finance construction work and become part owner of the fort. However, work proceeded slowly and the VOC was forced to pay the costs itself. The town flourished under the Company's strict neutrality during wartime and under the protection the fort offered the population. The VOC's presence on the Coromandel Coast was primarily motivated by the many kinds of cotton fabric that were cheaply available. These textiles were highly prized in the Moluccas for the manufacture of garments and could be profitably exchanged there for spices. Pulicat was the most important centre of the textile trade on the coast. The VOC enjoyed various privileges in Pulicat, which enabled it to control textile production. The local manufacturers were only allowed to produce fabrics ordered by the Company. The VOC rapidly managed to acquire a trade monopoly in Pulicat. From 1610 Pulicat housed the VOC headquarters for the Coromandel Coast. In 1687 the governor relocated to Negapatnam. After the English captured Nagappattinam in 1781 the governors of Coromandel returned to Pulicat. In 1795 Pulicat fell to the English too.

title: Pulopallai
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Puloppalai was home to one of the VOC churches. Throughout the 17th century the Company was in a constant state of war with the king of Ceylon. Because of the proximity of the frontier with the king's territory the church was built more in the fashion of a fort. To the right was a building housing a school. Puloppalai provided wood for export. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Punneikayal
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The Company decided to set up a trading base in Ponnekayl, a source of superb pearls. Although the pearl divers were not employed by the Company, they were required to sell their pearls to the VOC.

title: Punta de Araya
variants: Punta de Araya;Punta de Araya;Punta Araya
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Vanaf het einde van de 16de eeuw voeren Nederlandse schepen naar de kust van het huidige Venezuela in Zuid-Amerika, op zoek naar zout. Zout was in die tijd een belangrijk product, zeker voor de Republiek, die haar welvaart voor een groot deel aan de haringvisserij had te danken. Toen Spanje in 1580, tijdens de tachtigjarige oorlog, Portugal bezette, werd het voor de Nederlandse kooplieden steeds moeilijker om aan de hoge kwaliteit zout uit de Portugese plaats Setubal te komen. De ontdekking van de zoutpannen van Punta de Araya, een schiereiland gelegen tussen de stad Cumana en het eiland Margarita in Zuid-Amerika, maakte het zeer voor de Nederlndse handelaars aantrekkelijk om daar zelf voet aan wal te gaan zetten. Voor de komst van de Nederlanders werd het schiereiland al door de Spanjaarden geëxploiteerd, meer voor de parels dan voor het zout. Het duurde niet lang eer de Nederlanders ook hier problemen met de Spanjaarden kregen. Zij bouwden daarom kleine tijdelijke veldschansen in de direkte omgeving. Na 1609 ving een korte periode van rust aan. Toen de Nederlanders, na het aflopen van het 12-jarig Bestand bij Punta de Arraya terugkwamen, waren de Spanjaarden al meester van het gebied dat zij nu beschermden met een grote vesting: Santiago de Arroyo.

title: Purakkad
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Porca, slightly to the north of Kayankulam, fell under the aegis of the king of Cochin. The latter-day name of the village is Purakkad. Porca was originally a British trading post that was captured by the Dutch in 1666. The VOC finally succeeded in clinching a friendship treaty with the rajah of Porca in 1724. The Company subsequently built a stone lodge and a storage depot for pepper. Just as in Ponnani, the VOC appointed a resident here. The Dutch controlled the pepper monopoly from Porca to Cranganore.

title: Purmenent
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Purmerend was a small island in the Bay of Batavia, situated near to the islands of Onrust and Cuijper. The tiny island was home to leprosy sufferers, for whom a leper hospital had been built.

title: Purwakarta
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Kraton (palace) Pleret was built to fulfill the wish of Susuhunan Amangkurat I (1646-1677), who did not want to stay at his late father's (Sultan Agung, 1613-1646) former palace. Amangkurat I moved his new palace Purarya (Pleret) in 1647. In 1674 prince Trunanjaya revolted against Amangkurat I, who was forced to flee from his craton Pleret was ransacked The Sunan's two sons also joined their father. The second son, prince Puger, succeeded to regain Pleret. He crowned himself as King of Mataram. The result was a war with his elder brother Anom (Sunan Amangkurat II) in Kartasura, who with support of the VOC defeated Puger. Kartasura became the capital of the kingdom Mataram. Craton Plered was abandoned.

title: Puttalam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Puttalam was situated on the West Coast of Ceylon, north of Colombo. It became a well-known harbour town during the Portuguese era. When the Dutch came to Ceylon they sought permission to trade from the King of Kandy, who controlled the port. Puttalam functioned as an entropot for areca nut, a crop farmed by the King of Kandy's subjects. The wares were transported to the Indian coast via Kalpitiya. Puttalam was also a point of distribution for the Indian materials and textiles that were sold in Ceylon.

title: Putur
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Putur was home to one of the VOC churches. The VOC pledged to protect only those local inhabitants who converted to Protestantism. This led many Ceylonese to attend Company schools and churches. But often they were Christian in name only. Those who could recite The Lord's Prayer, the Ten Commandments and the Articles of Faith was considered a convert. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Qeshm
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Kismis, now known as Queshm, functioned as the grain store for the town of Gamron (now Bandar Abbas). In 1645 the Company attempted unsuccessfully to capture the fort. The VOC wanted to use it to extract trading concessions from Persia and to protect Gamron. A second attempt in 1684 was successful in capturing the stronghold.

title: Quelimanie
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Quilon
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. On 9 December 1658 a VOC force led by Rijcklof van Goens attempted to capture the town of Quilon from the Portuguese. The local queen ordered her subjects to resist because there seemed little to be gained from the VOC's aggressive trading activities. Van Goens finally succeeded in 1661: Quilon was conquered and the queen's palace was burned to the ground. After the VOC's capture of Quilon 480 soldiers were garrisoned there. One of their tasks was to act to the detriment of Portuguese possessions in Bombay. Quilon's played an important trade role as a supplier of pepper and pearls.

title: Raha
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Raiebaagh
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post, though the 'Generale missiven' mention the presence of an 'onderkoopman' (junior merchant) in 1641.

title: Rajbagh
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Rajmahal
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Ragiamahol was situated on the shores of the Ganges in northern Bengal. Up to and including 1710 the VOC silver was minted into Bengali coin - the carimabad or siccarupiah - in Ragiamahol. The British maintained a presence here from 1750 onwards. Silver was one of the VOC's key import products in India.

title: Rama
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Rarakit
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Rarakit was a settlement in Eastern Seram, outside the sphere of influence of the VOC in the 17th century. The VOC considered Rarakit, along with several other settlements in Eastern Seram, to pirates' nests, serving as both a refuge for clove smugglers and a staging area for possible raids on the Banda islands. The VOC attacked and destroyed Rarakit in 1649.

title: Recife Antigo
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In de tijd dat Olinda de hoofdstad van Portugees Pernambuco was, was Recife een klein dorpje waar enkele vissers leefden en werkten. Het dorp lag op een smal schiereiland, gescheiden van Olinda door het water. Nadat de Nederlanders in 1630 Olinda op de Portugezen hadden veroverd, werd Recife vrij snel als centrum van Nederlands-Brazilië aangewezen door haar gunstige ligging. Het reeds aanwezige verdedigingsysteem kon makkelijk uitgebreid kon worden. Recife werd de hoofdstad en het handelscentrum van Nederlands-Brazilië, waar behalve de haven ook de administratieve en religieuze gebouwen van het koloniale bestuur gevestigd waren. In de omgeving werden verschillende nieuwe forten gebouwd en oude forten uit de Portugese tijd werden grondig versterkt of herbouwd. Bij de ingang van de haven bouwde men fort de Bruyne (Fort do Brum) en fort do Buraco. Andere forten waren fort St. George, het Waterkasteel en fort Waardenburgh, ook bekend als fort Driehoek, dat in 1630 gesticht werd. In 1639 waren er in Recife al 2000 huizen. Door de schaarste aan ruimte werden de huizen gebouwd zoals in Nederland, met twee of meer verdiepingen en hoge gevels. Tijdens het bewind van gouverneur Johan Maurits van Nassau werden er nieuwe regels toegepast om de woonomstandigheden in de stad te verbeteren. Toch was dit niet genoeg. De enige oplossing bleef de stichting van een nieuwe stad. Voor dit doel werd het nabijgelegen eiland Antonio Vaz gekozen. Wat is overgebleven van het oude Recife is nu te vinden in de centrale wijk (Recife Antigo) van de hoofdstad van de Braziliaanse staat Pernambuco. Er zijn nog enkele gebouwen uit de Nederlandse tijd zoals de oudste synagoge van Amerika, tegenwoordig een museum. In 1654, het jaar van de Nederlandse capitulatie, viel Recife samen met Mauritsstad in de handen van de Portugezen.

title: Rembang
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1680 the VOC set up a trading post in Rembang, primarily in order to buy up wood. The extensive forests in the area were a source of wood highly suitable for export to Batavia where it was used in housing construction and for shipbuilding on the island of Onrust. In the early 18th century, the timber trade resulted in large-scale deforestation.

title: Rensselaer
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Rensselaerswijck was een kolonie gesticht door diamanthandelaar en bewindhebber van de WIC-kamer Amsterdam, Kiliaen van Rensselaer. Deze man, die het land kocht van de Mahican Indianen, is zelf nooit in Amerika geweest.. De kolonie, in dit geval een patroonschap, werd rond 1638 gesticht iets ten oosten van fort Oranje aan de Hudson rivier. Rensselaerswijck was al in 1660 uitgegroeid tot een welvarend dorp. Er woonden zo'n 200 mensen. Dergelijke patroonschappen werden door de WIC verleend aan eigenaren van land, vergelijkbaar met plantagehouders. (Met het verschil dat een plantage meestal uit één hoofdhuishouden bestaat en een patroonschap uit veel meer huishoudens.)Peter Stuyvesant had moeite met deze zelfstandige kolonie. Na enig geharrewar over de plaatselijke autoriteit, claimde hij een door de kolonie gebouwd dorpje in de directe omgeving van fort Oranje als officieel WIC-territorium en noemde dat Beverwijck (nu Albany).

title: Republiek
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Restinga island
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In de monding van de tegenwoordig in Brazilië gelegen rivier Paraiba, ten noorden van de nederzetting Filipea (Frederiksstad) hadden de Portugezen op een klein eiland een fort gebouwd om stad van mogelijke aanvallen vanuit de zee te verdedigen. Dit kleine fort maakte samen met de andere twee forten bij Cabedelo, Margaretha en S. Antonio, deel uit een verdedigingsdriehoek waar de rivier Paraiba uitmondt in de Atlantische Oceaan. Toen het kleine fort overgenomen werd door de Nederlanders in 1634, liet Johan Maurits van Nassau, gouverneur van Nederlands-Brazilië, de vestiging door palissaden omringen.

title: Rio Formoso
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Aan de Braziliaanse rivier Rio Formoso, ten zuiden van Cabo de Santo Agostinho, werd in 1633 door de Nederlanders een fort gebouwd, waarschijnlijk droeg het de naam fort Oranje. De Nederlanders hadden tussen 1632 en 1631 geprobeerd deze streek onder controle te krijgen, echter zonder succes. In 1633 lukte het de WIC om een Portugese versterking in te nemen en zich daar te vestigen om de toegang tot het gebied Arraial de Bom Jesus, waar het hoofdkwartier van de Portugese guerrilla gevestigd was, af te snijden. Zo werd het binnendringen in de vlakte van Varzea vergemakkelijkt. De Varzea was het meeste rijke gebied van de hele capitania (provincie) van Pernambuco.

title: Riviersonderend
variants: Riviersonderend;Revier Sonder Eind;Revier sonder End;Revier Sonder Endt;Revier Sonder Eynde;Rivier Sonder Eind;Rivier Sonder End;Rivier Sonder Eijnd;Rivier zonder eint
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. This river, which carries the same name to this day, was so called because it fed into the Breederivier and thus never came to an end. During the 18th century free burghers settled in the smaller VOC posts such as 't Ziekenhuis, Tijgerhoek and Zoetemelks Valleij. The Company's land muster-rolls fail to record these posts separately. In this region, which supplied the Company with wood and livestock, there were two Koina tribes: the Chainouqua in the west and the Hesseuqa in the east.

title: Road Town
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Robbeneiland
parent_name: Robben Island; Cape of Good Hope (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Robben Island lies at the mouth of Cape Town's Table Bay. In the 17th century it was used by the VOC as a signalling post for approaching ships. There was also a military post. Robben Island also served to shelter from the wind those vessels lying at anchor in Table Bay. In the months of April to October, when the wind blew from the north-west, the area became extremely hazardous for shipping.

title: Roma
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Roma was the name of a small island situated northeast of the island of Timor. The VOC set up sentry posts on most of the islands east of Timor, the majority of which were manned by three soldiers.

title: Rotterdam
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Rozengain
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The Bandanese island of Rozengain was in VOC possession from 1621.Around 1627 it was decided to concentrate the cultivation of Nutmeg on the islands of Banda Lontar, Ai and Bandaneira. Around 1634 the nutmeg trees on Rozengian were cut and the inhabitants were forced to move to one of the other Banda Islands. Until well into the 19th century, the island was used as a destination for convicted criminals, who were deported to the islands and forced to work in chain gangs in the djati forests as lumberjacks, or in the lime kilns or brickyards. For good reason Rozengain was also called 'Bandit Island.'

title: Rufisque
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Rufisque, ofwel Rio Fresco gelegen, werd rond 1678 tegelijkertijd met andere plaatsen in Senegal zoals Portudal en Joal, door de Fransen veroverd op de Nederlanders. Ook Arguin, een klein eiland gelegen in de gelijknamige baai aan de kust van Mauritanië, namen de Fransen over. Hierdoor nam de WIC-handel in Arabische gom, bezoarstenen, grijze amber en struisvogelveren af. Nadat de Fransen het gebied hadden overgenomen, probeerden de Nederlanders hun macht aan de Senegalese kust te herstellen. Echter de Fransman Jean Ducasse, leider van de Franse 'Compagnie du Senegal', sloot verbonden met de plaatselijke machthebbers om te voorkomen dat de Nederlanders weer voet aan wal konden zetten. Alle Nederlandse handelsposten in Senegal werden verwoest.

title: Run
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Run was one of the five Bandanese nutmeg islands. In 1616 it became an English colony. In 1621, the VOC took possession of Run without English permission. Around 1627, the VOC decided to concentrate the cultivation of nutmeg on the islands of Banda Lontar, Ai and Banda Neira. Run was rendered uninhabitable and all the mutmeg trees were cut down. De population was forced to leave. From 1629 the island was virtually uninhabited. In 1654 England and the Dutch Republic signed the Treaty of Amboyna, in which it was arranged that the VOC should cede the island back to the English. The acutal transfer took place in 1665. Because of the outbreak of the Second Anglo-Dutch War, Run was retaken by the VOC in that same year. In the Peace of Breda in 1667 Run, along with Surinam, was ceded to the Dutch, in exchange for, among others, New Amsterdam, which is present-day New York.

title: Ruwanwella
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In order to improve VOC control over the hinterland of Colombo, on which it depended for its supply of cinnamon, the company built a string of forts along the River Kelani. Ruanelle was one of these forts. It lay in the heart of the jungle and was difficult to reach. The post was abandoned soon after it was built. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: S. Luzia
variants: S. Luzia;St. Losie;St. Lucie;St. Louis;Se. Luce
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Saccam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. On the Taiwanese mainland, across from the sandbank where the VOC built fort Zeelandia in 1624, a Chinese-Dutch settlement soon developed. Its name, Saccam, probably derives from the language of the Siraya, the aboriginal group inhabiting this area. When the Chinese under VOC rule revolted in 1652, Saccam was partly destroyed in the revolt. For this reason Fort Provintia was built in the settlement in 1653. - When the Chinese warlord Koxinga invaded Taiwan in late April 1661, Saccam was the first settlement he conquered. After he succeeded in driving the VOC off Taiwan, Saccam would become the capital of the Tungning kingdom founded by him.

title: Sadian bon Porte
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source. See Nationaal Archief, Den Haag, inv. nr. VEL0321.

title: Sadras
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The Company opened an office in Sadras because of the high quality of the cotton fabrics manufactured there. The town's claim to fame was the extreme care with which the textiles were dyed. Another major factor was the wide of variety of rough and polished stone the VOC was able to buy here to build houses in Batavia and Ceylon.

title: Said
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC built a wooden guard post in Ceith, a small village on the northwestern coast of the island of Ambon, in 1656. At the time there were plans to further reinforce the guard post and to construct a building of stone. The redoubt of Zondernaam, a half-hour's walk away, also fell under Ceith.

title: Saint Lucia
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. This Caribbean Island was a French colony through most of the early modern age, although the English also conquered and occupied the island for several brief periods.

title: Saint Martin
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. - The Dutch first began to ply Saint Martin's ponds for salt in the 1620s. Despite the Dutch presence on the island, the Spaniards recaptured it in 1633. One year later, they built a fort (now Fort Amsterdam, near Philipsburg) and another artillery battery at Pointe Blanche to assert their claim and control access to Great Bay salt pond. A massive influx of African slaves took place in the 18th century with the development of sugarcane plantations by the French and Dutch.

title: Saint-Barthélemy
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The island Saint-Barthélemy was named by Columbus, after his brother Bartolomeo. Colonized by the French in 1648, it was then abandoned, ceded to the Knights Hospitaller, repurchased in 1665. In 1783 it was ceded to Sweden, and remaind a Swedish colony unitl 1878, when France repurchased it once more.

title: Salatiga
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Salatiga was a town situated in the Javanese interior, between Oenarang and Carta Soura. In Salatiga, which at the time was larger and more densely populated than Oenarang, farming was the most important economic activity. It was here the VOC built the fort 'de Herstelling' or 'Hersteller'. From 1765 onwards around 25 to 30 VOC employees were stationed at Salatiga.

title: Salayar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Saleyer was an elongated island separated from the southern Sulawesi peninsula by the Saleyer Strait. This island was traditionally subject to the king of Ternate, but subsequently came under the Company's authority. Saleyer was known for its forests and its cotton growing. The VOC built a fort there by the name of Defensie. Following the conquest of Maccassar in 1667 the VOC forbade other merchants to trade east of Saleijer.

title: Saldanha
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1652 the political Council of the Cape decided to commission an investigation of the area comprising St. Helena Bay, Saldanha Bay and nearby rivers and islands. The Company wanted to see whether the regions could be profitably exploited. If possible the Company wanted to engage in barter with the Koina tribe. Because the entire western coast north of the Cape fell outside the Company's charter, it could be claimed by the WIC or by other European powers. Eventually the Company founded a post at Saldanha Bay to repair VOC vessels and to avert a possible enemy threat. Thanks to the situation of its bay, Saldanha was a good anchorage for the Company's vessels. The post also played a key role in the supply of refreshments for VOC ships en route to the east. It supplied the vessels with fish, meat and vegetables. Until 1700 this outpost represented the northernmost borderpoint of the Cape colony. After 1795 it fell under the control of the British.

title: Salouky
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Saluku was situated just south of Lusiela, on the east coast of Hoamoal (Western Seram), a clove-producing region ruled by the <kimelaha>, the leader of Hoamoal with whom the VOC was periodically in conflict. . At the end of the Great Ambon War (1651-1656), the entire peninsula was depopulated, and the people living there forced to relocate.

title: Salvador
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. De WIC richtte al snel na het oprichtingsjaar 1621 haar krachten op de Portugese kolonie Brazilië en in het bijzonder op de stad Bahia, het centrum van deze kolonie. De Portugezen maakten enige tijd veel winst dankzij de productie van suiker. Deze winsten waren mogelijk door hun monopolie op de slavenhandel. Slaven waren immers de werkkrachten van de grote suikerplantages. Een eerste WIC-aanval op Bahia werd in 1624 gepleegd. Maar na een kortdurend succes werden de Nederlanders al weer na een jaar door de Spaans-Portugese macht uit Bahia verdreven. De WIC besloot niet direct op te geven. Na Piet Heins verovering van 'de Zilvervloot' vond een tweede aanval op Brazilië plaats. In 1630 werd het duidelijk dat de beste kansen voor succes niet in en om Bahia zouden liggen, maar bij het centrum van de suikerproductie, de regio Pernambuco in het noordoosten van de kolonie. Toch werd er in 1638, onder leiding van de nieuwe gouverneur Johan Maurits, opnieuw richting Bahia gemarcheerd. De meeste Portugezen waren na de veroveringstochten van Maurits hier naar toe gevlucht. Hun verzet tegen de WIC werd vanuit Bahia georganiseerd. Hoewel de forten buiten de stad in Nederlandse handen vielen (zoals de forten St. Alberto, S. Filipe en S.Bartolomeu), lukte het Johan Maurits niet om de stad Bahia te bezetten, de troepen trokken zich terug. Vanaf dit moment werden er nog verschillende pogingen gedaan, maar Bahia bleef onder Portugese controle. In 1646 werd het eiland Itaparica in de Bahia de Todos os Santos (Allerheiligenbaai) veroverd met de bedoeling de Portugese scheepvaart vanuit Salvador te belemmeren. Het was geen succes en een jaar later werd het eiland definitief ontruimd.

title: Sampora
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The land muster-rolls of the VOC refer to an outpost by the name of Sampora. At various points Sampora is mentioned almost synonymously with Tangerang.

title: San Juan
variants: San Juan;San Juan;Puerto Rico;Porto Rico;S. Ian de Porto Rico
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Het eiland Puertorico vormde voor de Spanjaarden een steunpunt voor hun handel en vaart in het Caribisch gebied. Sinds de 16de eeuw hadden zij zich op het eiland gevestigd met als hoofdkwartier de nederzetting San Juan. Om de baai van San Juan te verdedigen hadden de Spanjaarden verschillende forten gebouwd, waarvan het grootste fort San Felipe del Morro was. Sinds de oprichting van deze versterking toonde de WIC interesse om zich meester van het eiland Puertorico te maken. Dit is nooit echt gelukt. Alleen in 1625 lukte het de Nederlander Hendricksz. om het fortje Canuela te veroveren, maar niet het grootste fort, S. Felipe del Morro, dat daar tegenover lag. Het beleg duurde niet lang. In november moest Hendricksz. de strijd opgeven. Na deze mislukte poging werden de forten en de stad van San Juan door de Spanjaarden versterkt om zich tegen de komende aanvallen beter te kunnen verdedigen.

title: Sanana
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Sanana, or Sulabessie, was the most densely populated of the Sula Islands. The strategic importance of its fort, Fort Claverblad, was probably tied up with the VOC's attempt to secure a monopoly of the clove trade on the Moluccas. It is unclear whether the VOC ever established a permanent base at the fort, which was later rebuilt and renamed 'De Verwachting'.

title: Santa Luzia do Norte
variants: Santa Luzia do Norte;Allegoa do Norte;Alagoa do Norte
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In het zuiden van het Portugees-Braziliaanse gewest Pernambuco, de streek waar twee grote lagunes (as lagoas ofwel Alagoas) lagen, waren twee dorpen in Portugees bezit. Het ene dorp, aan de noordelijke lagune, was Alagoa do Norte, het andere dorp lag aan de zuidelijke lagune en droeg de naam Alagoa do Sul. De twee dorpen waren strategisch gelegen op de kustroute tussen Recife en de zuidelijke grens, de rivier São Francisco. In Alagoa do Norte stonden slechts drie engenhos (suikermolens), de regio was vooral van belang voor de WIC vanwege de aanvoer van vee en mandioca (maniok), een radijssoort waarvan meel gemaakt werd. Dit meel is nog steeds het basisingrediënt van het dagelijkse voedsel in Brazilië. Toen de Nederlanders in 1633 in Alagoas kwamen, vielen zij Alagoa do Norte binnen. Tegen alle verwachtingen in verzette de bevolking van de nederzetting zich hardnekkig tegen de nieuwkomers. In 1637, het jaar waarin het hele zuidelijke gebied van Pernambuco (tegenwoordig de staat Alagoas) door Johan Maurits van Nassau onder controle van de WIC gebracht werd, kwam ook Alagoa in Nederlandse handen.

title: Sao Luís
variants: Sao Luís;Sao Luis;Sao Luis do Maranhao;Maranhao;Marinhao;S. Luis do Maranhao;Maragnon
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Na de verovering van Loanda en het eiland São Tomé in Afrika, besloot Johan Maurits van Nassau, gouverneur van Nederlands-Brazilië, het Portugese eiland Maranhao in het noorden van Brazilië aan te vallen. Volgens Barlaeus, die tussen 1654 en 1664 Nederlands-Brazilië beschreef, waren er toen de Nederlanders voet aan wal zetten slechts zes bruikbare engenhos en drie indianendorpen. Engenho is de Portugese naam voor de molens waar suikerriet (cana de acucar) tot suiker werd verwerkt. Op het eiland lag ook een fort, genaamd São Luis do Maranhao. Honderden slaven die uit Afrika waren gehaald, werkten dag en nacht op deze suikermolens. Het suikerriet werd massaal op de grote plantages in Zuid-Amerika en op de Antillen verbouwd. Het eiland Maranhao bleef drie jaar lang onder Nederlands bestuur, in 1644 werd het opnieuw veroverd door de Portugezen. Maranhao was het laatste gewest in Brazilië dat onder Nederlands gezag raakte. Tussen 1641 en 1644 bereikte het Nederlands Braziliaanse territorium zijn maximale omvang: het strekte zich uit van Maranhao in het noorden tot Sergipe del Rey in het zuiden.

title: Saparua eiland
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Fort Duurstede was built on the island of Saparua in 1691. Fort Hollandia, situated a little further south, was the first fort on the island. After a devastating earthquake in 1671, the fort was not rebuilt. There would appear to have been a trading post on the island since 1645, from which cloves were exported.

title: Saramacca Rivier
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. This river originates in the Wilhelmina Mountains and flows north from there to meet the Coppename river, which flow out to sea together. Although the Surinam plantation economy first concentrated around the Surinam and Commewijne Rivers, it extended to the Saramacca River as well in the course of the 18th century.

title: Save
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. De Nederlanders hadden, in het begin van de 18de eeuw, een klein kantoor in Savi, een plaats gelegen in het achterland van de Slavenkust. Het kantoor, zeer minimalistisch van opzet, zeker in vergelijking met de kantoren van de Fransen en de Engelsen, was gelegen naast het koninklijke paleis van Savi.

title: Savonette
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Sawaij
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Saway, situated on the bay of the same name on Ceram's northern coast, was the first Dutch settlement to be established on this coast. Establishing a presence in the north and east of Ceram was less important to the Company than acquiring a foothold on the other islands which made up Ambon (the central and southern Moluccas). The outpost at Saway comprised a simple building surrounded by a stockade, a wooden perimeter fence. By 1788 or thereabouts the Company had fortified this settlement, which also boasted a stone powder magazine, with an additional 44 men.

title: Scarborough
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In 1654 vestigde zich een groep Koerlanders, genoemd naar hun aanvoerder de hertog van Koerland op Tobago. In datzelfde jaar stichtte de WIC een nieuwe kolonie aan de andere kant van het eiland, aan de Lampsinsbaai, ofwel Rockly Bay. Op een hoge heuvel bouwden de Nederlandse kolonisten het fort Lampsinsberg. Het fort had vier bastions, enkele barakken, een arsenaal en een gouverneurshuis. Onder aan de heuvel lag Lampsinstad. Naast het fort Lampsingsberg werd al snel door de Nederlanders een tweede, wat kleiner fort gebouwd, 'het fort van de Lampsins'. Het lag aan de zuidkant van het eiland maar de exacte locatie is niet duidelijk. Later, tijdens de expeditie van de Nederlander Jacob Binckes in 1676, werden er nieuwe forten op Tobago opgericht. De bedoeling van deze nieuwe expeditie was het eiland als handelscentrum te versterken en te koloniseren. Een nieuw fort, Sterreschans, werd gebouwd. Daarnaast, recht voor het fort op de heuvel, plaatste men nog een kleiner bolwerk met zicht op de baai. Het nieuwe fort Sterreschans was gelegen aan de Klipbaai, ofwel Rockly Bay, nabij het oude fort van Lampsins. Het was bemand met 480 mensen en had 23 kannonen. In 1677, toen de Fransen het eiland definitief veroverden, werd Sterreschans opgeblazen. Bickens en 250 van zijn mannen kwamen om het leven.

title: Seekoeivlei
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC outpost of Rietveld was also known as Zeekoe Valleij. It lay east of Sandvlei, on the False Bay coast. The outpost mainly offered work to farm labourers. In 1751 they were given an additional task: to report those people carrying weapons. This was because the wild animals on the Cape Flats needed to be protected. Slaves with weapons had to be imprisoned, for otherwise they could learn to become self-supporting by hunting.

title: Sekondi
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Na een aantal jaar van Nederlandse aanwezigheid, bouwden de Nederlanders in het plaatsje Sacunde hun fort Oranje. De WIC vestigde zich rond 1670 in het 'goudgebied'. In 1694 vielen de plaatselijke Ahanti het fort aan. Zij namen het fort in en vernietigden het zodanig dat het door de Nederlanders opnieuw opgebouwd moest worden. Met de economische situatie van de WIC was het in Sacunde niet verbijsterend goed gesteld. Rapporten tonen aan dat tussen 1705 en 1716 weinig goud werd geëxporteerd en dat slechts 151 slaven werden verhandeld. In 1872 ging het fort over naar de Engelsen.

title: Semarang
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. - In 1705 the king of Mataram ceded sovereignty over the Preanger territories, Semarang and Cheribon to the Company. In Semarang the Company encouraged the cultivation of indigo, which was used as a dyestuff. The local ruler declared his willingness to invest in indigo production, and soon delivered the first shipments. Growers continued to produce indigo, even when the price fell drastically as a result of oversupply. - In 1708 the headquarters of the VOC on the north-eastern coast of Java was relocated to Semarang from Japara. In 1748 the 'opperhoofd' or supervisor in Semarang was named governor of the north-east coast of Java. - The city was divided into four parts: the Javanese settlement with the big mosque, markets and the house of the regent on the west bank of Kali Semarang, the Malay settlement on the east bank, the Chinese settlement opposite the Javanese settlement on the east bank and the Dutch settlement with the fort north of the Chinese settlement.

title: Senya Beraku
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In de aan de Goudkust gelegen plaats Senya Beraku werd in 1667 een loge gebouwd door de Nederlandse WIC-dienaren. Daarmee startte een langdurige relatie met de bewoners van het gebied Agona. In 1705 werd begonnen met de bouw van een fort. Door de hoop op een bloeiende handel in goud, ivoor en slaven gaven de Nederlanders het fort de naam 'De Goede Hoop'. De naam werd bewaarheid: de handel in slaven werd zeer omvangrijk door de talloze oorlogen in de regio. Deze conflicten leverden zoveel slaven op, dat het fort te klein bleek voor de verwerking ervan. In 1816 werd het fort verlaten.

title: Seram Laut
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. In 1633, Artus Gijsels, the governor of Ambon, first organised a military expedition to Seram Laut, as part of the 'illicit' clove trade had apparently moved to this island, and it also served as a base for raids on Banda. During this expedition, the population of Seram Laut surrendered, in spite of their fortifications which the attacking VOC forces found daunting, and declared themselves to be vassals of the VOC. Even so, conflict between the inhabitants of Seram Laut and the VOC would recur throughout subsequent decades.

title: Sergipe del Rey
variants: Sergipe del Rey;Sergipe del Rey;Sao Cristovao
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Na een korte verovering van de regio Sergipe del Rey, ten zuiden van de Rio São Francisco, lukte het gouverneur Johan Maurits en zijn leger pas in 1641 dit gewest onder Nederlands bestuur te krijgen. Het stadje Sergipe del Rey lag tussen de rivieren Varabarris en Rio Sergipe del Rey (nu Rio Sergipe), had drie kerken en een Franciscanenklooster. Op een heuvel lag een kapel die aan São Cristovao was gewijd. Er bevond zich in de Portugese periode geen fortificatie in en om de stad. Pas in 1641 werd er door de Nederlanders een fort gebouwd, tussen de rivieren Sergipe del Rey en São Francisco. In 1645 werd het gebied weer overgenomen door de Portugezen.

title: Serikkembelo
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The village of Serikkembelo, once known as Cambello, had long been subject to the king of Ternate, who was in a state of war with the Spanish. In 1607 Admiral Matelieff agreed with this king that the VOC would protect him against the Spanish, in exchange for cloves from all the Molucca Islands. Cambello was one of the first locations at which the VOC was permitted to build a trading post and a fort, under the terms of a contract with the local ruler. Cambello was one of the most important sources of cloves.

title: Serinhaem
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Sermata
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In the 18th century the VOC established a small outpost on Sermatte, a small island east of Timor. It was rarely manned by more than three soldiers.

title: Sero Lauw
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Serulau was a settlement on Hoamoal (Western Seram), a clove-producing region ruled by the <kimelaha>, the leader of Hoamoal with whom the VOC was periodically in conflict. At the end of the Great Ambon War (1651-1656), the entire peninsula was depopulated, and the people living there forced to resettle.

title: Shama
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Rond 1520 werd het fort St. Sebastian door de Portugezen gesticht. Rond 1683, toen de Nederlanders het fort overnamen, werd het fort gerestaureerd. De plaats werd door de WIC niet als een belangrijke handelspost gezien. Het plaatsje leverde enkel water, brandhout en slaven van lokale handelaren op. In het begin van de 18de eeuw ontstonden hier wel suiker- en katoenplantages. In 1872 ging het fort over naar de Engelsen.

title: Sharkej
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Sirkhej, or Sergees, now known as Sharkej, was a small town near Ahmadabad which was reputed to supply the best indigo in all India. The VOC opened a trading post there in the 17th century, which closed in 1670. Like many Indian cities, Sirkhej had a 'tang' or tank, which functioned primarily as a reservoir for the town's drinking water. In addition gardens were often laid out around these tangs, which served as the burial ground for leading citizens of the town. The tombs often took the shape of little round buildings.

title: Sherpur
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In the mid-17th centure the VOC maintained an office in Sherpur, but because the locally manufactured silk was not of the desired quality this trading post was abandoned after a time. The company had reckoned on there being a big demand for the silk in Japan, but it transpired that the silk from Cassimbazar yielded better returns. In order to save on costs, the silk was not stored in a brick warehouse but in the existing local depots.

title: Shiraz
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The company did not maintain a fully-fledged trading post here, but was represented by a number of intermediaries. However the VOC did accept the gift of a building where wine could be made. Most of the intermediaries were Armenians who bought the coveted attar of roses, or 'Shiraz wine' here. This arrangement continued until around 1730.Trade in Shiraz came under the Persian directorate. European VOC employees in Gamron would often stay in the relative cool of Shiraz during the summer months.

title: Siam, Maccassar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The land muster-rolls of the year 1790 refer to the VOC outpost of Siam, which fell under the colonial administration in Macassar. The Siam outpost employed 10 VOC employees while the entire colonial administration at Macassar employed 1519.

title: Siau
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Siau is the central island of the Sangir archipelago to the north of Sulawesi. The VOC had already established a presence here as early as 1616 when Siau was still a small and poor kingdom which enjoyed little trade. Alongside the stone fort of Doornenburg the Dutch built a smaller fort called Maetsuycker on the volcano. The Company maintained a presence in Siau right up until the mid-18th century, but Fort Doornenburg never numbered more than eight personnel.

title: Signal Hill
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Silalauw
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC built a blockhouse called Beverwijk in Sila on the island of Nusa Laut. Eight to 33 troops were stationed at the fort.

title: Simon' s Town
parent_name: Peninsula; Cape of Good Hope (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Simonstown lies on False Bay, to the south of Cape Town. A harbour was built here in 1743 because unfavourable winds between April and October made it difficult to anchor in Table Bay. By 1777 a hospital, a governor's house, warehouses and stables had been built.

title: Sint Joris Baai
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Sint Michielsbaai
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Er werd in 1744 fort St. Michiel gebouwd aan de Michielsbaai. Deze was gelegen ten westen van fort Amsterdam te Willemstad, het bolwerk van de WIC op Curaçao.

title: Sirri Sorrij
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Together with Oelath, Sirri Sorry on the Bay of Saparua was one of the most important trading centres on the island of Saparua. Together with Ulat and Ouw, Sirisori was situated in the most densely populated part of the island. Originally the VOC headquarters for the three islands Saparua (Honimoa), Haruku (Oma) and Nusa Laut were situated here, but this later became Fort Duurstede in Saparua town. Sirri Sorry had a redoubt, known as Hollandia. Originally a house built of wooden planks and used for storing merchandise, it was later upgraded to a small fort and subsequently a major castle. In 1669 its walls were heightened and a moat dug. The fort was demolished by an earthquake in 1671 but was subsequently rebuilt.

title: Slagbaai
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Smoke Alley
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Soecawayana
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Around 1730 the VOC maintained a fort and a trading station in Soecawayana. The settlement boasted a carpenter, a cooper and a blacksmith. In addition there was a powder room, lodgings for the military, a hospital and a church. The town was situated at the point where two rivers met; these were the Tsitaron, also known as the Beet River, and Tsikouw. The town was most likely also known as Tjikao at a later date. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Soetwaters Eijlant
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The land muster-rolls repeatedly refer to this island as one of the settlements near Tutucorin. The VOC outpost on the island was manned by one or two soldiers.

title: Somerset West
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The town of Somerset West was built in the 19th century, but the area was settled long before then. The residence of Willem Adriaan van der Stel, 'Vergelegen', was built here. Somerset West lies in a fertile, horseshoe-shaped valley, part of which is coastal. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Sommelsdijk
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Songkhla
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Soyo
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Soyo of Mpinda was een van de plaatsen aan de Angolese kust die de WIC in 1641 veroverde op de Portugezen. Net zoals in de nabijgelegen plaatsen Malemba en Cabinda werden ook hier slaven ingekocht. Na het verlies van de belangrijkste plaats aan deze kust, namelijk Loanda, waren de WIC-dienaren genoodzaakt ook de meeste andere posten van de WIC in dit gebied te verlaten. Na 1648 werd door de WIC niet meer gevaren op plaatsen die zuidelijker lagen dan Congo. Volgens kaart nr. VEL1052 (Nationaal Archief) zijn Sonho of Sango en Mpinda twee verschillende plaatsen.

title: St. Andries
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. St. Andries lay on the Malabar Coast, just under Manicorde. One of the VOC's many guardposts along the Malabar Coast was stationed here. The majority of such posts were in order to safeguard the pepper trade. Local traders attempted to transport their pepper via the inland waterways to the coast, where it generated more income. Thanks to its monopoly, the VOC was able to pay less.

title: St. Anna's dorp
variants: St. Anna's dorp;St. Annasdorp;dorp bij de Waterputten;Schottegat;Santa Annabaai
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Het dorp St. Anna, gelegen aan de noordoostelijke kant van het Schottegat, op Curaçao, was een van de eerste vestigingsplaatsen van de Nederlanders op het eiland. In 1639 werd hier een 'fort bij de waterputten' gebouwd ter bescherming ervan. Waarschijnlijk werd dit fort tot 1648 gebruikt.

title: St. Bastiaan
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The St. Sebastiaan pass was one of four in Colombo's immediate environs that has been noted in the land muster-rolls. A Portuguese monastery with the same name existed in Colombo.

title: St. Helena eiland
parent_name: St. Helena; Cape of Good Hope (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. St. Helena was used as a staging post on the way to Asia by the Portuguese, English and Dutch. The island had plenty of fresh water, bird life, domestic livestock run wild, and fish. In 1633 the Dutch Republic took possession of the island. During the second half of the 17th century, sovereignty over St. Helena alternated between the VOC and the British.

title: St. Kitts
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. St. Kitts was settled by English and French colonist in the years after 1623. Both groups settled at the two opposite extremes of the island. Hessel Gerritsz mentions in his Rotario that settlements could be found on three different sides of the island. On the southeast side, the French cultivated tabacco and held a fort, as they did on the west too. Two miles north of this site layed an English fort next to a river which offered good drinking water. The French were forced to dig holes to find proper water sources. The colonist, among whom several Dutchmen, focusses on the cultivation of tobacco, which made them dependent on importing food from other colonies. Dutch merchants on Sint-Eustatius saw their chances and traded food for salt.

title: St. Kruis
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Aan de baai van St. Kruis op Curaçao, waar tegenwoordig het gelijknamige plaatsje St. Kruis gelegen is, werd waarschijnlijk in het begin van de 18de eeuw een fort gebouwd, genaamd naar de plaats Santa Cruz. Vanuit dit fort konden de Nederlanders de baai beter verdedigen. In dezelfde periode werden de forten Westpunt en De Knip gebouwd.

title: St. Louis
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: St. Lucia
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. In the late 1550s, the French pirate François le Clerc (known as Jambe de Bois, due to his wooden leg) set up a camp on Pigeon Island, from where he attacked passing Spanish ships. In 1605, an English vessel called the Oliphe Blossome was blown off-course on its way to Guyana, and the 67 colonists started a settlement on Saint Lucia, after initially being welcomed by the Carib chief Anthonie. By 26 September 1605, only 19 survived, after continued attack by the Carib chief Augraumart, so they fled the island. In 1664, Thomas Warner (son of Sir Thomas Warner, the governor of St Kitts) claimed Saint Lucia for England. He brought 1,000 men to defend it from the French, but after two years, only 89 survived with the rest dying mostly due to disease. In 1666, the French West India Company resumed control of the island, which in 1674 was made an official French crown colony as a dependency of Martinique. Both the British and the French found the island attractive after the sugar industry developed, and during the 18th century the island changed ownership or was declared neutral territory a dozen times, although the French settlements remained and the island was a de facto French colony well into the eighteenth century. In 1722, George I of Great Britain granted both Saint Lucia and Saint Vincent to The 2nd Duke of Montagu. He in turn appointed Nathaniel Uring, a merchant sea captain and adventurer, as deputy-governor. Uring went to the islands with a group of seven ships, and established settlement at Petit Carenage. Unable to get enough support from British warships, he and the new colonists were quickly run off by the French.

title: St. Paul eiland
variants: St. Paul eiland;St. Paul;St. Paulo;St. Paulus
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: St. Thomas
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. San Thome lay on the Coromandel Coast. The Portuguese had a long-established presence here, for out of San Thome and Nagapatnam they were in a position to control the entire Coromandel Coast. San Thome subsequently fell under the king of Golconda, and later, in 1669, the Dutch took over. Even so, the town itself was subject to Portuguese influences for some considerable time. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: State Island
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Peter Minuit (ook wel: Minnewit), die in 1626 60 gulden (aan goederen) aan de Indianen had betaald voor het eiland Manhattan, kocht op verzoek van Michael Pauw in 1630 het tegenovergelegen gebied Staten Eiland. Pauw was patroon van het gebied Pavonia, dat iets ten noorden lag van Staten Eiland. In 1663 werd er een klein houten blokhuis opgericht ter protectie van de nieuwe kolonisten die zich op Staten Eiland gevestigd hadden.

title: Stellenbosch
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The refreshment station at Table Bay was never intended as a profit-making venture for the VOC. The Cape could only become self-supporting with the aid of a large population of white farmers. Until the late 17th century the European population was confined to the area between Cape Town and the first mountain ranges of the south-western Cape, an area of roughly 70 by 100 kilometres. In 1672 a large area of land was purchased from the Hottentots (the indigenous Khoi-khoi and San) and settlers began expanding beyond the Cape plain. In 1679, Stellenbosch was founded under the administration of Governor Simon van der Stel. The governor opened his own businesses in the town. After 1700 the colony's farming activities expanded even further east, and Stellenbosch became the name of a district.

title: Straat Le Maire
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Passage between Isla de los Estados (Staten Island) and Tierra del Fuego, charted in 1616 by the expedition of Schouten and Le Maire, which sailed through the passage when looking for a new route to Asia by sailing south of Tierra del Fuego.

title: Sukadana
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1617 Sukadana began supplying diamonds to the Company, which opened up a trading post there. In 1622 an army arrived from Mataram to avenge the murder of one of their traders. The VOC's trading post went up in flames and was never rebuilt, although trading still continued.

title: Sukaraja
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The tiny settlement of Soecapoera on the Tjiwoetan River numbered only a single VOC employee in 1765.

title: Sumedang
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The Company records show that in 1765 only a single employee was stationed in Soemadang, which was situated a little to the east of Bandung.

title: Sumenep
parent_name: Madura Island; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The island of Madura was conquered by Sultan Agung in 1624 and later in the seventeenth century was divided in three regencies: Bangkalan in the west, Pamekasan in the middle and Sumedang in the east. After the First Javanese War of Succession (1677-1707) Pamekasan and Sumedang placed themselves under VOC overlordship, so that the company inadvertently gained control of these regions. The rulers of three regencies, who had always supported the VOC against Mataram, were treated with great courtesy by the VOC Sumedang was a supplier of agricultural product to the VOC. The capital lied on the river Marengan which 10 kilometer to the south flow into Strait Madura. Only small craft could navigate on the river. The first Dutch fort which was built in 1705 stood near the mouth of the river.

title: Surabaya
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Because of its favourable situation on the Balinese Sea and its navigable river, Surabaya was one of the most important ports on the north coast. It was the only state that continued for years to offer resistance to the king of Mataram, who conquered all the coastal territories in the course of his campaigns. Eventually Surabaya also succumbed to Mataram until it fell under VOC control in 1743. It then became the seat of the official in charge of the north-eastern coast of Java.

title: Surakarta
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Keraton (Palace) Kasunanan is also called Surakarta Hadiningrat Palace was built in 1745 by Sultan Paku Buwono II. It started with the construction of Mataram Palace to replace the palace at Kartasura which was destroyed in the 1742's rebellion of the Chinese people against the power of Pakubuwono II, ruler at Kartasura. With the assistance of VOC the rebellion was squashed. Kartasura was retaken, but the palace was already destroyed and considered desecrated. Pakubuwono II then ordered Tumenggung (Minister) Honggowongso and Tumenggung Mangkuyudo and the Dutch commander J.A.B. van Hohendorff to find a location for the new capital of Mataram Kingdom. A new palace was then built on a site, 20 km South East of Kartasura, in 1745, at Sala Village, on the banks of the River Bengawan Solo. It was later renamed, Surakarta. (Old manuscripts mentioned, “Salakarta”). According to archives, the new palace was built using teak wood from Kethu Forest, a forest near Wonogiri city, and the logs were drifted to the site through the river. The new palace was officially taken in use on February 17, 1745.

title: Surat
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. After various unsuccessful attempts, the VOC opened a base in Surat in 1616. Surat was the main port of northern India, and belonged to the Great Mogul Empire. The merchants of Surat sailed to Persia, the Middle East and Southeast Asia. Initially the VOC purchased cotton fabrics from the Surat merchants who traded them in Atjeh. The fabrics were an indispensable means of exchange in the Moluccan spice trade. During the course of the 17th century the Company succeeded in capturing the bulk of the trade in cotton and spices between Surat and the archipelago. The VOC had no forts and relatively few employees in Surat. Compared with its other bases, the Company's military presence here was minimal. In the early 18th century the Mogul Empire began to decline. This led to unrest in the interior, and supplies of cotton and indigo to Surat dwindled. Trade with Persia also diminished as a result of political unrest. During the 18th century, Surat's role was taken over completely by Bombay, where the British maintained a trading base. The VOC carried on a flourishing trade at Surat. The Company had been granted a number of trading privileges by the Mogul emperor and the Surat directorate established other trading bases in centres as far away as Agra. Once the VOC started trading cotton and spices in the Red Sea region and opening trading bases there, many Surat merchants feared that they would lose out to the Company there too. But although there was a decline in the overland caravan trade through Persia as a result of the VOC's shipments of cotton and spices to Europe, the Company was never able to dominate the trade in the Red Sea region completely. The Company's directors and merchants in Surat lived in fabulous style. Their public appearances were as impressive as those of the local nobility or courtiers at India's imperial palace. For example, they would travel in canopied palanquins, accompanied by a complete retinue. It was often a source of considerable annoyance to Company officials in Batavia, but the Surat office maintained that it was essential to make a display of power and wealth in order to achieve anything in India. The VOC opened a base at Surat in 1616. The first director took up his post there in 1620. Surat was in English hands between 1781 and 1784. The VOC subsequently regained control only to lose it once more to the English in 1795.

title: Suriname Rivier
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. This river was the main artery of the Surinamese plantation industry.

title: Surnows Kreek
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. By the late eighteenth century the area around this creek was partially cultivated.

title: Suvali
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC outpost of Suvali lay to the north of Surat, on the coast. Because of the innumerable sandbanks, the harbour of Surat was only navigable for small vessels. As such Suvali's bay offered a good opportunity to lie at anchor. Due to its situation, from the 17th century onwards Suvali became the gateway for Dutch trade with the Gujarat region.

title: Swellendam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Swellendam was a district with a village of the same name in the eastern Cape. Governor Swellengrebel, who brought a string of new areas under the Company's control during his administration, named the outpost in 1748.

title: Syriam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC maintained several comptoirs in the kingdom of Pegu, including that of Siriangh. An office was set up here in 1635. Together with Martavaan, Siriangh was easy to access by water, unlike the other two comptoirs, Ava and Pegu, which were located in the interior. In 1679 the Company decided to disband the offices in Siriangh and Ava due to their 'improper actions and poor negotiation': 'hare onbehoorlyke maniere van doen en de slegte negotie'.

title: São Tomé
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Op 16 oktober 1641 veroverde Cornelis Jol, met een vloot van 21 schepen en 2100 man, het Portugese suikereiland São Thomé, dat voor de kust van Gabon ligt. Hij vertrok vanuit de Braziliaanse plaats Recife. Op dezelfde expeditie veroverde hij de stad Loanda, ofwel São Paulo de Loanda, in het huidige Angola. Op dat moment, rond 1640, had de WIC het grootste handelsimperium tijdens haar bestaan.In 1648 al weer, verloor de WIC haar post Loanda aan de Portugezen, waarmee het tij keerde. Niet alleen de comptoiren aan de Angolese kust werden aan de Portugezen overgelaten, maar ook de garnizoenen op São Thomé moesten het eiland verlaten.

title: Tacome
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Takome, on the northwest coast of Ternate, was a Ternatan town, conquered on the Spaniards by VOC troops and their allies in 1608. Initially an important collection point of cloves, its importance declined as the cultivation of cloves was increasingly moved to the Ambon islands in the course of the 17th century.

title: Tahuna
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Taboecan lay on the east coast of the island of Sangir, which was also known as Sangi or Sangihe. The VOC constructed a lodge here, but this was never manned by more than around 11 people. Taboecan was one of the most important settlements on the island of Sangir, numbering around 800 households. The island was rich in good wood that was used both to build houses and ships. In addition the island was a rich source of coconut oil, used by the VOC in preparing food for the garrison and as lamp fuel.

title: Takoradi
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Volgens de 17de eeuwse schrijver en hostoricus Olfert Dapper zouden de Nederlanders en de Engelsen al voor de stichting van fort Witsen in Takoradi, in 1665, schepen naar deze locatie hebben gestuurd om daar in goud te handelen. De Engelsen zouden hier tijdig mee zijn opgehouden, vanwege de tegenvallende aanwezigheid van de grondstof. Toch bouwden de Nederlanders er in 1665 fort Witsen. Dit fort wordt echter na een paar jaar verwoest. In 1684 wordt fort Witsen verlaten. Een kaart uit 1791 (Nationaal Archief VEL0759) laat zien dat de WIC dan nog steeds (of weer) aanwezig is in het fort.

title: Taliabu
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The island of Taljabo, the largest in the Sula archipelago, was situated east of Sulawesi. In 1705 the VOC had seconded two employees to the island of Taljabo.

title: Tamandarè
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Tamma Callang
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The land muster-rolls of 1735 refer to an outpost called Tamma Callang, which was occupied by seven VOC employees. The exact location of this VOC post is unclear, although its classification in the aforementioned land muster-rolls indicate that it was a post in north Sulawesi.

title: Tampakamam
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Tampakam, once known as Tambamme, was home to one of the VOC churches. The Company employed many clergymen who preached the faith in what were often the most rudimentary of churches. The VOC awarded so-called disciple money to preachers for every soul they managed to convert to Christianity. Little attention was paid to how genuine their faith was. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Tan-shui
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Shortly after Fort Zeelandia was built in 1624, the Company governors in Batavia decided to build another fort in the north of Formosa, opting for the town off Tamsui near Kelang. According to Pieter van Dam, who recorded the history of the VOC around 1701, the town of Tamsui, or Tansoui as he calls it, boasted a fine harbour. The local industry included pearl diving and there was also alluvial gold.

title: Tanete
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Tangail
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Tangalla
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The Tangale settlement was favourably situated on the island's southern coast and was frequently used for loading products such as rice. A fort and a church were built at Tangale in 1775. This small VOC settlement played a key role during the Sinhalese uprising of 1760 against the Dutch authorities on the south of the island.

title: Tanimbar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Tanjong Poura
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Tanjongpoera lay east of Batavia in the Krawangsche district. The Company had maintained a timber yard here since the early years of its existence. In the 18th century Tandjongpoera became a key place for monitoring the cultivation of indigo. The Company built a fort here.

title: Tanjung Timur
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Tanjung Timur was initially a country estate south of Batavia on the Tjiliwoeng River, today known as Ciliwung. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Tanjung West
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Tanjungpinang
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Riouw, today known as Tanjungpinang, was a major port in the Malacca Straits. From the second half of the 18th century onwards, the VOC made several attempts to gain control of the harbour at Riouw, where the private trade in tin was concentrated. Riouw was known as a staple market, where people made their living from free trade. During the VOC era, the town fell under the authority of the Sultan of Jahore. The Company wished to subject this port to its rule, but the sultan was able to prevent this. It was only in the late 18th century, around 1784, that the VOC appointed a resident to gather the tolls. However the free trade in tin, which the VOC regarded as illicit trade, continued.

title: Tapajos rivier
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Tappenoulie
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The land muster-rolls of 1760 refer to a VOC station by the name of Tappenoulie, which in that year employed five VOC employees.

title: Tarrytown
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Tarrytown is een plaats aan de Hudson rivier, iets ten noorden van Manhattan, aan de oostelijke kant van de rivier gelegen. De plaats heeft haar ontstaan te danken aan Adriaen van der Donck. Hij kreeg van de WIC toestemming om een patroonschap te stichten in Tarrytown. De naam Tarrytown is waarschijnlijk een verbastering van 'tarwe'. Toen de eerste Nederlandse kolonialen in 1644 hier aankwamen, verwoestten zij het oorspronkelijke dorp Alipconk, waar Wecquaesgeek Indianen woonden.

title: Tarusan
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Tasso Island
variants: Tasso Island;Ilha de Taço;Ilha de Taço;I. Tassa;Tassa
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Tasso is de naam van een eilandje in de monding van een rivier aan de kust van Sierra Leone. Het Engelse fort op het eiland werd in 1664 door admiraal Michiel de Ruyter geplunderd. Het is niet echt duidelijk of er sprake is geweest van een Nederlandse vestiging.

title: Tatta
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Pieter van Dam, who recorded the history of the VOC around 1701, refers to a comptoir of the Company in Sindh on the mouth of the Indus River. The comptoir bought up all manner of textiles.
