Dutch contacts with Sind took place in the year 1632 and in 1757. Subsequently and for a short time, from 1660-1662, there was a trading post established.

title: Tawariekoera (kreek)
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. By the late eighteenth century, the area around this creek was cultivated.

title: Tegal
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC officials in Tegal had a permanent base close to the most important markets. They purchased pepper and rice, which were then transported in small quantities by buffalo cart to the main trading post. Here too, the Company blockaded the rivers after the rice harvest so that local traders were forced to sell their rice to the VOC first, at low prices.

title: Tellippalai
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The clergyman Baldaeus led the congregations of northern Ceylon. He left a detailed description of his parish. He described the inhabitants of Tellippalai, once known as Telipole, as being keenly interested in the Christian religion. In 1658 the church at Tellippalai was the venue for Baldaeus's first sermon in Ceylon. The church had a theatre attached. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Tempati (kreek)
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Tempati Creek is located in Sipaliwini, Suriname. During the 18th century several plantations were built in the surrounding area.

title: Tengapatnam, Malabaar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Tengapatnam was the southern-most VOC settlement on the Malabar Coast. It was situated in the area of Travancore, south of today's Trivandrum. The VOC established a settlement here in order to prevent other European companies entering Malabar from the south. Contracts were sealed with the rajah, agreeing that the pepper grown in the region could only be supplied to the VOC. Of course this was not always the case. For this reason Tengapatnam also functioned as a guard post to combat smuggling.

title: Tent Bay
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Terlucco
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Terlucco was a VOC outpost on the east coast of the island of Ternate, just north of Malayo. In 1610 the VOC built a fort here known as Tolucco or Hollandia in a bid to prevent the Spanish from establishing a settlement here and thereby making the harbour unsafe. The fort was built of stone and slaked lime, and had an unusual layout that differed entirely from that of other fortifications built by the Dutch. It could be that the unusual construction was linked to the fort's location on the very point of a cliff.

title: Ternate
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Fort Oranje was built by the VOC in 1607 in Malayo on Ternate. It was a strong fortress surrounded by a moat. Various other forts were later built on Ternate, or captured from the Spanish. The VOC's military power on Ternate was mainly intended to fight the smugglers who traded with their competitors, and to maintain the clove monopoly. In 1801 Fort Oranje fell to the English. The clove-producing North Molucca Islands were divided into a number of small states, the most powerful of which was the sultanate of Ternate. The earliest contacts between the Dutch and Ternate date back as far as 1599. In 1607 the sultan of Ternate asked the VOC to provide it with assistance against an attack by the Spanish. Although it proved impossible to drive the Spaniards off the island completely, the Company did obtain an agreement granting a monopoly of the clove trade. Ternate was dependent on foreign traders to sell its cloves and import foodstuffs. The ships used in the area, known as cora-coras, were used for warfare, and were not suitable for trading transport. The VOC's trade monopoly in Ternate also made the island dependent on the Company for food imports. But because the VOC imports were insufficient to meet the demand, the inhabitants of Ternate were continually forced to violate the monopoly. The VOC did all it could to stamp out the smuggling, and often used violence. The trade agreements with the sultan were ceremonially reaffirmed regularly after they had been broken. Each time the sultan had to promise not to supply cloves to anyone other than the Company. The food shortages that plagued the population because of the Company monopoly led to revolts, which the VOC crushed with much bloodshed. In 1677 the sultan of Ternate was finally stripped of all his military power and made permanently subject to the VOC. Prior to the foundation of Batavia in 1619, the VOC's governor-generals were more or less peripatetic; taking up residence alternately on Ambon and in Fort Oranje on Ternate. After 1619 the governor of the Molucca Islands resided for a time in the fort on Ternate.

title: Tessindia
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location (Koninlijke Bibliotheek, inv.nr. 185 A 5 deel V, I, na p. 146) featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Teun
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Thewer, now known as Teun, is a small island east of the island of Damar. The VOC maintained a small outpost here that throughout the 18th century was usually manned by three soldiers.

title: Thiruppapuliyur
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Thiruppapuliyur lay 70 miles north of Nagapatnam, not far from Tegenapatam. The Dutch established a presence here as early as 1608. The trading post collected indigo, 'Guinees kantoen' and other products, such as saltpetre. The trade here served as a catalyst for the inter-Asian dealings of the VOC.

title: Tidore
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In 1605 the VOC conquered the island of Tidore. The Portuguese had a number of bases on the island; after their defeat by the VOC, they left the Molucca islands for good. The subjection of the sultan of Tidore, who had long been the major competitor and enemy of the sultan of Ternate, was of strategic importance to the VOC. It enabled the Company to secure a trade monopoly in the Molucca islands. As well as food crops, Tidore also produced cloves. After the VOC's conquest of the Portuguese territories, the sultan of Tidore appealed to the Spanish in Manila for assistance. The Spanish who succeeded in establishing a foothold on Tidore remained on the island until 1663. Only after their departure was the VOC able to gain complete control over the trade there. The Company's presence on Tidore was always limited to small military posts; the island lacked a good harbour, and so a trading station was never opened there.

title: Tifore
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Tiku
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Ticous lay north of Priaman on the West Coast of Sumatra. The VOC set up an office here around 1667 after abandoning its post on the island of Tjinko, also known as Poulo Tjinko. Ticous was a centre for the pepper trade. The VOC supplied cloths and 'lijnwaten' or cotton textiles, in exchange for the pepper.

title: Tiruchchirappalli
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Tirumullaivasal
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Titaway
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Little is known of the village of Titaway on the west coast of the island of Nusa Laut other than that the VOC maintained a guard post here in the 18th century which was never manned by more than two soldiers.

title: Tiworo
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Tiworo (also known as Pantsiano) was a polity around the eponymous Tiworo Strait, south of Southeast Sulawesi, with its capital on the north side of the island of Muna. It stood under control of Makassar and functioned as a refuge and staging area for Makasar fleets going to and from the Ambon Islands, to trade there or assist in the fight against the Dutch. In January 1655, during the Great Ambon War (1651-1656), a VOC fleet destroyed this capital.

title: Tjeparra
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Tjepara should not be confused with Jepara, a bigger city east of Semarang. The Tjepara referred to here was situated in the immediate vicinity of Batavia and was a small VOC post that is only mentioned a few times in the land muster-rolls. Where it is mentioned, the records indicated that only a single VOC employee was stationed there.

title: Tobo
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Tobo was a fortified village on the south coast of Seram, which was besieged by VOC troops and their allies, led by governor Artus Gijsels, in 1631. An image of the village was included in the latter's personal archive.

title: Tocujos eiland
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Tokai
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Tokai country house on the Cape Peninsula, south of the Cape of Good Hope, was built around 1795 by J.A. Rauch, a German. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Tolitoli
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The small VOC outpost of Tontoli in northern Sulawesi had a safe harbour. During the 17th century the area was for a many years governed by a triumvirate. There were three brothers, one of whom was king, one who was governor and one who was captain.

title: Tontotte
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Tontotte was a tiny guard post on the Kelani River, east of Negombo. The Company built various small forts along the river. Tontotte boasted a simple fort with four points and a wooden house in the middle. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Torarica meer
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Travancore
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Trincomalee
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The deep bay of Trincomalee was an ideal natural harbour and shelter for ships. In 1639 the VOC captured Trincomalee from the Portuguese. The port was strategically important as a base for the fleet and guarding the sea routes. In the 17th century the port was guarded by as many as six forts. Even so, this proved insufficient to repel the French, who attacked in 1672. The port was soon recaptured. Because of its unhealthy climate, Trincomalee was unpopular among Company employees. Ceylon's main product was cinnamon, and small amounts were also harvested at Trincomalee. To harvest the cinnamon, the bark is cut from the tree. It is then dried in the sun and rolled up. The area around Trincomalee also supplied clothes, pearls, wood, and the stimulant areca. During the 17th century the East Indies Council in Batavia debated several times whether to hand Trincomalee over to the king of Kandy. Rijcklof van Goens, governor of Ceylon, opposed this vigorously. He preferred to fortify the harbour, and it was he who increased the number of forts to six. When English competition in the region increased in the late 18th century, the forts were further strengthened. Because of its strategic importance the harbour was a constant centre of political discord.

title: Trindade en Martim Vaz
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The Trindade and Martin Vaz Islands were discovered in 1502 by Portuguese navigators led by Estêvão da Gama, and, They were officially claimed by Portugal, but remained uninhabited. A Dutch expedition to the island in 1665 similarly found the islands to be too inhospitable for a settlement.

title: Trinidad
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. This Caribbean Island was a Spanish colony, until its conquest by the British in 1797.

title: Tristan da Cunha eilanden
variants: Tristan da Cunha eilanden;Tristan De Acunha eilanden
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The islands were first recorded as sighted in 1506 by Portuguese explorer Tristão da Cunha; rough seas prevented a landing. He named the main island after himself, Ilha de Tristão da Cunha. It was later anglicised from its earliest mention on British Admiralty charts, to Tristan da Cunha Island. Some sources state that the Portuguese made the first landing in 1520, when the Lás Rafael captained by Ruy Vaz Pereira called at Tristan for water. The first undisputed landing was made on 7 February 1643 by the crew of the Dutch East India Company ship Heemstede, captained by Claes Gerritsz Bierenbroodspot. The Dutch stopped at the island four more times in the next 25 years, and in 1656 created the first rough charts of the archipelago.The first full survey of the archipelago was made by crew of the French corvette Heure du Berger in 1767. The first scientific exploration was conducted by French naturalist Louis-Marie Aubert du Petit-Thouars, who stayed on the island for three days in January 1793, during a French mercantile expedition from Brest, France to Mauritius. Aubert made botanical collections and reported traces of human habitation, including fireplaces and overgrown gardens, probably left by Dutch explorers in the 17th century.

title: Tulbagh
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Around 1720 it was decided to establish a string of small outposts at strategic locations. Roodezand was one of these, along with Groene Cloof, Saldanha Bay and Klapmuts. Many farmers established holdings in the area around Roodezand and it soon grew into a sizeable community. Wheat was the principal crop. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Tumble Down Dick Bay
variants: Tumble Down Dick Bay;Tommeldijkbaai;Tumble Down Dick Bay
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Tuticorin
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Tuticorin was a large town: by 1700 it numbered around 50,000 inhabitants. In 1658 Rijcklof van Goens captured the town for the VOC in a bloodless take-over. Once the VOC had secured a monopoly on the pearl trade, it kept a strict watch to ensure that all the pearls were sold in Tuticorin. Like the other Dutch bases on India's southern coast, Tuticorin fell under Ceylonese jurisdiction.

title: Udupiddi
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. As elsewhere in Ceylon the Portuguese introduced the Catholic faith to Udupiddi, once known as Ureputti. The Company aimed in turn to convert the Catholics of Ceylon to Protestantism. Nevertheless, the Portuguese Catholic influence remained strong. In order to counter this influence it was decided in the 1690s actively to stimulate the growth of a local Protestant elite. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Uduvil
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. In the wake of the Portuguese Catholic mission the VOC introduced its own Protestant missionaries in the latter half of 17th century. In doing so the Company made grateful use of the Portuguese churches. With a congregation numbering around 1,000, Uduvil, once known as Oudewil, was a comparatively large community. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Uijtkijk
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Ulat
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Oelath, situated on the Bay of Saparua, was a busy trade centre alongside the village of Sirri Sorry. Throughout the 18th century this outpost was never manned by more than a single soldier. The land muster-rolls always refer to this village alongside that of Ouw.

title: Unare rivier
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Unawatuna
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Unawatuna is situated on the opposite side of the bay to Galle. Unawatuna and environs were of key importance to the fresh water supply for Galle. The governor commissioned a country residence named 'Nooit Gedacht' to be built there in 1735. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Ungaran
parent_name: Java; Java's North East Coast (VOC area)
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Oenarang was a village situated at the foot of a mountain, between Semarang and Salatiga. The mountain slopes were used to cultivate various crops and orchards and black sugar was grown there. According to Pieter van Dam, who recorded the history of the VOC around 1701, Oenarang had a population of 300 or 400 households subject to the local ruler. When the VOC established a presence here in 1780 it built the fort 'de Ontmoeting'.

title: Untung Jawa
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Small island to the northwest of what was formerly Batavia

title: Vaddukoddai
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Vaddukoddai, known to the Europeans as Batecotte, was a prosperous fishing village. A saltwater river ran past the village. The church was one of the few with several floors and dated from the Portuguese period. The church hall housed a school for religious education for the local inhabitants. The church was still in use as late as 1990. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Vadodara
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. During the 17th century the VOC maintained a trading post in the affluent city of Baroda, which was situated north of Surat in the interior, on the route between Broach and Ahmedabad. Baroda was particularly well known for its coarsely woven cottons, that were exported via Cambay by Portuguese, Jewish, Muslim and Hindu merchants. In the surrounding region the people grew indigo. The pigment was not of a particularly good quality and for this reason served as a dyestuff for cheaper types of textiles. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Vaersenbaai
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Valdívia
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. De verovering van Brazilië had de Heren XIX doen hopen dat er ook andere streken van Zuid-Amerika onder Nederlandse invloed konden worden onderworpen. De West-Indische Compagnie hoopte met de expeditie naar Chili zelf aan het goud en zilver te kunnen komen dat voorheen alsmaar in Spaanse handen was. De expeditie, onder leiding van Brouwer en Herckmans, vertrok in 1642 vanuit Nederland. Via Recife, de hoofdplaats van Nederlands-Brazilië, werd naar Chili gereisd. De expeditie werd geen succes. Het lukte de WIC niet om zich er langer dan een paar maanden te vestigen. Het eerste doel was het eiland Chiloe, een strategisch punt van waaruit de Zuid-Amerikaanse kust aangevallen kon worden. Vanuit dit eiland deden de Nederlanders in 1643 de haven van Valdivia aan. Valdivia was ooit een van de machtscentra van de Spanjaarden en werd in 1599 verwoest en heroverd door de Chilenen. De Nederlanders kregen van de Chileense bevolking toestemming om op het plein van Valdivia een schans te bouwen. De Nederlanders, op zoek naar goud, werden door de inwoners van Valdivia ontmoedigd dit metaal te zullen vinden. Na een jaar werd Valdivia verlaten omdat de Spaanse vloot vanuit de hoofdstad Lima op weg was en de gevraagde Nederlandse versterkingen vanuit Brazilië niet op tijd in Valdivia aankwamen. Herckmans keerde met zijn mannen terug naar Brazilië, Brouwer was al eerder op het eiland Chiloe overleden.

title: Vannarponai
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The natives of Vannarponai village processed cotton. They dyed cotton fabrics with the plant dye known as 'saeye' that was readily available in northern Ceylon. The dye was reddish brown in colour. This village, too, had its own Protestant church. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Varani
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The Company preached Protestantism to the local inhabitants on Ceylon. Baldaeus, the clergyman who headed the congregations of northern Ceylon from 1656 to 1665, regularly toured his parish. He described Varani, once known as Waranni, as rich in tropical fruits with a rather dilapidated church building. The compilers of this database have not as yet come across a source in the literature that identifies this location as a VOC post.

title: Varzea
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Vembar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Bempaar was one of the VOC outposts north of Tutucorin.

title: Vengurla
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC opened a base in Vengurla in 1637. This town was an important market for VOC mace and cloves from the Molucca Islands, and was itself a supplier of pepper. In 1673 Batavia decided to place this base under the control of Surat. When the VOC conquered the south coast of India a few years later, Cochin took over Vengurla's role as the principal transshipment port on India's southern coast. The VOC deserted Vengurla in 1685.

title: Vergenoegd
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Verlaatene S.E. Compagnies post
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: Victoria
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Vierendepatnam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Vila Velha
variants: Vila Velha;Schoppestad;Van Schoppe stad;Nossa Senhora da Conceicao;Schop;Nostre Signora de Conception
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In 1633 werd het eiland van Itamaracá, ten noorden van Olinda en Recife gelegen, bezet door Nederlandse soldaten onder leiding van kolonel van Schoppe. Niet alleen het fort aan de zeekant werd door de Nederlanders versterkt, maar ook besloten de nieuwe bezetters een vestiging te stichten op een heuvel, waar al een kleine kerk en een batterij bestonden uit de Portugese tijd. De plaats, eerder bekend onder de naam van Nossa Senhora da Conceicao, werd een versterkte nederzetting en kreeg de naam Van Schoppe stad ofwel Schoppestad. Door de strategische ligging was het vanuit deze plaats mogelijk om een groot deel van eiland te verdedigen.

title: Vishakapatnam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Vishakapatnam was a small village close to Bimilipatnam, where the VOC had established a lodge. The outpost was founded in the early 17th century. In Vizagapatnam the Company was able to buy in goods such as coarsely woven cotton, rice and arrack. The shipyard at Vishakapatnam served for the repair of the Company's ships. Around 1619 the VOC lodge at Masulipatnam was closed temporarily and the VOC employees there were temporarily transferred to the lodge at Vishakapatnam.

title: Vishoek
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. This post on the False Bay coast between Muijsenberg and Simon's Bay was a centre of the fishing industry. Here fish was caught, salted and dried as supplies for the vessels en route to the east. The post had a fish-house and a gardener's hut that also functioned as a storage depot for vegetables. The post was manned by sailors and a quartermaster. When the Gentlemen Seventeen ordered around 1790 that the system of Company stations around the Cape be rationalised, the post at Vishoek was abandoned. All its tasks were subsequently carried out by the post at Simon's Bay, which lay further south and was more favourably situated to serve passing ships.

title: Visschers Kreek
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Visserhoek
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The cattle post Vissershoek was situated on the Dieprivier, a few kilometres northeast of the post at Bommelshok. Pieter van Dam, who recorded the history of the VOC around 1701, notes that in the year 1693 the post was manned by two Company employees and a slave. The post had a flock of 836 sheep.

title: Vlamingo Kreek
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Vredenburg
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Vypin
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Vypin was an elongated island situated between Cochin and the mouth of the Peryar River. During the siege of Cochin in 1663, the island was further reinforced with a fort, Nieuw-Orangieën. The island was also home to a leper colony.

title: Waai
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. In Way the VOC built fortifications later christened 'Amersfoort'. A corporal and several soldiers were stationed there.

title: Wacogenive rivier, post aan de
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Waeputih
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Together with a number of other small villages, Waeputih, situated in west Ceram on the Hoamoal peninsula, fell under the aegis of Luhu with its Overburg redoubt. According to the land muster-rolls of 1775, Waeputih was a new post employing 26.

title: Waisama
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Waisama is situated on Buru, a big island at the far west side of the Ambon Islands. In the first half of the 17th century, it was officially under indirect rule from the Sultan of Ternate. As opposed to Western Seram, the VOC did not have much involvement in the region in this period. However, as the island was sometimes used as a hiding place and staging area by opponents of the VOC monopoly from e.g. Makassar, when they came to fight and/or trade in the islands, the VOC sometimes sent expeditions there to find and destroy such fleets. In 1657 the VOC officially became the ruler of Waisama, along with all of Buru, when the indirect rule of Ternate was abolished. Even after that time, however, the VOC had limited power and influence there.

title: Wajer
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The nutmeg plantations named Waijer on the eastern coast of the island of Lonthoroot were guarded by a fort of the same name, Wayer, also sometimes called Concordia. The land muster-rolls for the year 1691 also refer to the fort by the name of Orangie. The fort with its triangular base was built in 1639. Over the years it was severely weakened by a series of earthquakes. For this reason it was demolished in 1732, soon to be replaced with a new fort on a square base. Situated close by was a warehouse for the storage of nutmeg

title: Wakenaam Island
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Walawe
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The small town of Walawe is situated at the mouth of the Walawe River in the south of the island of Sri Lanka. The salt pans were to be found in the region between Walawe and Panama. Before the VOC gained power here, the salt pans served to supply the king of Kandy. Once the region fell under the influence of the VOC and the Company acquired a monopoly on the salt, relations between the Dutch and the kingdom of Kandy deteriorated.

title: Wana (kreek)
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. By the late eighteenth century the area around this creek was cultivated.

title: Wancan
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Wanicka kreek
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. This creek was a tributary to the Saramacca not too far from Paramaribo, and gave its name both to the Wanica path leading from Paramaribo to the Saramacca river, and to the Wanica canal, dug in the late 18th century to connect the Saramacca and Surinam Rivers.

title: Wayamoe, kreek
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. The Wayamoe creek is a stream and is located in Marowijne, Suriname. The area was cultivated in the course of the 18th century.

title: Waynitoe
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Waynitoe was a tiny VOC outpost set up to defend the Bay of Ambon. The settlement has since been swallowed up by Ambon City.

title: Welgelegen
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Welgelegen country house was assinged to J. van der Heiden in 1676. The entrance to the estate dates from 1757. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: Welgemoedt
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Weligama
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Beligao, was the name the Portuguese gave to Weligama, situated in southern Ceylon between Gale and Matara. Due to its favourable situation on a bay to the south of the island, Weligama was used by the VOC as a guardpost. Cinnamon was grown on a large scale in the surrounding region, but the area also produced many roof and floor tiles and bricks for the VOC.

title: Wellington
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Werinama
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. A literary source identifying this location as a VOC post has not yet been traced. The images of this location featured in this programme currently serve as source.

title: West End
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Westpunt (Curaçao)
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. In het tegenwoordige plaatsje Westpunt, gelegen op de meest uiterste westpunt van Curaçao, bouwden de Nederlanders voor het jaar 1774 een fort, bewapend met een kanon.

title: Wetar
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Wetter, now known as Wetar and situated to the north east of the island of Timor, was one of the islands referred to in Company documents as 'Zuid-wester Eylanden'. This group of islands in its entirety fell under the government at Banda, and not under the aegis of Timor, which was situated nearer by.

title: White Hook
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Wia-Wia kust
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The Wia Wia Coast is the mangrove coast east of Paramaribo, towards the Marowijne river

title: Wiapoco, post aan de
variants: post aan de Wiapoco;post aan de Oyapoc;post aan de Oiapoque
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Willemstad
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Wilmington
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Op bevel van de Zweden bouwde Peter Minuit, de voormalige gouverneur van Nieuw-Nederland, fort Christina. Dit gebeurde in 1638 op de westelijke oever van de Delaware Rivier. Toen de Nederlanders het fort overnamen in 1655, herdoopten zij het met de naam Altena. Het fort werd versterkt en voorzien van een garnizoen.

title: Wironje Kreek, post aan de
variants: post aan de Wironje Kreek;post aan de Wiruni Creek
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Witteboomen
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The area at the foot of the Constantiaberg was named 'Witte Boomen' (White Trees) after the silver-coloured trees that grew there. As early as 1668 the VOC had already established a woodcutters' yard in the region.

title: Wokam
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. 'Aroe' referred to one of the Aru islands that lay in eastern Indonesia, south of Irian Jaya. The land muster-rolls of the year 1785 refer to the archipelago as the 'Zuidooster Eylanden'. In that year the outpost on Aroe, then named Wokan, was manned by 11 VOC employees. The island was famous for its oyster banks. A report about the post written by the 2 VOC officials Cornelis Stul and Carel Roosenburgh, who visited the island in 1683, paints a bleak picture of the situation at the time. They found a nurse and two soldiers seriously ill and a half-blind sergeant. The schoolmaster who had been appointed to bring Christianity to the indigenous population was absent, having undertaken a journey in order to promote his private trading interests. The governor further learned that two other VOC employees had been murdered, while a third had died not long before his visit.

title: Worcester
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Wynberg
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. Several farmers settled on the slopes of the Wijnberg, a hill near the grain store, de Schuur, and Constantia. According to Pieter van Dam, who recorded the history of the VOC around 1701, in 1693 Wijnberg numbered a community of 32 company employees and 262 cattle.

title: Yala
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The VOC built a redoubt in Yala, on Ceylon's south coast. Like Panama and Mahagama, Yala was a key location to the VOC in maintaining the Company's monopoly of the salt trade.

title: Yonkers
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company. Jonkheer Adriaen van der Donck diende een tijdje (1641-1643) als 'sheriff' in Rensselaerswijck, de kolonie in de omgeving van fort Oranje, te Beverwijck (Albany). Toen hij een patroonschap (zoals Rensselaerswijck) voor zichzelf wilde, verkreeg hij van de West-Indische Compagnie een stuk land, dat hij Colen Donck noemde. Het lag ietsje ten noorden van Manhattan. Patroonschappen werden door de WIC verleend aan een soort van plantagehouders, met het verschil dat een plantage meestal uit één hoofdhuishouden bestaat en een patroonschap uit veel meer huishoudens.Van der Donck stelde zich Nieuw-Nederland voor als een voortvarend gebied vol met bruisende steden. Dankzij zijn inspanningen verkreeg Nieuw-Amsterdam in 1653 stadsrechten. Daarnaast schreef Van der Donck een uitgebreid werk over Nieuw-Nederland.

title: Zaane
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company. The land muster-rolls indicated that Zaane was a small VOC outpost on Ambon. Its precise location is unclear.

title: Zandpunt
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Zeelandia Baai
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Zeven Provincien
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: Zuidkant
description: Locality associated with Dutch West India Company.

title: onbekend China
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: onbekend Indonesië
description: Locality associated with Dutch East India Company.

title: onbekend Zuid-Afrika
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies.

title: Xiamen
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. - Amoy, present-day Xiamen, was a port city on the eponymous island at China's southeast coast. After the VOC had settled on Taiwan in 1624, hoping to be able to set up regular trade with China from there, they were regularly active in the area around Xiamen. This area was the power base of the Zheng clan, a mighty maritime faction with much influence on the China Sea and along the coast, with which the VOC had a rather tenuous relationship. In the 1630s, the VOC fought several battles near the islands, sometimes as an ally of clan leader Zheng Zhilong, sometimes as his enemy. - After the fall of the Ming Dynasty (1644) Zhilong's son, Zheng Chenggong (known in the Dutch sources as Koxinga) became the dominant power in the region. From the nearby island of Jinmen (known in Dutch sources as Quemoy), he launched an invasion of Taiwan in 1661, which would drive the Dutch from the region. - The river which floats out onto the ocean just west of Xiamen, the Jiulong, was known to the Dutch as the Chincheo. - Nowadays, Xiamen is Chinese territory, whereas Jinmen is Taiwanese.

title: Tonga
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The Tonga islands were visited by Abel Tasman's expedition in January 1643.

title: Osaka
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Osaka was an important commercial center in early modern Japan. The Castle of Osaka located here was the last holdout against Japanese unification in 1615. From the 17th century onwards, VOC tribute missions passed through Osaka en route to the Shogunal court in Edo.

title: Edo
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Edo (present-day Tokyo) was the seat of the Tokugawa shoguns from 1603 onwards. VOC envoys therefore visited the city every few years.

title: Dabul
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Dabhol was an important trading port in the Islamic trade network in the Indian Ocean. In 1508, it, fell victim to a brute retaliation attack by the Portuguese following the Battle of Diu. All the same, the city was never colonized by either the Portuguese or the Dutch. It does regularly feature in early modern Dutch cartographic material.

title: Matanzas (Bay)
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. Bay on the north coast of Cuba, known in Dutch history and cartographic material as took a Spanish silver fleet there in 1628.

title: Mexico City
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. This importans Spanish colonial city was built over the original Aztec capital Tenochtitlan. Although it features regularly in Dutch cartographic material, the Dutch never held any infuence in the area.

title: Rio de Janeiro
description: Locality indirectly linked to Dutch East or West India Compagnies. The rivermouth giving its name to the present Brazilian city features regularly on Dutch cartographic material. However, the Dutch never controlled this area in any way.
